sourceDesc.p: Annotations for the Digital Anon project

person.note: Sir Francis Acton is an antagonist in one of the two intertwined subplots of Thomas Heywood's domestic tragedy A Woman Killed with Kindness. He is the brother of Anne Frankford (persistently referred to by Woolf as Frankland). He and Sir Charles Mountford brawl over the result of a hawking competition, and in the brawl Mountford kills Acton's two huntsmen. Mountford is released from prison but left impoverished by the fees: at the time Heywood was writing, English gaols charged their inmates for food, upkeep, and any privileges that an inmate could afford, and becomes significantly indebted and returns to prison as a debtor. Seeking further revenge against Mountford, Acton decides to seduce Mountford's sister, Susan. Acton wishes to use their affair to disgrace Mountford but falls in love with Susan. Hoping to win Susan's affection, Acton pays off Mountford's debts and drops charges for the murder of his huntsmen. In a gesture of thanks, Mountford offers his sister to Acton, whether to marry or 'To seize her as a rape or lustful prey [...] To murder her that never meant thee harm' (14.127-9). Susan reluctantly agrees to marry Acton when he professes his genuine love for her. See A Woman Killed With Kindness for more details.

series.title: Arden early modern drama

person.note: Henricus Cornelius Agrippa von Nettesheim was a 15th and 16th century German polymath who claimed to have doctoral degrees in theology, medicine, and law. He wore many hats over his life, teaching at the universities of Dôle and Padua, practiced law in Metz and medicine in Geneva, Fribourg and Antwerp, acted as court astrologer to Louise de Savoi in Lyon and court historiographer to Margaret of Austria (cf. Hoorens and Renders, pp. 3-4). Agrippa was best known, however, as the author of works of skeptical and occultist philosophy. However, it should be noted that the Agrippa Woolf names in these drafts is somewhat of an outlier: an early modern interloper among lists of classical orators and writers. Of the many ancient Romans named Agrippa, Woolf may have had in mind Marcus Vipsanius Agrippa (c. 63–12 BCE), statesman and soldier discussed by Horace, Suetonius, and Livy, among others.

analytic.title: Heinrich Cornelius Agrippa and Witchcraft: A Reappraisal

person.note:
If these drafts can be said to have a hero, Anon is that hero. Anon is VW's figuration for the oral ballad tradition that pre-dates and prefigures English literature and literary language: Anon's 'common voice singing out of doors' (M51. Anon... fol. 1r) is the necessary precondition for English literature. In these drafts, Anon is 'sometimes woman; sometimes man' (M45. Anon. fol. 5r), and the narrator of Room, theorising about a 'lost novelist, a suppressed poet', 'venture[s] to guess that Anon, who wrote so many poems without signing them, was often a woman', but VW uses masculine pronouns almost exclusively to refer to Anon herein.
Anon is born from the primeval forests that cover Britain's landmass prior to recorded history, his song emerging from the mimicry of the songs of 'innumerable birds' that Trevelyan discusses(3; cf. M.53. Anon... fol. 1r), and whom Woolf quotes throughout these drafts.
However, Anon's work is knowable only because Anon has been killed. In some fragments, William Caxton kills Anon through the introduction of the printing press to England in the 1470s (M45. Anon. fol. 6r), in others it is the printed book itself that kills Anon (cf. M.1-8-2. Anon... fol. 1r) while in others he is to be found in the early modern playhouse, and his death comes at the moment that this drama outgrows the stage and is 'replaced by the theatre of the brain' (M.112-2, fol. 2r). Just as Anon's voice is a necessary precondition to literature in English, so too is Anon's death. In a curious aporetic, though, Anon's voice is only audible at the moment of his death.
Anon's death is not the end of anonymous modes of being, however. Some fragments gesture towards the revival of Anon, or at least to the revival of pre-modern modes of perception:
By choosing a vuew carefully to shut out a chimney or a bungalow we can still see what Anon saw-- the bird haunted reed whispering fen; the down covered with turf, and the scar long healed over the moor, over the down, along which Anon came when he made his journeys (M.53. Anon... fol. 2r)
Cf. Phillips, 'Drafting' for a more detailed overview of this narrative.

analytic.title: Drafting ‘Anon’ and Killing Anon: Virginia Woolf and the Genesis of English Literary Language
Drafting ‘Anon’ and Killing Anon

monogr.title: Genetic Narratology: Analysing Narrative across Versions
A Room of One's Own and Three Guineas

person.note:
The Archbishop of Canterbury is the primate of the Church of England and the head of the Anglican church worldwide. Woolf makes several references to different Archbishops of Canterbury throughout the drafts of 'Anon.' Woolf mentions at least two. The earliest she mentions in found in conjuction with Caxton and the English mythscape of Le Mort Darthur: symbols of Arthurian romance and mythical kingship are juxtaposed with the temporal and mundane trappings of power that resides in London and the Archbishop of Canterbury. The Archbishop of Canterbury in situ when Caxton printed Le Mort Darthur was Thomas Bourgchier (c. 1411-1486), who served at the same time as Chancellor of England, and though he sided with Henry VI in the War of the Roses, he found favour with Henry's Lancastrian successor Edward IV (Clark n.p.).
Another Archbishop is to be found in Woolf's discussions of Hugh Latimer's sermons. In his Second Sermon preached before King Edward, Latimer talks of 'troubl[ing] my Lord of Canterbury and being at his house, now and then I walke in the Garden looking in my booke', befire being interrupted by 'one at the gate would speake with you' (Latimer 40). Woolf uses this anecdote in her discussion of Latimer. Though Latimer does not name the Archbishop in question, it is likely to be his friend and co-reformer, Thomas Cranmer. Cranmer served Henry VIII for much of his reign, first providing theological arguments in support of Henry's divorce from Katherine of Aragon. Cranmer was elevated to Archbishop of Canterbury in 1533 and did much to establish the Church of England's independence from Rome. Cranmer was burnt at the stake in 1556 (MacCulloch, n.p.).
Meanwhile, the Archbishop of Canterbury at the time Woolf wrote the 'Anon' drafts was Cosmo Gordon Lang, at whom she had already taken aim in TG. Though only referred to pseudonymously as 'An Archbishop,' Lang is one of the three photographed figures who punctuate Woolf's 1938 essay (247) and the photograph is used metonymically to refer to the Church's historical and contemporary exclusion of women.

analytic.title: Bourchier, Thomas (c. 1411–1486), cardinal and archbishop of Canterbury

monogr.title: A Room of One's Own and Three Guineas

person.note: The legendary once and future king of England. Arthurian literature is vast and diffuse: medieval sources are written in English, Latin, French, German, Norse and Icelandic, Welsh, and Breton, in a plethora of genres (cf. Bruce 507-31), from the ninth century onwards (Bruce 37). Geoffrey of Monmouth's Latin Historia Regum Brittanae (History of the Kings of Britain; 1138) is a major early source for Arthur's 'biography' (38), but Woolf's source for Arthurian legend is Thomas Malory's Le Morte Darthur (1485). In Malory's account of Arthur's life, Arthur is the son of Uther Pendragon and Igraine, though Uther dies and Arthur is raised in secret. Arthur proves that he is the rightful king of England by pulling the sword from the stone (it is unclear as to whether this sword is Excalibur), and his early battles. Arthur then recedes from what is putatively his own narrative: his story gives way to the various adventures and misadventures of his retinue, the knights of the Round Table: these include Lancelot's affair with Guinevere, Arthur's wife, and the quest for the Holy Grail. Eventually, Arthur discovers Lancelot's affair with Guinevere and is convinced by Gawain to battle Lancelot's forces in France. With Arthur's knghts away, his son Mordred seizes the crown and Guinevere: in the ensuing battle, Arthur kills Mordred but is himself mortally wounded and is borne to Avalon, perhaps to be healed and perhaps to die and, in popular mythology, await resurrection (cf. Lacy 295-6 for a fuller summary).

person.note: Anne Bacon was the mother of politician and philosopher Francis Bacon, and a woman of great learning and intellect in her own right: she and her sisters were educated in ancient languages and theology from childhood. She published translations of the sermons of Bernadino Ochino from Italian (1548, 1551), and translated from Latin John Jewel's Apologia Ecclesiae Anglicanae [Apologie of the Churche of Englande (1564)]. She was an avid reformationist Puritan who sheltered preachers at Gorhambury, the Bacon estate in Hertfordshire (Magnusson n.p.). Some 121 of her letters survive, which speak vividly to the intellectual and practical labour Bacon undertook both as a thinker and as the head of a wealthy household. Woolf was most likely to have encountered a selection of her letters in the first volume of Spedding's seven-volume Life and Letters of Francis Bacon (1861-74), which the Woolfs had in their library (LLVW). In a letter to VSW dated 19 February 1929, Woolf recollects an early memory of being lent books to read by LS from the shelves in his study, along with a pleased exclamation of ' "Gracious child, how you gobble!".' She names 'Speddings Bacon' among these volumes (L4 27, §. 2005). She writes of Anne Bacon's letters in one of the reading notebooks she kept in preparation for the 'Anon' drafts, noting the disjunction between 'Colloquial language that comes straight from talk' and Bacon's letters (cf. RN37).

analytic.title: Bacon [née Cooke], Anne, Lady Bacon (c. 1528–1610), gentlewoman and scholar
Bacon [née Cooke], Anne, Lady Bacon (c. 1528–1610), gentlewoman and scholar

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

person.note:
Francis Bacon, Viscount St Alban, was attorney-general and Lord Chancellor during the reign of James VI and, more crucially for this narrative, the son of Anne Bacon and a natural philosopher and essayist. His first publication was the 1597 volume containing ten short essays, bulked out with Religious Meditations and Places of Perswasion and Disswasion, though his career as a natural philosopher began in earnest with the 1605 publication of The Twoo Bookes of Francis Bacon: of the Proficience and Advancement of Learning, Divine and Humane (referred to more briefly as the Advancement of Learning). He would return to the essays in 1610, around the time of his mother's death, by 1625 had published some 58. The 1620 Novum organum (titled after the Organon, Aristotle's works on logic) is an ambitious philosophical work that seeks to establish the primacy of the experimental process in natural philosophy. This was unfinished at the time of its initial publication, though Bacon worked periodically on it after his impeachment and (brief) imprisonment in the Tower of London. The New Atlantis is a posthumously published utopia that describes a scientific community that attempts to put into practice Baconian experimental philosophy (Peltonen n.p.).
LLVW contains four editions of Bacon's works. The earliest is a 1680 edition of his essays, while a 10-volume 1819 edition of his works is somewhat of a family affair. It contains the armorial bookplate of James Stephen Jr (1789-1859), VW's grandfather. It also contains LW's annotations, and five of the volumes were rebound by VW. Meanwhile, in a letter sent to VSW dated 19 February 1929, Woolf recollects an early memory of being lent books to read by her father , along with a pleased exclamation of ' "Gracious child, how you gobble!",' and names 'Speddings Bacon' among these volumes (L4 27, §. 2005). This is a 1861-74 seven-volume Life and Letters edited by James Spedding, and signed, annotated, and doodled in by Leslie Stephen. How many of the seven volumes she gobbled is unrecorded. The most recent edition is a 1924 reprint of the 1597 Religious Meditations, Places of Perswasion & Disswasion, sent as a review copy, although no such review survives. VW made two pages of notes on Bacon's essays as part of the 'Reading at Random' notebook (RN 37).

analytic.title: Bacon, Francis, Viscount St Alban (1561–1626), lord chancellor, politician, and philosopher

monogr.title: The letters and the life of Francis Bacon including all his occasional works, namely letters, speeches, tracts, state papers, memorials, devices and all authentic writings not already printed among his philosophical, literary, or professional works, newly collected and set forth in chronological order with a commentary biographical and historical
The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

person.note: Francis Beaumont was an English playwright, best known for his plays written with John Fletcher, even if only nine plays in the 1647 folio Comedies and Tragedies written by Francis Beaumont and John Fletcher, Gentlemen can be definitively attributed to the pair (cf. Finkelpearl, n.p.). As a figure who almost always worked in collaboration with others, his body of work has waxed and waned over the centuries. Beaumont frequented the Mermaid Tavern, where he reputedly met Ben Jonson (cf. O'Callaghan n.p.). The Woolfs had two editions of works by (or at least attributed to) Beaumont and Fletcher in their library: an 1840 edition which had belonged to Leslie Stephen, with his annotations and drawings, and a two-volume set published as part of the Mermaid series 'The Best Plays of the Old Dramatists' and edited by John St. Loe Strachey, cousin to Lytton Strachey. VW took notes on The Maid's Tragedy (1619, Beaumont and Fletcher) and The Two Noble Kinsmen (1613-4?), which was attributed previously to Beaumont and Fletcher but is now attributed to William Shakespeare and Fletcher (Cf. Silver, XIX).

Ludwig van Beethoven was an Austrian composer of chamber, symphonic, and choral music, as well as one opera, the 1805 Fidelio, which Woolf mentions in these drafts. VW's writing displays an evident familiarity with his work, and she discusses listening to his music in diary entries and letters throughout her life. In VO, Rachel Vinrace thinks of 'the spirit of Beethoven Op. 112' as she falls asleep (35; however cf. Hussey 14 for debate as to the precise Opus number). In JR, Jacob asks Bonamy ' "What about Beethoven?"' (116). In W, Bernard purchases a 'picture of Beethoven in a silver frame' (152). In a famous passage of her unfinished memoir 'Sketch' 'Hamlet or a Beethoven quartet' as 'the truth about the vast mass that we call the world': part of this truth is that there is 'no Shakespeare; there is no Beethoven; certainly and emphatically there is no God; we are the words; we are the music; we are the thing itself' (MoB 81).

monogr.title: Virginia Woolf A to Z: a comprehensive reference for students, teachers and common readers to her life, work and critical reception
Virginia Woolf A to Z

series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

person.note: An English wool-merchant or 'merchant of the staple' whose life Eileen Power narrates in her collection of micro-histories Medieval People (1924; LLVW contains 1937 reprint). Power describes him as 'one of the most delightful people revealed to us in any of the fifteenth-century letters' (117).

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

person.note: Thomas Bilney, known by the diminuitive nickname Little Bilney, was a priest, evangelical reformist preacher and, ultimately, martyr who was educated in Cambridge and preached across Norfolk and East Anglia. Having read Erasmus's Latin translation of the New Testament in 1516, Bilney became an enthusiastic reformer in Cambridge, and converted a number of his fellow scholars including Hugh Latimer. By 1525, Bilney was touring East Anglia, preaching against pilgrimages and veneration of saints' remains and icons. In November 1527, he was put on trial for heresy for the first time and escaped death by renouncing his previous teachings, and was instead imprisoned for two years. In 1531, he began to preach again in the open, and was swiftly put on trial and burnt at the stake as a relapsed heretic (cf. Carter n.p.).

analytic.title: Bilney, Thomas (c. 1495–1531), evangelical reformer and martyr

person.note: A.C. Bradley was an English literary critic. In 1904 as Professor of Poetry at the University of Oxford, Bradley wrote and published his best-known work, Shakespearean Tragedy: Woolf read and made notes on this work in 1909 concurrently with Hamlet, King Lear, Macbeth and Othello (cf. RN24).

A physician and essayist from Norwich whom Woolf continually figures as a ghostly companion and interlocutor, and whom, Hagen notes, she 'regularly associates [...] with the challenges and the pleasures of reading' (177). Though she first writes about him in the unpublished 1919 essay 'Reading,' Beth Rigel Daugherty provides evidence that she lectured on his writing at Morley College on 18 January 1905 (158). The text of the lecture has not survived but cf. PA 223-4 for Virginia Stephen's description of this lecture's writing process. 'Reading' figures Browne as populating an 'immeasurable avenue' populated by figures from the literary past (E3 142), and as 'the first to talk of himself [...] broach[ing] the subject with an immense gusto. He returns to it again and again, as if the soul were a wondrous disease and its symptoms not yet recorded' (155). Woolf's 1923 essay 'Sir Thomas Browne' is ostensibly a review of a 'beautiful Golden Cockerel edition' of Browne's works (368). It spends little time discussing the edition itself, but rather dwells on the rhetorical character and variousness of his prose, imagining the 'halo of wonder round everything that he sees' (371). The CR1 essays 'The Elizabethan Lumber Room' and 'Notes on an Elizabethan Play' (E4 53-62; 62-71) both turn to Browne in their concluding paragraphs. In the first instance, Browne is one whose 'immense egotism has paved the way for all psychological novelists, autobiographers, confession-mongers, and dealers in the curious shades of our private life' (58), while in the second he is among the writers to whom the mind 'as if tired with company [...]' turns toward or 'steals off to muse in solitude; to think, not to act; to comment, not to share; to explore its own darkness, not the bright lit-up surfaces of others. It turns to Donne, to Montaigne, to Sir Thomas Browne, to the keepers of the keys of solitude' (69). In ND, Ralph Denham examines a 'small and very lovely edition' of Browne that belongs to William Rodney, and which Rodney gifts Denham (73). The preface to O names Browne second among the list of 'friends [the narrator] have helped me in writing this book' (5), while his writing 'took [Orlando's] fancy amazingly' (67, cf. Hagen). Woolf took notes on Browne's essays and letters at different points in her life: these notes can be found in RN 17, 25, 38, and 49. LLVW contains seven editions that collect Thomas Browne's writing, including a 1658 fourth edition of Pseudodoxia Epidemica rebound by VW.

analytic.title: Sir Thomas Browne and the Reading of Remains in <hi rend="italics">Orlando</hi>

person.note: Victorian poet and playwright who, through his marriage to Elizabeth Barrett Browning, came to play an important role in F. In VO, Lucy Allan is engaged in writing a primer on English literary history 'from Beowulf to Browning' (113), and in O, Nick Greene cites him as example that ' "the great days are over. We live in degenerate times"' (254-5). LLVW contains ten editions of Browning's poetry and letters.

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

person.note: Robert Burton was the author of The Anatomy of Melancholy, first published in 1621 and significantly expanded by Burton in the years following this: it grew 'by more than two thirds of its original size' over the thirty years from its initial publication to the publication of the final edition to bear Burton's additions in 1651 (Gowland in Burton xviii). Burton was a life-long student of Christ Church College, Oxford, where he studied theology and practiced an eclectic autodidacticism. Though he held positions other than that of the 'tumbler over of other mens books' (M112, Set 3 of 3 [The Reader: so long as the play was dominant.] fol. 1r) the Anatomy was his life's work, and little else by him survives beyond a Latin university comedy titled Philophaster (1606-15).

Cato most likely refers to one of two Roman senators, Cato the Elder (Marcus Porcius Cato; 234-149 BCE) or Cato the Younger (Marcus Porcius Cato Uticensis; 95-46 BCE). Both were conservative politicians and noted orators: Cato the Elder wrote De agri cultura, the oldest extant work of Latin prose, while Cato the Younger campaigned against Julius Caesar in the civil war that birthed the Roman Empire. Woolf references Joseph Addison's Cato, a Tragedy (1712) in her CR1 essay titled 'Addison' and O. Addison's play dramatises the final days of Caesar's civil war and of Cato the Younger's life. The Woolfs had multiple four copies of this play in their library: one in a standalone edition from 1750, the others in collected editions.

series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

person.note: English diplomat and trader who introduced the printing press to England, most likely in 1476 (cf. Blake). As a diplomat and trader, he had lived across Europe, and acquired a press in Cologne in 1471-2, where in addition to learning to print, he became a 'publisher who controlled the presses which produced his books' (Blake). The first work he published in English was the first edition of Chaucer's Canterbury Tales, and he both significantly revised and printed Thomas Malory's Morte Darthur. Within the context of Woolf's literary history, he introduces to Britain the technology that is to kill Anon by settling his words in print, though also preserving Anon's songs beyond the moment of their enunciation.

analytic.title: Caxton, William (1415x24–1492), printer, merchant, and diplomat

monogr.title: Le morte Darthur: Sir Thomas Malory's book of King Arthur and of his noble knights of the round table.: The text of Caxton

person.note: Middle English poet. VW's most sustained engagement with his work is in the CR1 essay 'The Pastons and Chaucer' (1925; E4 20-38), which reads Chaucer's literary texts alongside the more prosaic Paston Letters. VW read and took notes on The Canterbury Tales and the long narrative poem Troilus and Criseyde in 1924, in preparation for writing this essay (cf. RN 47, 49). She returned to Chaucer later in life, reading his work as she begins to write her literary history. In a diary entry of 30 October 1938 she writes of reading Chaucer 'concurremtly with French prose. But I'm word haunted' (D5 183). In a letter dated 2 February 1939 to May Sarton, she writes of giving herself 'a license to read no modern writing for one full year' after having sold her stake in the Hogarth Press to John Lehmann, and that she has been 'so steeped in modern manuscripts that I was losing all sense that one differed from the other.' She tells Sarton that she is 'reading Chaucer' as a respite 'and hope in a year to have recovered my palate' (L6 314, §. 3485). LLVW contains three editions of Chaucer's works, including Skeat's six-volume edition. Cf. Ellis, Mitchell for differing accounts of Woolf's engagement with Chaucer and the Chaucerian more broadly.

analytic.title: Framing the Father: Chaucer and Virginia Woolf
Framing the Father
"The details of life and the pulsings of affect": Virginia Woolf's Middle English Texts

person.note: Roman statesman, philosopher and writer whose oratory and rhetoric had a vast impact on the development of Latin prose and on the development of Renaissance humanism. Cicero was branded an enemy of the state for his opposition to Mark Anthony in the tumult that followed Caesar's death, and was killed trying to flee Italy in 43 BCE. The Woolfs had five editions of works by Cicero in their library, two English translations of his letters and three Latin editions with LW's inscription and annotations (LLVW). In her diary entry dated 27 February 1935, VW notes her desire to 'stop reading F[aery] Q[ueen]: to read Cicero's letters, & the Chateaubriand memoirs' (D4 283).

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

person.note: Character from Woolf's short story 'The Legacy' (1940), drafted in 1940 for Harper's Bazaar but published posthumously in HH. Angela Clandon is the recently deceased wife of Gilbert, a minor (though wealthy) politician. She is evidently introduced to radical politics by the also-deceased 'B.M.,' the brother of her secretary Sissy Miller. Readers only learn of this, however, as her husband reads through her diary and becomes convinced that she had an affair with 'B.M.' and took her own life in order to join him in death.

monogr.title: The Complete Shorter Fiction of Virginia Woolf

person.note: Character from Woolf's short story 'The Legacy' (1940), drafted in 1940 for Harper's Bazaar but published posthumously in HH. Gilbert Clandon is a minor politician sorting through the effects of his recently deceased wife Angela. He begins to read her diary and becomes convinced that she was having an affair with a man referred to as 'B.M.,' who introduced her to radical politics, and that she took her life in order to join 'B.M.' in death. Clandon's 'legacy,' it seems is 'the truth': that Angela had 'stepped off the kerb to rejoin her lover' and to 'escape from him' (CSF 287)

monogr.title: The Complete Shorter Fiction of Virginia Woolf

person.note: Lady Anne Clifford, countess of Pembroke, Dorset, and Montgomery was a woman of letters and a noblewoman associated with the court of James I. Her surviving diaries, kept between January 1616 and December 1617, speak to her love of literature and vigorous autodidacticism: she writes of reading (or listening to) the Bible, contemporary literature including the Essays of Michel de Montaigne and Edmund Spenser's long poem The Faerie Queene, Turkish history, and the sermons of John Donne, whom she met at least once, on the 20th July 1617 (Clifford 74). For his part, Donne said of Clifford that 'she knew well how to discourse of all things, from predestination to slea-silk' (Spence n.p.). The extant portions of Clifford's diaries were written in the shadow of legal disputes sparked by her father George Clifford, third earl of Cumberland's unlawful decision to settle his estate not upon Clifford but upon his brother, Francis Clifford and Clifford's decision to challenge the will. This was a challenge that ended only with Francis Clifford's death without male heirs, upon which the lot reverted to Anne Clifford (cf. Sackville-West in Clifford, xxviii-xxx). Anne Clifford spent much of the period that the diaries cover at Knole, the house in which Vita Sackville-West was born and Orlando's great house in O. Lounsberry writes on Woolf's 1931 reading of Clifford's diaries (2.107-14), describing its publication, its narrative, and Woolf's impressions of the diary. The Woolfs had a copy of Sackville-West's 1924 edition of Clifford's diaries in their library: Woolf made three sets of notes on it, in preparation for CR1 and again in preparing to write the 'Anon' drafts (cf. RN 9, 37, see also RN2. [Holograph reading notes] Notes for reading at random., fol. 8r). At some point, LW annotated this volume. VW writes to VSW twice about Anne Clifford, first on Boxing Day 1940 (L6 454-5, no. 3672) and the second time on 4 February 1941 (L6 469-70, no. 3689), both times asking for biographies and material on her life: as VW notes in the latter of the two letters, their Mecklenburgh Square residence had been bombed and 'all my books are to bits.'

monogr.title: The Diary of the Lady Anne Clifford: With an Introductory Note by V. Sackville-West

analytic.title: Clifford, Anne [known as Lady Anne Clifford], countess of Pembroke, Dorset, and Montgomery (1590–1676), noblewoman and diarist

person.note: William Brooke, tenth Baron Cobham, was a well-connected diplomat who acted as patron for William Harrison, who dedicated his Description of England to Brooke (cf. Harrison I.cix).

monogr.title: Harrison's Description of England in Shakespere's youth: Being the second and third books of his Description of Britaine and England

series.title: Publisht for the New Shakspere Society

person.note: Samuel Taylor Coleridge was a romantic poet and essayist. Relevant here are Coleridge's lectures on William Shakespeare: from 1808 to 1891, he delivered some eight courses of lectures either dedicated to Shakespeare or discussing him in conjunction with other authors. Much of this criticism is no longer extant, though among the 20 volumes of Coleridge's various writings in LLVW is an 1885 volume titled Lectures and Notes on Shakspere [sic] and Other English Poets. This collects Coleridge's notes for his 1818 lectures on Shakespeare, as well as on the plays of Ben Jonson, and Beaumont and Fletcher. It also reproduces transcriptions of his 1811-12 Lectures on Shakespeare and Milton. The volume contains LS's annotations and drawing. Though no reading notes on this volume are extant, Woolf draws on Coleridge's description of the androgynous mind for her expansion of the topic in Room (88-9 et passim). VW published two essays on Coleridge, at either end of her career as a writer. Her 1918 Times Literary Supplement review 'Coleridge as Critic' (E2 221-225) specifically remarks on Coleridge's writings on Shakespeare: 'His notes upon Shakespeare are, to our thinking, the only criticisms which bear reading with the sound of the play still in one's ears. They possess one of the marks which we are apt to discover in the finest art, the power of seeming to bring to light what was already there beforehand, instead of imposing anything from the outside' (222). In On Being Ill (1930), Coleridge's readings of Shakespeare are drowned out: 'Illness, in its kingly sublimity, sweeps all that aside and leaves nothing but Shakespeare and oneself [...] even Coleridge himself squeaks like a distant mouse' (E5 202). In October 1940, the New Statesman & Nation published VW's review 'The Man at the Gate' (E6 235-41) and the next week published 'Sara Coleridge,' VW's review of a biography of Coleridge's daughter, (E6 249-255). Woolf read widely in Coleridge in preparation for her 1940 essays, writing to T.S. Eliot on 15 May 1940 that she was 'reading Coleridge through' (L6 398, no. 3608). She may have read an 1804 letter in which Coleridge writes of his plans to read Shakespeare and treat 'Each scene of each play I read, as if it were the whole of Shakespere's [sic] Works — the sole thing extant,' and read 'Ben Johnson [sic], Beaumont & Fletcher, & Massinger' in the same manner (Coleridge in Mahoney 501). This is a mode of reading that bears remarkable similarities to the one described in M111, set 3 of 3 [The Reader: Anonymity was a great possession], fol. 5 recto, which asks for readers to 'cease to consider the plays separately' and 'scramble them together as one common attempt,' 'as sketches for one masterpiece.'

A Room of One's Own and Three Guineas

person.note: Along with Nin and Pulley, one of a trio of 'invisible influences' that interpellate the early English singer as a subject and shape their song. Woolf begins to discuss these influences as early as RN2. [Holograph reading notes] Notes for reading at random. The names of all three of the trio are defined by Joseph Wright in his English Dialect Dictionary, with which Woolf was evidently familiar (cf. Leaska in Woolf 1978, xii). Wright defines a 'crot' as a 'very small part' (Crot), but OED cites an older usage in the c.1400 poem Cursor Mundi, where it is used to denote a 'particle, bit, atom [or] individual piece' (crot | crote (n), cf. also Phillips 215).

analytic.title: How Should One Read “The Reader”? New Approaches to Virginia Woolf’s Late Archive

Pargiters

person.note: Thomas Dekker was a English poet, pamphleteer, and playwright. Little is known of his life. The most reliable source for his early years as a playwright is the diary of Philip Henslowe, which details Dekker's dealings with Henslowe's theatre company. By 1600 he was a combatant in the 'War of the Theatres,' writing Satiro-mastix as a response to Ben Jonson's parody of him in Poetaster. In spite of growing success as a pamphleteer, he spent 1613–20 in debtors' prison, and sought to reestablish himself as a playwright following his release (cf. Twyning n.p.). The Woolfs had two editions of Dekker in their library, one part of the Mermaid series 'The Best Plays of the Old Dramatists' and the other a 1924 Bodley Head reprint of his 1603 pamphlet The VVonderful Yeare, a prose account of the death of Elizabeth I and of the plague epidemic of that year. VW took notes on two of his plays, Old Fortunatus and The Witch of Edmonton in preparation for CR1, noting of the latter that it was 'odd, because its apparently about real people, of the lower classes, & at the present time–—all unlikely in Ethan drama.' She later made notes on The VVonderful Yeare in preparation for CR2 (cf. RN9, 32).

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

person.note:
William Feilding was a courtier for James I and Charles I and naval officer who took part in the unsuccessful 'Spanish Match,' an attempt by James I to ally Protestant England and Catholic Spain through marriage (joined by Francis Manners). This attempt at marital diplomacy was allegorised by Thomas Middleton in A Game at Chess. Feilding later travelled extensively throughout India (Thrush n.p.).
It is unclear why Woolf mentions Feilding, the Earl of Denbigh in this distinctly witchy context (cf. M1-8, 1 of 10. [The great Elizabethan house, Penshurst...], fol. 4r). However, in 1594, a Gwen verch Ellis was put on trial, and possibly executed, for witchcraft in Denbigh, Wales (Parkin).

analytic.title: Witchcraft, women's honour and customary law in early modern Wales
Feilding, William, first earl of Denbigh (c. 1587–1643), naval officer and courtier

person.note: Edward of Lancaster ascended to the throne of England and Ireland in 1461 during the decades-long period of civil war known as the War of the Roses: William Shakespeare depicts Edward's defeat of his predecessor Henry VI and the turbulent early years of his reign in Henry VI, Part III. Though Edward attempted to secure his position by means both military and marital, this did not prevent him from being being forced to flee the country by the Earl of Warwick, who then freed the captive Henry VI and restored him to the throne in 1470 (cf. 3H6 4.iii). Edward returned to England, and to power, in 1471 and thereafter ruled until his death in 1483 (cf. Horrox n.p.).

analytic.title: Edward IV (1442–1483), king of England and lord of Ireland

series.title: The Arden Shakespeare. Third series

person.note:
Edward Tudor was the son of Jane Seymour and, as his only male heir, the short-lived successor to Henry VIII as king of England and Ireland. Though his reign was curtailed by what was most likely a combination of tuberculosis and measles or smallpox, he was nonetheless influential. He was crowned with great pomp on 19 February 1547: the Archbishop of Canterbury, Thomas Cramner, proclaimed him 'God's Viceregent, and Christ's Vicar,' and in this capacity oversaw much of the reformatory work Cramner had begun under the previous monarch – perhaps most significantly for the development of English as a literary language, this work included the 1549 introduction of the vernacular Book of Common Prayer (Hoak n.p.).
In M1-8, 2 of 10. Anon. Holograph, fol. 7, Woolf writes notes that in translating The Lord's Prayer into English and reciting it at the end of his sermons, Hugh Latimer 'put English into the highest places' and 'fashion[ed] a common tongue,' while in M52. Anon. Typescript fragment..., fol. 18r, she adds further nuance, writing that he paradoxically gave minstrels a new 'lease of life' insofar as he 'was rescuing [English] from the back door' at which Anon had sung. It is not a stretch to see Cramner's vernacular prayerbook as part of this same recovery.

analytic.title: Edward VI (1537–1553), king of England and Ireland

person.note: Elizabeth Tudor was queen of England and Ireland from 1558 to 1603, and the last Tudor monarch. The only child of Henry VIII and his second wife, Anne Boleyn, her reign was marked by religious persecution, imperial expansion, and literary flourishing. In BA's pageant, one Eliza Clark, 'licensed to sell tobacco' plays Elizabeth. Her monologue takes in the 'seafaring men' who brought imperial plunder, '[c]argoes of diamonds, ducats of gold' to the metropole and William Shakespeare: 'For me Shakespeare sang' (61-2). After an appearance by Albert, the scene shifts, 'perhaps [to] the Globe theatre' and Elizabeth quotes Falstaff in commanding the pageant's other actors to '"Play out the play"' (64, cf. 1H4 II.iv.402). Woolf makes passing references throughout to Lytton Strachey's 1928 biography Elizabeth and Essex.

series.title: The Arden Shakespeare. Third series

monogr.title: Elizabeth and Essex: A Tragic History

series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

person.note: Very little has been written about the life of Mariana Irwin, beyond Anne Clifford's description of her marriage to Edmund Sheffield as 'a mean match, an undiscreet on part of him' (89-90). The two married on 4 March 1619: he was 64; she 16 (Stater n.p.).

analytic.title: Sheffield, Edmund, first earl of Mulgrave (1565–1646), politician

person.note: John Falstaff (referred to as Oldcastle in some editions) is a character in William Shakespeare's history plays 1 Henry IV and 2 Henry IV and his comedy The Merry Wives of Windsor. He is killed offstage after 2 Henry IV: he is eulogised by his former companions in Henry V (2.3 ll. 5-40). Thoby Stephen was evidently impressed by this: in 'Sketch' VW recounts how the '[t]hat large natural inhumanity' in Shakespeare, exemplified by 'shuffling off Falstaff [...] without a sign of sympathy [...] delighted' her brother (MoB 152). This example of Shakespearean inhumanity is recapitulated in 'Reading' (1919), where the narrator notes that 'Shakespeare dismissed Falstaff callously enough' to evidence a 'cruelty' common to 'the great writers' (E3 158). In 'Mr Conrad: A Conversation' (1923) one of the interlocutors cites Falstaff as the originator of a 'broad and free [...] common English humour' in which Conrad, a foreigner, cannot share (E3 379). Elsewhere, Falstaff is a potent exemplum of the force of creativity. The narrator of 'How Should One Read a Book' discusses 'the varied art of the poet; his power to make us at once actors and spectators; his power to run his hand into character as if it were a glove, and be Falstaff and Lear' (E6 579) while the variant text of 'The Antiquary' published posthumously in The Moment and Other Essays (1947) says that Scott's characters bear the 'seed of life' like Shakespeare's but do not '[live] as profoundly, as fully, as Falstaff lives or Hamlet' (E6 435). In 'The Art of Biography' (1939), VW writes that '[e]ven Dr Johnson created by Boswell will not live as long as Falstaff as created by Shakespeare' (E6 187).

series.title: The Arden Shakespeare. Third series
The Arden Shakespeare. Third series

person.note: John Ford was an English playwright best known today for 'Tis Pity She's a Whore (printed 1633), a tragedy whose action is spurred by the incestuous romance of siblings Giovanni and Anabella. Ford's practice as a dramatist was highly collaborative, and his dramas were richly intertextual: early in his career, Ford co-wrote plays with Thomas Dekker and Thomas Middleton, while his 1628 play The Lover's Melancholy was printed with marginalia acknowledging Robert Burton's Anatomy of Melancholy as a source (Neill n.p.). Meanwhile, 'Tis Pity has often been read as a reworking of Romeo and Juliet. The Woolfs owned an 1888 edition of his plays, edited by Havelock Ellis and published as part of the Mermaid series 'The Best Plays of the Old Dramatists' (cf. LLVW). Woolf took notes on 'Tis Pity, as well as The Lover's Melancholy and The Broken Heart (published 1633) in preparation for CR1 (cf. RN9).

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

person.note: Master John Frankford (persistently referred to by Woolf as Frankland) is a major character in Thomas Heywood's domestic tragedy A Woman Killed With Kindness. The play opens with his marriage to Anne Frankford, the sister of Sir Francis Acton, and his decision to invite Wendoll to stay in his household as a long-term, perhaps permanent, guest. Anne Frankford and Wendoll begin an affair, which Frankland later discovers, walking in on Anne and Wendoll in bed. He is restrained from killing Wendoll and exiles Anne, saying that he intends to 'not martyr thee | Nor mark thee for a strumpet, but with usage | Of more humility torment thy soul | And kill thee, even with kindness' (13.150-1). Seeking to repent, Anne starves herself. Hearing of her parlous health, Frankford rushes to Anne's sickbed and the two reconcile, but this is not enough to prevent her death.

series.title: Arden early modern drama

person.note: Anne Frankford (consistently referred to by Woolf as Frankland) is a major character in one of the two subplots of Thomas Heywood's domestic tragedy A Woman Killed With Kindness. She is the sister of Sir Francis Acton. The play opens with her marriage to Master John Frankland. John Frankland invites Wendoll to live in the newlyweds' home as a permanent guest, and Anne and Wendoll begin an affair. Frankford discovers the pair, and is restrained from killing Wendoll. In an act of retribution intended to 'torment [her] soul' and 'kill [her], even with kindness' (13.150-1), John exiles Anne and all of her possessions to a manor some seven miles from their home, and directs her to live out the rest of her days there. Her days are cut short as Anne starves herself, seeking to repent. Frankford is summoned to Anne's side, which gives the pair the chance to reconcile, but this is not enough to prevent Anne's death.

series.title: Arden early modern drama

person.note: Little is known about Ingram Frizer's life, save that he killed Christopher Marlowe in what is popularly believed to have been a tavern brawl on 30 May 1593 in Deptford, London, although more recently this popular conception has been called into question (cf. Nicholl, n.p.). Though it may have taken place in private rather than a tavern, the specific details of Frizer's fight with Marlowe are less doubtful. In M108 [The Reader: There is a jolt at the points.], fol. 5v, Woolf paraphrases G.B. Harrison's account of Marlowe's death, itself a paraphrase of contemporary court records: 'malicious words passed between Marlowe and Frizer about the payment of the reckoning, until Marlowe [...] sprang on Frizer [...] and taking Frizer's dagger from his back wounded him twice in the head. Frizer being then put in fear of his life strove to get his dagger back, and in the struggle gave Marlowe a mortal wound over the right eye of which he instantly died' (G.B. Harrison, 258). Woolf read and took notes on G.B. Harrison's An Elizabethan Journal (1928) in 1940, in preparation for the 'Anon' drafts (cf. RN37), and had a copy of his 1923 Shakespeare's Fellows: Being a Brief Chronicle of the Shakespearean Age in her library (cf. LLVW).

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog
An Elizabethan journal: Being a record of those things most talked about during the years 1591-1594
An Elizabethan journal;

analytic.title: Marlowe [Marley], Christopher (bap. 1564, d. 1593), playwright and poet

person.note: Mary Fytton was the daughter of Edward Fytton and, at some point between mid-1596 and early 1598, served as maid of honour at Elizabeth I's court (Larminie n.p.). Prior to her arrival at court, Sir William Knollys wrote to her father that he would play the role of 'the Good Shepperd & will to my power deffend the innocent lamb from the wolvyshe crueltye & fox-like subtletye of the tame bests of this place' (Knollys in Newdigate-Newdegate 9) but he was not as good as his word and fell in love (unrequited) with Fytton, evidenced by a series of letters (unanswered). Fytton left the court shortly thereafter (Larminie n.p.), and the letters that Woolf quotes imply that she left in disgrace. VW read this narrative in Newdigate-Newdegate, which she took notes on in preparation for the 'Anon' drafts (RN37). Mary Fytton's relationship with Knollys is one part of Newdigate-Newdegate's narrative but VW's notes focus on this strand. In his 1899 Dictionary of National Biography entry on Fytton, Sidney Lee notes that she was 'fantastically alleged' as the Dark Lady of Shakespeare's sonnets, but that this is a 'fanciful theory, which does not admit of serious consideration' (Lee).

analytic.title: Fitton [married names Polewhele, Lougher], Mary (bap. 1578, d. 1641), courtier and gentlewoman

monogr.title: Gossip from a muniment room; being passages in the lives of Anne and Mary Fitton, 1574 to 1618.

person.note: The father of Mary Fytton, Edward Fytton was from Gawsworth in Cheshire. He was a prominent landowner and owned plantations in Ireland, though found this to be 'financially unrewarding' (Cunningham).

Sir Gawain was part of Arthur's retinue, the knights of the Round Table in Arthurian legend. Despite (or perhaps because of) his manifold appearances across the Arthurian canon, his character is far from consistent: in the anonymous middle English poem Sir Gawain and the Green Knight (late c. 14th) he is a figure of chivalric virtue; in Woolf's source for Arthurian mythology here, Thomas Malory's Morte Darthur (1485), he is a 'brash bully' who 'contributes to Britain's downfall by egging Arthur into a war with Lancelot' (Bruce 211). In the Morte, he is killed in battle at Dover. Caxton writes in his Preface to Malory's work that Gawain's skull could still be seen at Dover Castle (Caxton in Malory 2).

series.title: Garland reference library of the humanities

monogr.title: Le morte Darthur: Sir Thomas Malory's book of King Arthur and of his noble knights of the round table.: The text of Caxton

person.note: John Gower was a trilingual poet who wrote Latin, French, and English poems of extraordinary length: the Latin Vox Clamantis [The Crying Voice] is over 10,000 lines long, while the Anglo-Norman Mirour de l'Omme [The Mirror of Man] and the Middle English Confessio Amantis [The Lover's Confession] are both roughly 30,000 lines in length. Little documentary evidence survives to speak to his life, though he was evidently friends with Geoffrey Chaucer. In one manuscript tradition of Confessio Amantis, Gower dedicates the poem to Chaucer, as the speaker asks Venus to 'gret wel Chaucer whan ye mete | As mi disciple and mi poete' (Gower 1.8, note to ll. 2941), while the penultimate stanza of Chaucer's Troilus and Criseyde apostrophises Gower and dedicates the poem to him: 'O moral Gower, this book I directe | To the [...] | To vouchen sauf, there nede is, to correct | Of youre benignites and zeles goode' (Chaucer V.1856-8). There is no extant evidence to suggest that Woolf read Gower.

imprint.publisher: Published for TEAMS (The Consortium for the Teaching of the Middle Ages) in association with the University of Rochester by Medieval Institute Publications

series.title: Middle English texts series

person.note: Walter Wilson Greg was an editor of Shakespeare (among others) and scholar of the renaissance stage whose work remains foundational to critical bibliography and therefore to modern Anglo-American textual scholarship. Woolf read Greg's landmark 1904-08 two-volume edition of Philip Henslowe's diaries in preparation for work on the 'Anon' drafts, and cites it multiple times herein, though nothing written or edited by Greg appears in the Woolfs' library.

Elizabeth Grey, Countess of Kent, was the granddaughter of Bess of Hardwick, and a literary figure in her own right. She was probably educated by translator John Florio (Considine n.p.), who dedicated his translation of the Essais of Michel de Montaigne to her.

analytic.title: Grey, Elizabeth [née Lady Elizabeth Talbot], countess of Kent (1582–1651), literary patron and supposed author

person.note: William Harrison, was a cleric and historian. He was household chaplain to William Brooke, tenth Baron Cobham, who would later institute him as rector of the parish of Radwinter in Essex. In the 1560s and '70s, he embarked on a historiographical project that was ambitious, to say the least, working on a manuscript titled Chronological computations from the beginning of the world to his own times, which he later expanded into The great English chronology (Parry n.p.). In 1576, Raphael Holinshed commissioned Harrison to write A Description of England, which formed part of Holinshed's Chronicles. Harrison dedicated his Description to Baron Cobham.

monogr.title: Harrison's Description of England in Shakespere's youth: Being the second and third books of his Description of Britaine and England

series.title: Publisht for the New Shakspere Society

person.note: Henry Tudor was king of England and Ireland from 1509 until his death in 1547. As ruler, he broke from Rome and the authority of the Pope in order to divorce his first wife, Catherine of Aragon, greatly expanding his own power in the process. In so doing, he established the Church of England with himself as the divinely annointed Supreme Head. William Shakespeare and John Fletcher collaboratively wrote King Henry VIII, which was first performed under the title All is True in 1613 at the Globe theatre. At this performance, a cannon was discharged onstage: it misfired, setting the thatch roof of the playhoouse alight and burning down the structure.

Philip Henslowe was a theatre financier and patron, whose diary provides an invaluable window into the business of the Jacobean stage. Henslowe financed and took an active interest in the construction of the Rose playhouse in Southwark, and its resident theatre company, Lord Strange's Men, later the Lord Admiral's Men. In 1600, he began work on another playhouse, the Fortune, as a joint venture with the actor Edward Alleyn. Henslowe was a success at the court of King James, being appointed as gentleman sewer of the chamber in 1603 and jointly purchasing the mastership of the royal game with Alleyn, which would enable them to license bear baiting, in 1604 – they held baiting at the Rose fortnightly (cf. Cerasano n.p.) Henslowe's diary is somewhat of a composite volume: it contains accounts kept by a John Henslowe regarding the 'felling and disposal of timber and other matters in Ashdown forest' from 1576-1581, and thereafter contains a mixture of what Greg describes as 'accounts and memoranda relating both to private affairs, dramatic and other' from 1592 to 1609. It contains accounts of family business, matters relating to the Rose and the performances therein, details of monies lent and received, astrological formulae, medical recipes and charms, and details of a joint starch-making venture he undertook with Alleyn. The small folio volume lay undiscovered in the archives of Dulwich College, a boys' school in London, until 1780 where they remain today (Greg in Henslowe i.xii-xxiii). Woolf read the two-volume edition of Henslowe's diary edited by W. W. Greg in preparation for her work on the 'Anon' drafts, gleaning much of her information on the material conditions of the early stage from Greg's exhaustive commentary on the diary (Cf. RN14, 37).

Mary Herbert (née Sidney), was a poet, translator, and literary patron. She was the sister of Philip Sidney and their brother Robert. She received a humanist education at home before joining the court of Elizabeth I, marrying Henry Herbert, second earl of Pembroke in 1577. She and her husband lived at Wilton House. Philip Sidney dedicated The Countess of Pembroke's Arcadia (1593). After Philip's death in 1586 she continued to act as patron for many poets who had benefited from her brother's largesse, and she was a skilled poet and translator in her own right, creating a virtuosic translation of the Book of Psalms.

monogr.title: The Countess of Pembroke's Arcadia
monogr.edition: The tenth edition with his life and death, a brief table of the principal heads, and som sic other new additions.

imprint.publisher: Printed by William Du-Gard, and are to be sold by George Calvert, at the half Moon in the new buildings in Paul's Church-yard, and Thomas Pierrepoint at the Sun in Paul's Church-yard, MDCLV

person.note: Thomas Heywood was an English playwright, writer, and actor best known today as the author of A Woman Killed with Kindness. Though a fraction of his work survives, Heywood was, by his own accounts, an extraordinarily prolific figure on the Elizabethan and Jacobean stage. In his epistle dedicatory to the reader in The English Traveller he claims that this is one 'amongst two hundred and twenty, in which I have had either an entire hand, or at the least a maine finger' but that these plays were – fittingly, for the subject matter of Woolf's history – ephemeral, that his 'Playes are not exposed unto the world in Volumes, to beare the title of Workes (as others)' and that 'it was never any great ambition in me, to bee in this kind Voluminously read' (cf. fol. A3).

monogr.title: The English traueller: As it hath beene publikely acted at the Cock-pit in Drury-lane: by Her Maiesties seruants. Written by Thomas Heyvvood.

person.note: Thomas Hobbes was a philosopher whose work both speaks to the political turmoil of sixteenth and seventeenth century Britain and is of enormous importance to later political theory. LLVW contains two copies of his 1651 Leviathan (one of which bears LW's annotations) and one copy of his Behemoth, or The Long Parliament (1668; pub'd posthumously in 1681) in their library.

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

person.note: Raphael Holinshed was a historian who was employed in Reyner Wolfe's printing house to assist Wolfe's ambitious project to create a ' "universal cosmographie"' (Clegg n.p.). Holinshed did not quite manage to create a universal history, but he nonetheless was able to publish the first edition of the Chronicles of England, Scotland, and Ireland in 1577 in two lavishly-produced volumes. The Chronicles was expanded significantly seven years after Holinshed's 1580 death (Clegg). William Harrison's Description of England is collected in both editions. Though the history Holinshed's volumes told was not the most accurate, it was vastly influential nonetheless, providing a source text for many of Shakespeare's history plays, King Lear, Macbeth, and Cymbeline.

Robin Hood is a legendary outlaw hero. Tales of his deeds date from as early as 1450 (Holt n.p.) and, popularly, he lived in Sherwood Forest, Nottinghamshire, with his band of Merry Men and stole from the rich in order to give to the poor. In the sixth of his sermons preached before Edward VI, Latimer talks distressedly about being upstaged by Robin Hood (whether the real deal or not). He fulminates that 'This Realme hath beene ill provided for, that it hath such corrupt judgements in it, to preferre Robin Hood to Gods word', and tells his audience that 'If the Bishops had bin Preachers, there should never have beene any such thing' (Latimer 73-4). VW's handmade index to Edward Arber's English Garner anthology has an entry titled 'Hood, Robin, song of' (RN Arber fol. 9r). In M52. Anon, fol. 19 recto, VW refers to mummers acting Robin Hood: this is perhaps a reference to the anonymous early print 'mery geste of Robyn Hoode and of hys lyfe,' a compilation of ballads about Robin Hood and his companions (Mery Geste).

analytic.title: Hood, Robin (supp. fl. late 12th–13th cent.), legendary outlaw hero

monogr.title: A mery geste of Robyn Hoode and of hys lyfe, wyth a newe playe for to be played in Maye games very pleasaunt and full of pastyme.

Frvitfvll sermons: preached by the right Reverend Father, and constant martyr of Iesus Christ, Master Hvgh Latimer, newly imprinted with others not heretofore set forth in print, to the edifying of all which will dispose themselves to the reading of the same
Frvitfvll sermons
Index by VW to "AN ENGLISH GARNER" (1 vols 1877-1896) by Edward ARBER
Arber Anthology Index

person.note:
Norweigian playwright whose work was received enthusiastically by VW and by Bloomsbury more broadly. In his autobiography LW describes the plays' impact on his Cambridge contemporaries. They contained 'something else, something extraordinarily exciting which belonged to the immediate moment in which we lived and yet went down into the depths of our beliefs and desires and the great currents of history [...] the cobwebs and the veils, the pretences and hypocrisies which suppressed the truth, buttressed cruelty, injustice, and stupidity, and suffocated society in the nineteenth century, were broken through, exposed, swept away' (Leonard Woolf i.163).
Though VW does not write in a sustained fashion on Ibsen, he appears throughout her works. VW takes notes on Hedda Gabler (1891; cf. RN 47) in 1924, in preparation for CR1 and on The Master Builder (1892; cf. RN 25). She scribbles the name of The Wild Duck on the back of notes on E.M. Forster's Where Angels Fear to Tread (1894; cf. RN 15): in 'The Novels of E.M. Forster' (1927) she makes a sustained comparison between novelist and playwright, writing that Forster's 'closest affinity' is with Ibsen insofar as they share a 'combination of realism and mysticism,' and mentions both The Master Builder and The Wild Duck by name: whereas these plays create a 'sense of instant certainty,' there is an 'ambiguity at the heart of Mr Forster's novels' (E4 495-7). In 'Hours in a Library' (1916), Woolf's hypothetical young reader reads 'the whole of Ibsen' (E2 56), and in 'Poetry, Fiction and the Future' (1927) she writes of Ibsen's dramatic prose (E4 438). In VO, Rachel Vinrace reads a 'brightly-covered red volume lettered on the back Works of Henrik Ibsen' (136), and in ND Cyril Alardyce proposes to Katharine Hilbery's aunt Celia by means of a letter ' "full of quotations"' of ' "Ibsen and Butler"' (110). She writes two diary entries with the imperative that she 'must' read Ibsen: in her entry of 28 August 1922 she wants to compare him with Euripides (D2 196), and on 28 November 1928 she writes that she 'must read Ibsen & Shakespeare & Racine' (D3 210). In a letter to Quentin Bell dated 8 March 1934, she describes Lydia Lopkova's performance as Nora in a recent production of A Doll's House: 'she was a marvel, not only a light leaf in the wind, but edged, profound, and her English was exactly what Ibsen meant——it gave the right aroma' (L5 282, §. 2863). The only play of Ibsen's to which she refers by name herein is Ghosts (1881), which she does not discuss elsewhere.
LLVW contains a standalone copy of his The Master Builder and a twelve-volume Collected Works in their library (1906-12) which is missing the eleventh volume: in a letter dated 09 December 1914 she suggests that Clive Bell might have it: 'I noticed that you have No. 11 in the red edition of Ibsen——which is missing from our set. Is it possible that someone staying at Asheham took it away with them? You seemed only to have odd volumes, so I thought it possible' (L2 54, §. 713).

monogr.title: Sowing: An Autobiography of the Years 1880-1904

series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

person.persName: James VI of Scotland and I of England
person.note: James Stewart was annointed as James VI of Scotland at the tender age of thirteen months and, after the death of Elizabeth I and the subsequent union of the crowns, ruled as James VI of Scotland and James I of England and Ireland, although the union was never an easy one (Wormald n.p.). Prior to the union, he was a prolific author, attempting to codify Scottish poetry and distinguish it from English verse in the 1584 Reulis and Cautelis to be Observit and Eschewit in Scottish Poesie, and he was author of Daemonologie (1597), a tract on witch-hunting: the Woolfs had a 1924 Bodley Head Quartos facsimile of this (LLVW). Woolf draws from Daemonologie in her discussion of witches in the drafts herein. James's reign following the union saw a flourishing of English poetry and drama.

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

analytic.title: James VI and I (1566–1625), king of Scotland, England, and Ireland

person.note: An Anglo-American novelist whose long literary relationship with the Stephen family and hence with VW began as early as August 1878 when The Cornhill Magazine, edited by Leslie Stephen, printed his novella Daisy Miller (Edel 1.274). After James's relocation to Europe, he became a frequent visitor at Hyde Park Gate and Talland House (Annan 108). In 'Sketch' VW recalls the 'hesitations and adumbrations with which [he] made the living room [of Hyde Park Gate] seem rich and dusky' (MoB 173). One of her earliest publications was a 1905 review of The Golden Bowl, and she describes visiting him in a 1907 letter sent to Violet Dickinson (L1 306, §. 380). In a 1915 letter she asks Lytton Strachey to '[p]lease tell me what merit you find in Henry James. I have disabused Leonard of him; but we have his works here [at Asheham], and I read, and can't find anything but faintly tinged rose water, urbane and sleek, but vulgar and as pale as Walter Lamb' (L2 67, §. 732). She continues to write on Henry James throughout her career, both in essays specifically devoted to his work (cf. 'The Old Order' [1917; E3 167-76], 'Within the Rim' [1919; E3 22-5], 'The Letters of Henry James' [1920; E3 198-207], 'Henry James's Ghost Stories' [1921; E3 319-26]), an essay on critical assessments of his work ('The Method of Henry James' [1918; E2 346-9]), and in essays on the history and development of literature. In 'Hours in a Library' (1916), she writes that James was 'of course alive when this reader came to [him]' but nevertheless was 'already accepted among the classics' (E2 57). The CR1 essay 'The Patron and the Crocus' compares James to Samuel Butler and George Meredith: '[e]ach despised the public; each desired a public; each failed to attain a public; and each wreaked his failure upon the public' (E4 213). In 'Is Fiction an Art?' (1927), Woolf's review of E.M. Forster's Aspects of the Novel, Woolf critiques Forster's 'notably harsh judgment of Henry James' (E4 461). In her long 1929 essay 'Phases of Fiction,' Woolf lists James among the 'psychologists' (E5 63) alongside Proust and Dostoevsky. She took notes on 12 of his works at various points in her life, and LLVW contains 24 separate editions of his works. In 1924, the Hogarth Press published Henry James at Work, a biographical essay by Theodora Bosquanet, who acted as James's amanuensis from 1907-16.

Though VW never writes an essay dedicated to Samuel Johnson, the figure of this essayist, biographer, playwright, poet, editor (most notably of Shakespeare), and 'harmless drudge' (Johnson 'Lexicographer') nonetheless looms large in the richly populated landscape of her essays. The title of Woolf's two volumes of literary-historical essays invokes the Johnsonian common reader, whom she discusses in the preface to CR1. Writing of Gray's 'Elegy [Written in a Country Churchyard],' Johnson 'rejoice[s] to concur with the common reader; for by the common sense of readers uncorrupted with literary prejudices, after all the refinements of subtilty and the dogmatism of learning, must be finally decided all claim to poetical honours' (Johnson 'Gray' 385). VW expands on this invocation, writing of the common reader's 'instinct to create for himself, out of whatever odds and ends he can come by, some kind of whole' (E2 19), and this mode of reparative reading guides the CR essays. Woolf quotes from his life of Joseph Addison in her CR1 essay 'Addison' (E4 110-3), while he is among the guests in the essay 'Dr Burney's Evening Party'(1929, expanded for inclusion in CR2). We see Fanny Burney reading his novel Rasselas (1759) and writing Johnsonian sentences (E5 431), while he and Hester Thrale Piozzi appear in person later in the essay: Thrale Piozzi sings arias while Johnson remains silent and 'certainly almost blind' (438-43). The last of Woolf's essays to be published in her lifetime was 'Mrs Thrale' (1941; E6 292-7), a review of a life of Hester Thrale Piozzi, with whom Johnson had a close friendship for many years. On the verso of M109 [The Reader: At what point in Elizabethan drama...], fol. 1 is a portion of the TS for this essay. VW cites an instance of Johnsonian misogyny in Room when she quotes from Cecil Gray's Survey of Contemporary Music: "Of Mlle. Germaine Tailleferre one can only repeat Dr. Johnson's dictum concerning a woman preacher, transposed into terms of music. 'Sir, a woman's composing is like a dog's walking on his hind legs. It is not done well, but you are surprised to find it done at all.'" (50, cf. also Goldman 47-56 for more instances of dancing dogs). Johnson's dictum was originally reproduced in James Boswell's Life of Samuel Johnson, a work to which VW returns throughout her career. In 'The Art of Biography' (1939), she writes that Lytton Strachey's Eminent Victorians (1918) will 'do for the old Queen [Victoria] what Boswell did for the old dictionary maker,' (E6 184) although neither would 'live as long as Falstaff by Shakespeare' (186). Leslie Stephen wrote an 1878 biography of Johnson for the English Men of Letters series, and his Hours in a Library contains an essay on Johnson.
