person.note: Elizabethan playwright and poet associated with the Mermaid Tavern and hence with Beaumont and Fletcher (O'Callaghan). VW first discusses Jonson in a November 1905 letter to her brother, Thoby Stephen, that discusses her readings of Elizabethan playwrights. She tells her brother that '[t]omorrow I go on to Ben Jonson, but I shant like him as much as Marlowe' (L1 46, §. 39). In a diary entry dated 18 January 1918 she writes that on the 15th, Lady Strachey had 'read Ben Jonson's masques' to her and Leonard (D1 106). In the CR1 essay 'The Elizabethan Lumber Room,' she writes of 'the hyperbole, more surprising in a writer so terse and muscular, of Ben Jonson' (E4) while in 'Notes on an Elizabethan Play' she writes that 'outside Shakespeare and perhaps Ben Jonson, there are no characters in Elizabethan drama, only violence whom we know so little that we can scarcely care what becomes of them' (E4 64). He is a hero of Orlando and a friend of Nick Greene (O 81-2), and in introducing her theory of the androgynous mind, the narrator of Room tells her audience that Jonson's 'had a dash too much of the male' (93). Woolf refers to Jonson's plays throughout her reading notes, discussing The Alchemist, Bartholomew Fair, Epicoene, or the Silent Woman, The Sad Shepherd, and Volpone. In addition, in 1934 she makes notes on the prose compendium Timber: Or, Discoveries on Men and Matter, which she refers to in M111, set 3 of 3 [The Reader: Anonymity was a great possession] (RN45).

series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

person.note: William Kempe was an actor on the Elizabethan stage, who began his career as a 'jesting plaier' at courts in Europe. By 1594, he was part of the Lord Chamberlain's Men, William Shakespeare and Richard Burbage's theatre company. He is known to have played the roles of Peter, the Nurse's servant in Romeo and Juliet and Dogberry in Much Ado About Nothing, and it is conjectured that he played Bottom and Falstaff. By 1599 he had sold his share of the lease of the Globe and left the company. Kempe returned to clowning and his next public appearance was a highly unlikely one: in 1600, he performed a morris dance from London to Norwich, a journey of roughly 130 miles. He advertised this in a pamphlet, Kemp's Nine Daies Wonder. The precise date of his death is unknown, though it is likely that he died in 1603, a particularly bad plague year (Eccles III 293-5).

Sir William Knollys was the 1st Earl of Banbury and a cousin of Elizabeth I. Of relevance here is his relationship with Mary Fytton. Prior to her arrival at Elizabeth's court, he wrote to Fytton's father promising that he would play the role of 'the Good Shepperd & will to my power deffend the innocent lamb from the wolvyshe crueltye & fox-like subtletye of the tame bests of this place' (Knollys in Newdigate-Newdegate 9). His letters to Mary Fytton evidence quite a different relationship: one of an unrequited love for her. The letters went unanswered and Fytton left the court after only a very short stint there. The letters from Fytton's mother imply that she left the court in disgrace.

monogr.title: Gossip from a muniment room; being passages in the lives of Anne and Mary Fitton, 1574 to 1618.

person.note: Thomas Kyd was an English playwright, best-known for The Spanish Tragedy, though it was not attributed to him until 1773, over 175 years after his death: the play was considered anonymous until that point (cf. Mulryne n.p.). Details of Kyd's life are scant until he was arrested on charges of libel on 11th May 1593: officers searched Kyd's lodgings and did not find libellous material; rather, they found material deeped heretical. Kyd was almost certainly tortured by 'strappado' and wrote letters upon his release claiming that the heretical material belonged to Christopher Marlowe, with whom he was sharing lodgings. Kyd wrote these letters after Marlowe's death on 30th May 1593, and died himself shortly afterwards (Calvo and Tronch in Kyd 6-9).

series.title: Arden early modern drama

analytic.title: Kyd, Thomas (bap. 1558, d. 1594), playwright and translator

person.note: The author of BA's pageant. Miss La Trobe writes and directs the pageant that is performed in Woolf's 1941 novel. Eisenberg identifies La Trobe and Anon as counterparts (260) in an essay published in 1981 but drafted prior to Silver's publication of her edition of the 'Anon' drafts.

analytic.title: Virginia Woolf’s Last Words on Words: Between the Acts and ‘Anon’

monogr.title: New Feminist Essays on Virginia Woolf

series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

person.note: One of Arthur's knights of the Round Table and perhaps the most famous. While Lancelot's roots are in French romances (Bruce 308) and a vast amount of medieval literature in English, French, and German, testifies to Lancelot's story, Woolf's source for Arthurian mythology here is Thomas Malory's Morte Darthur (1485). In this account, Lancelot performs valiant feats as part of Arthur's retinue and in so doing attains 'the greatest name of any knight of the world' (Malory 128), but falls in love, and begins an affair, with Guinevere, Arthur's wife. Arthur discovers the affair and sentences Guinevere to be burned at the stake; Lancelot rescues her and they retreat to Joyous Gard, Lancelot's keep. Arthur wins this battle and Lancelot is exiled but at great cost – Arthur's final defeat at the hands of his son Mordred follows shortly thereafter.

series.title: Garland reference library of the humanities

monogr.title: Le morte Darthur: Sir Thomas Malory's book of King Arthur and of his noble knights of the round table.: The text of Caxton

person.note: Remarkably little can be reliably established about the life of William Langland, author of the long Middle English poem The Vision of Piers Plowman. Piers Plowman is an dream poem that sees the speaker travelling through an allegorical and at times surrealistic landscape in search of a goodly Christian life. Langland evidently worked on this text for years, if not decades, as three variant traditions of the poem are extant (A, B, and C), each one expanding on the last and each one referencing topical events that allow for them to be dated – tentatively, at least. Beyond internal evidence from the texts of his poem, the only reliable source describing Langland's life is a Latin inscription on the flyleaf of a copy of Piers Plowman (Kane n.p.). If VW read Langland's poem, then no trace survives: their library does not contain a copy; she made no notes on it and she makes no reference to it in any published work.

Reformation bishop, preacher, and, ultimately, martyr. During his early life Latimer was 'as obstinate a Papist as any in Europe' and in the oral examination for his theology degree preached against Lutheran reformer Philip Melancthon until he was converted to the reformist cause at Cambridge by Thomas Bilney (Latimer 124v). As a reformist theologian, he won the (wavering) favour of Henry VIII during the establishment of the Church of England but was imprisoned as a heretic by Mary I in the Bocardo, Oxford and burnt at the stake on 16 October 1555. LLVW contains a 1635 edition of Latimer's sermons, which VW took extensive notes on in 1940-1 in preparation for her Common History project, as much it seems for Latimer's socio-cultural commentary as for his theology (cf. RN 16).

analytic.title: Latimer, Hugh (c. 1485–1555), bishop of Worcester, preacher, and protestant martyr

person.note: John Leland was an English antiquary, historian, and collector of books whose Itineraries, records of his journeys around England undertaken 1538-43, did much to establish local history as a methodology. Leland was a fervent believer in the historical reality of King Arthur and Arthurian legend: the only prose work he published in his lifetime was the Latin tract Assertio inclytissimi Arturii regis Britanniae, which 'attempted to establish the validity of Arthur's historical existence' (Carley n.p.). His 1542 Itinerary reports that Arthur's castle, Camelot, was located in the Somerset village of Cadbury, and that a silver horseshoe was found in the village (Leland I.151, cf. also Strachey in Malory xii).

monogr.title: The itinerary of John Leland in or about the years 1535-1543
Le morte Darthur: Sir Thomas Malory's book of King Arthur and of his noble knights of the round table.: The text of Caxton

person.note: The Lord Mayor of London is the leader of the City of London Corporation and the mayor of the City of London, a historic district in the centre of London proper (which, as of 2000, has its own mayoralty). As the Lord Mayor is elected for a term of one year, and she does not specify a date, Woolf could be referring to any number of potential mayors. Southwark became a locus for early modern playhouse culture because it was close to the City of London, but outside of the Lord Mayor's jurisdiction.

John Lydgate was an English monk who wrote poems of ever-increasing length in a variety of genres. Among these is the Troy Book, a 30,000-line Middle English poem that tells the complete history of Troy from its foundation to its fall. In 'The Journal of Mistress Joan Martyn,' Martyn is sent a 'manuscript from London; called The Palace of Glass, by Mr John Lydgate' (CSF 46). Joan Martyn references Lydgate's House of Glas here, but the narrative she recounts, 'about Helen and the Siege of Troy' is from his Troy Book. If VW read any of Lydgate's poetry then no trace of that reading remains, and LLVW contains nothing by the poet.

monogr.title: The Complete Shorter Fiction of Virginia Woolf

person.note: Little can be established for certain about the life of the author of Le Morte Darthur, beyond that which can be gathered from evidence internal to the book itself. Certainly, he was 'called Thomas Malory, he was a knight and a prisoner, and he finished his work dring the ninth year of King Edward IV's reign' (Lacy 294). While there were 'six Thomas Malorys known to have been alive at the same time' (294), the most likely candidate was Sir Thomas Malory of Newbold Revel. Though this Malory was a knight and MP early in life, by 1450 he had evidently had a startling change of heart and, on 4 January 1550 attempted to ambush and murder the Duke of Buckingham. He followed this with an eighteen month crime spree which encompassed 'extortion, theft, rape, cattle rustling, robbery of the local abbey, and deer stealing and enormous damage to property' (Field n.p.). He spent the rest of his life in and out of prisons: while out of prison he joined Edward IV and the Lancastrians in his war against Henry VI and the Yorkists. His fortunes varied dramatically depending on which side was ascendant. It is thought that he wrote the Morte in the Tower of London, having been imprisoned without charge during the interregnum when Henry VI was restored to power (Field n.p.)

series.title: Garland reference library of the humanities

person.note: Francis Manners was the sixth earl of Rutland, and a participant in the courts of King James I and Charles I, and was a key figure in the unsuccessful 'Spanish Match' that Thomas Middleton allegorises in A Game at Chess (Loomie n.p.). In his Life of Shakespeare (1898, expanded ed. 1907), Sidney Lee reports that Manners paid William Shakespeare and Richard Burbage to 'design[] an "impresa"' for a royal jousting tournament, though the design itself does not survive (Lee 455-6).

analytic.title: Manners, Francis, sixth earl of Rutland (1578–1632), nobleman

person.note:
Playwright, poet, and possible spy for Elizabeth I. He was killed in a bar brawl by Ingram Frizer (cf. note on Frizer for the gory details). Woolf first mentions Marlowe in a November 1901 letter to her brother Thoby Stephen, in which she writes that she has read 'Dr Faustus and Edward II' and thinks 'them very near the great man [Shakespeare]——with more humanity I should say——not all on such a grand tragic scale' (L1 46, §. 39). She does not mention Edward II again. In August 1923 reads and takes notes on the second part of Tamburlaine and Faustus (cf. individual play entries for details), as well as The Jew of Malta: she writes that Marlowe 'cant combine his lyrics with the structural framework of a tragedy' and sums up Barabas as 'having a great power of displaying hate' (RN 25, fol. 32). She also takes notes on his long poem Hero and Leander in the same notebook.
In VO, Marlowe's works are to be found in Ambrose Ridley's library, though he is unsure quite why they are there (192) and he is among the dead whose names are enumerated in 'The Evening Party' (CSF 100). In JR, he is a favourite of Jacob Flanders, who transcribes and 'collate[s] editions of Marlowe in the British Museum,' the outcome of which is an 'incredibly dull essay' (173-4). In O, Marlowe is a literary hero of the young Orlando, and an associate of Nick Greene. He is mentioned as a forerunner necessary for Shakespeare to be able to write in Room (59) and he is among the dramatists whose plays Donne sees in the CR2 essay 'Donne after Three Centuries' (E5 351).
LLVW contains two collected editions of Marlowe, one of which is an 'unexpurgated' edition by sexologist Havelock Ellis, as well as a standalone edition of Hero and Leander. In addition it contains a copy of Leslie Hotson's The Death of Christopher Marlowe (1925) which VW used as a source herein (cf. RN 37).

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

monogr.title: The Complete Shorter Fiction of Virginia Woolf
A Room of One's Own and Three Guineas

person.note: John Marston was a poet, playwright and priest perhaps best known for his long-running literary feud with Ben Jonson. It is likely that Marston satirically portrayed Jonson in Histriomastix, and that Marston was the target of several of Jonson's satirical forays. This, however, did not stop Marston from providing a prefatory poem to Jonson's Sejanus (1605) or dedicating his own play, The Malcontent (1603-4) to him. The latter play, a dark comedy, was one of Marston's most successful plays. By 1609, Marston had become ordained as a priest, and thereafter he slowly fades from the historical record (Knowles n.p.). The Woolfs' library contains an 1856 three-volume edition of Marston's plays, signed and annotated by Leslie Stephen. Woolf rebound the second of the three volumes, but if she read any of the plays, no notes are extant.

analytic.title: Marston, John (bap. 1576, d. 1634), poet and playwright

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

person.note: An early Lutheran theologian against whom Hugh Latimer preached in the final examination for his degree in divinity. Latimer professes to have spent his 'whole Oration' preaching against Melancthon 'and his opinions.' Thomas Bilney was in the congregation and later converted Latimer to a mode of the Lutheranism he had inveighed against (Latimer 124v). VW read the sermon in which Latimer discusses this in 1940-1, cf. RN 16.

In Arthurian legend, Merlin is a wizard and advisor to King Arthur. He first appears in Geoffrey of Monmouth's Historia Regum Brittanae (1385), and is adapted from the Welsh prophet Myrddin. (Bruce 358-9). In Le Morte Darthur, VW's source for Arthurian myth, Malory figures him as a a near-constant companion to Arthur who foretells many of his adventures, before being imprisoned under a rock by the Lady of the Lake (Malory 75-6).

series.title: Garland reference library of the humanities

monogr.title: Le morte Darthur: Sir Thomas Malory's book of King Arthur and of his noble knights of the round table.: The text of Caxton

person.note: Michelangelo di Lodovico Buonarroti Simono is an Italian renaissance painter, sculptor and architect, famous enough to go by his first name. In RF, VW quotes a letter Fry sends to G. Lowes Dickinson (Goldie) from Italy, in which he writes that the Medici Chapel ' "makes me quite certain that Michelangelo was the greatest architect that has lived since Greek times"' and that the chapel ' "expresses an idea at least as complete and intelligible as a sonata of Beethoven's"' (71). Also writing from Italy, VW asks her sister '[h]ow did Miachel Angelo paint the ceiling [of the Sistine Chapel]? Slung on a board? What do you think of Raphael? and of Michael Angelo? Please tell me" (L3 367, §. 1747).

Thomas Middleton is credited as the only English renaissance playwright other than William Shakespeare to have 'created plays still considered masterpieces in four major dramatic genres: comedy, history, tragedy, and tragicomedy' (Taylor in Middleton i.25): he also wrote prose satire, masques and pageants. He collaborated with Shakespeare, writing part of Timon of Athens, and sold Shakespeare's company, The King's Men, the text of The Revenger's Tragedy to perform, thereby beginning a commercial and artistic partnership that would endure past Shapespeare's death in 1616. Middleton was 'apparently the only playwright trusted by the King's Men to update Shakespeare's plays after his death' (Taylor n.p.). Middleton's final play, A Game at Chess was his greatest commercial success but also proved his downfall. A theological and political satire that gives the Spanish Match, an unsuccessful attempt by King James I to ally Protestant England and Catholic Spain through marriage, allegorical form as a chess game. The play sees England and Spain locked in a ritualised, carefully choreographed intrigue – the play's characters are chess pieces moving across a board, struggling for advantage and to avoid '[t]he bag [which], like hell-mouth, opens | To take her due' (5.3.179-80). The play was performed for an unprecedented nine days, from 5-14th August 1624, before it was closed down. The Privy Council ordered a manhunt for Middleton, after which he was probably imprisoned: thereafter he stopped writing for the stage (Taylor n.p.). Unlike many of his contemporaries, VW did not make reading notes on Middleton (or at least none are extant), and none of his works are catalogued in their library.

analytic.title: A Game at Chess: A Later Form

person.note: A character in Woolf's short story 'The Legacy,' drafted 1940 for publication in Harper's Bazaar but only published posthumously in HH. Sissy Miller is the secretary of the recently deceased Angela Clandon, and the brother of the mysterious 'B.M.' Angela's husband Gilbert reads through his wife's journals and becomes convinced that she had an affair with 'B.M.'.

monogr.title: The Complete Shorter Fiction of Virginia Woolf

person.note: Michel Eyquem de Montaigne was a French essayist whose works were a continual touchstone for VW. Though she would not publish on Montaigne until 1925, she reads him far earlier: cf. Allan, who traces this life-long relationship and their many affinities. In a letter of 25 January 1903, she writes to thank her brother Thoby for having 'routed out a Montaigne for me,' likely in translation by Charles Cotton, and tells him that she 'always read[s] Montaigne in bed' (L1 66, §. 66). Two days later she writes to Thoby that 'the Montaigne and Bacon are a continual delight to me" (67, §. 67). Her first published mention of Montaigne comes only two years later in the 1905 essay 'The Decay of Essay-Writing,' in which she calls him 'the first of the moderns' (E1 25). Two decades later, CR1 essay on Montaigne, a review of a recent edition of Charles Cotton's translation of the Essais, numbers him among the few writers who 'succeeded in drawing [himself] with a pen' (E4 71). Woolf's diary entry of 25 April 1931 describes the trip that she and LW took to Montaigne's chateau at St. Michel-de-Montaigne and the tower in which he wrote, upon whose rafters Montaigne chalked lines from his essays, including his motto, 'Que S'cais je? [What do I know?]' (D4 20-1). LLVW contains six editions of his writings: five editions of his essays, and the translation of the diaries he kept during his 1580-1 journey to Italy that the Hogarth Press published in 1929.

In Arthurian mythology, Morgan le Fay is a sorceress who variously acts as an aid or antagonist to Arthur. In VW's source for Arthurian mythology, Le Morte Darthur, she is Arthur's half-brother. Malory makes her Arthur's constant antagonist. She learns magic from Merlin and works to engineer her brother's downfall. However, this does not stop her from bearing Arthur's body away from the place of his final battle with Mordred to Avalon for healing (Bruce 368).

series.title: Garland reference library of the humanities

person.note: Maurice Morgann was a scholar of literature and a colonial administrator of whom little is known: he instructed his executors to destroy all his papers after his death (Cornish n.p.). He was best known in the centuries following his death as the author of Morgann's Essay on the Dramatic Character of Sir John Falstaff (1777): as late as 1894, his entry in DNB praises it, saying that it remained 'unsurpassed' for 'style, intellectuality, knowledge of human nature, and consequent profound appreciation of Shakespeare' (Seccombe n.p.). The Woolfs had an 1892 edition of in their library (LLVW), though if VW made notes on it, none are extant.

analytic.title: Morgann, Maurice (1725–1802), colonial administrator and literary scholar

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

person.note: Author, designer, leader of the Arts and Crafts movement, revolutionary socialist and founder of the Kelmscott Press. LLVW contains three copies of his first poetry collection The Defence of Guenevere and Other Poems (1903) in their library, one a gift from Lytton Strachey to LW and another a gift from Philip Sidney Woolf and Cecil Woolf to LW, and a copy of his 1915 The Pilgrims of Hope and Chants for Socialists. In MD, Sally Seton gives the young Clarissa volumes of William Morris at Bourton, and the two plan a society to abolish private property and 'reform the world'. Their plans have to be kept secret and the books have to be 'wrapped in brown paper' to escape the watchful gaze of Aunt Helena who 'never liked discussion of anything' (30).

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

person.note: Early modern playwright, poet, and prose pamphleteer. In 'A Society' (1920) Helen quotes from 'Spring, the sweete spring, is the yeres pleasant King,' a song in his 1600 comedy Summers last will and testament (CSF 127; Nashe 5). Beyond this, and mention of The Unfortunate Traveller herein, there is slender evidence to suggest VW encountered Nashe: no reading notes survive if she made any, LLVW contains no works by him, but her index to Edward Arber's An English Garner contains one item by Nashe, 'Somewhat to read for them that liste,' a prefatory epistle to Philip Sidney's Astrophel and Stella (RN Arber fol. 15r; Arber I.497-502). In the 1916 essay 'In a Library,' she quotes Nashe's poem 'In a Time of Pestilence' — or at least quotes a quotation thereof.

person.note: Attended Anne Clifford. "Daughter of Mary Sackville and Henry Neville, 7th Baron Abergavenny, niece and god-daughter of Richard Sackville, part of the household at Knole" (Malay 287)

Along with Crot and Pulley, one of a trio of 'invisible influences' that interpellate the early English singer as a subject and shape their song. Woolf begins to discuss these influences as early as RN2. [Holograph reading notes] Notes for reading at random. The names of all three of the trio are defined by Joseph Wright in his English Dialect Dictionary, with which Woolf was evidently familiar (cf. Leaska in Woolf 1978, xii). According to Wright's dictionary, 'Nin' is a Cornish dialect verb meaning “to drink” but is also cross-referenced to 'none,' whose usage in various dialects bears similar valences to standard English usage (Nin, cf. also Phillips 214).

analytic.title: How Should One Read “The Reader”? New Approaches to Virginia Woolf’s Late Archive

person.note: Lady Elizabeth Stafford was a lady-in-waiting to Katherine of Aragon but was known primarily for her abusive marriage to Thomas Howard, duke of Norfolk, and its collapse in the 1530s (Graves n.p.). She was patron to poet and playwright John Skelton and mother of Henry Howard, Earl of Surrey. What VW intended to quote in the blank in M50. Anon., fol. 9r is not apparent.

analytic.title: Howard [née Stafford], Elizabeth, duchess of Norfolk (1497–1558), noblewoman

person.note: The paterfamilias of the Oliver family in BA, and one of the denizens of Pointz Hall. A retired member of the Indian Civil Service, he is father to Giles Oliver and father-in-law to Isabel (Isa) Oliver, brother to Lucy Swithin and has an Afghan hound named Sohrab – Hussey notes that Oliver's 'habit of yelling at [Sohrab] to heel' was reminiscent of LW's (194).

monogr.title: Virginia Woolf A to Z: a comprehensive reference for students, teachers and common readers to her life, work and critical reception
Virginia Woolf A to Z

series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

person.note: A member of the Oliver family in BA, and an inhabitant of Pointz Hall. He is the (unfaithful) husband of Isabel (Isa) Oliver, with whom he has two children and the son of Bartholomew Oliver.

series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

person.note: A member of the Oliver family in BA, and an inhabitant of Pointz Hall along with her husband Giles, with whom she has two children, and father-in-law Bartholomew. Isa is somewhat of a frustrated poet, whose murmured lines of verse punctuate BA.

series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

person.note: A cloth-merchant from Cogeshall, Essex. He is the subject of a chapter of Eileen Power's Medieval People (1924; LLVW contains 1937 reprint). Power draws on three sources to evidence his life: 'houses, brasses, and wills' which 'contain much evidence for the increasingly rapid growth during the last two centuries of the Middle Ages of a large and prosperous middle class, whose wealth was not based upon landed property but upon industry and trade' (158).

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

person.note: Brother to Mary Sidney (neé Herbert) and hence brother-in-law to Philip and Robert Sidney, and a patron of literature in his own right. He is the dedicatee of Shakespeare's first folio and a potential identity for the pseudonymous Mr W.H. to whom Shakespeare's sonnets are dedicated. However, in this narrative, he is more closely associated with Mary Fytton and The Chopping Knife.

Samuel Pepys kept a diary from 01 January 1660 to 31 May 1669, only stopping because he feared blindness, having taxed his vision 'so long as to undo my eyes almost every time I take a pen in my hand' (9.564). Though VW only took one line of notes on Pepys' diaries, copying out the line she quotes herein into RN 37 (1937-41), she first read Pepys over two weeks in the spring of 1897 (PA 62-70). Barbara Lounsberry notes Pepys as a significant early influence on the young Virginia Stephen's diaries (1.31-4) and traces this influence throughout her career as a diarist, through to distinctly Pepysian echoes in her 1939 diary entries (3.28). In 1918, VW reviewed a publication of papers read at meetings of the Samuel Pepys Club (Papers on Pepys; E2 233-8). LLVW contains three editions of Pepys' diary (one with Leslie Stephen's annotations), another of his correspondence and other papers, and Percy Lubbock's 1920 monograph on Pepys.

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog
The diary of Samuel Pepys. Vol. 9, 1668-1669
Becoming Virginia Woolf: her early diaries & the diaries she read
Becoming Virginia Woolf
Virginia Woolf, the War Without, the War Within: Her Final Diaries and the Diaries She Read

person.persName: Pliny the Elder or Pliny the Younger
person.note: Woolf refers to one of two first-century Latin authors. Pliny the Elder was a geographer whose Naturalis Historia was encyclopedic in scope but was left unfinished at the time of his death at Pompeii in 79 CE, as Mount Vesuvius erupted. His nephew, Pliny the Younger, watched the eruption from across the Bay of Naples and provides an eyewitness account of the event. Pliny the Younger was a noted letter-writer, and LLVW contains an 1865 Latin edition collecting some of them. There is no evidence of VW having read this volume or any other of the letters; nor any of the works of Pliny the Elder.

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

person.note: Along with Nin and Crot, one of a trio of 'invisible influences' that interpellate the early English singer as a subject and shape their song. Woolf begins to discuss these influences as early as RN2. [Holograph reading notes] Notes for reading at random. The names of all three of the trio are defined by Joseph Wright in his English Dialect Dictionary, with which Woolf was evidently familiar (cf. Leaska in Woolf 1978, xii). Out of the trio, Pulley's name is probably the most familiar to modern anglophone audiences: Wright defines it as the 'wheel placed over a pit over which the rope for drawing coals is passed' (Pulley, cf. also Phillips 215).

analytic.title: How Should One Read “The Reader”? New Approaches to Virginia Woolf’s Late Archive

monogr.title: The Pargiters: the Novel-Essay Portion of 'The Years'
Pargiters
monogr.idno: 823.91 18 British Library DSC 78/7131 British Library HMNTS X.989/52030

person.note: Radical Protestant reformists who, in an English and British context, attempted to remove Roman Catholic influences from the newly-established Church of England. The sect grew in influence during the early 17th century and became associated with the Parliamentarians during the English Civil War. Chambers attests to their growing cultural influence and the effect that this influence had on the English stage, up to the moment that Parliament ordered playhouses to close at the outbreak of civil war on 2 September 1642 (1.387-8).

Sir Walter Raleigh wore several hats: he was a courtier and favourite of Elizabeth I, a soldier in Ireland, a colonist in Virginia, an explorer who searched for El Dorado, and a propagandist and poet. He is popularly credited with introducing tobacco and the potato to Britain; despite his putative contributions to British cuisine, he did not find favour with James I, who had him executed (Nicholls and Williams n.p.). VW reviewed a selection of Raleigh's prose for TLS, published 15 March 1917 (E2 91-96). VW's handmade index to Edward Arber's English Garner anthology notes has two entries for Raleigh's writing (RN Arber fol. 20r).

analytic.title: Ralegh [Raleigh], Sir Walter (1554–1618), courtier, explorer, and author

monogr.title: Index by VW to "AN ENGLISH GARNER" (1 vols 1877-1896) by Edward ARBER
Arber Anthology Index

person.note: Rafaello Sanzino da Urbino, referred to in English as Raphael, was an Italian renaissance painter and architect. He is a constant presence in RF. Woolf writes in a letter to Vanessa Bell dated 26 April 1927, sent from Rome, that among the works of art she has seen 'Raphael comes out very much better than I expected' and asks Bell her opinion of the painter, as well as whether Michelangelo painted the Sistine Chapel 'slung on a board' (L6 367, §. 1747). In TL, Lily Briscoe and William Bankes discuss the 'significance of mother and son' in painting, and Lily's 'neglect' of the subject: Briscoe saves face by teling Bankes that she does 'not intend to disparage a subject which, they agreed, Raphael had treated divinely' (145).

person.persName: Anne Dudley (neé Russell), Countess of Warwick
person.note: Anne Dudley (1548/9-1604; neé Russell) was maid of honour to Elizabeth I, Countess of Warwick through her marriage to Ambrose Dudley, Earl of Warwick, and aunt and godmother to Anne Clifford (Adams).

analytic.title: Dudley [née Russell], Anne, countess of Warwick (1548/9–1604), courtier

person.note: According to Malay, this member of Anne Clifford's social circle was a "Lady of Queen Anne of Denmark's bedchamber" (290).

French aristocratic letter-writer better known in English as Madame de Sévigné. VW wrote a 1939 essay on de Sévigné, which was only published posthumously. This essay compares the 'unconscious naturalness' of de Sévigné's letters with those of anglophones Horace Walpole and Thomas Gray (E6 497 cf. 'The Humane Art' on Walpole's correspondence [1940 E6 225-9]). Notes on de Sévigné's correspondence and secondary material can be found in RNs 16, 37, 54: the first two also contain notes for Woolf's literary history. LLVW contains three French-language editions of her letters in their library, as well as two copies of Edward FitzGerald's 1914 Dictionary of Madame de Sévigné: VW has written an index in one of these copies.

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

person.note:
VW read, quoted from and alluded to William Shakespeare's works almost constantly throughout her life, as well as imagining for him a sister whose mute voice is metonymic of women's writing throughout literary history. Fox describes the playwright as part of the 'atmosphere' of Hyde Park Gate (94) and details VW's early ambivalence she felt towards him (94-6), an ambivalence which she had yet to overcome by 1909 when she took notes on Hamlet, King Lear Macbeth, Othello, and Romeo and Juliet, alongside A.C. Bradley's Shakespearean Tragedy (cf. RN 29). Woolf never writes an essay specifically on Shakespeare, and the later drafts herein begin to give a reason for this:
M112, Set 1 of 3 argues Shakespearean criticism is always inadequate and that
One reason why Shakespeare is still read is simply the inadequacy of Shakespearean criticism. The inadequacy of that criticism is means that is due of course to the it is always autobiographical criticism
(M112 [The Reader]. Typescript fragment with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 5p. fol. 1 recto)
In M111, Set 1 of 3, Shakespeare is read to 'testify [...] to the enormous possibilities of speed' and VW asserts that the 'truest account of reading Shakespeare' would not resemble a conventional book 'with a beginning middle and end' but rather a collection of 'notes':
used for more general purposes--when the ink has gone dry upon the pen to revive the sense of language; or to testify, when words seem motionless, to the enormous possibilities of speed. One reading always supersedes another Thus the truest account of reading Shakespeare would be not to write a book with a beginning middle and end; but to collect notes, without trying to make them consistent.
(M111 Set 1 of 3, [The Reader: But her own passion, the disgrace, the humiliation...]. fol. 1 verso)
Froula argues that '[f]igures of Shakespeare are often figures of Woolf: moments of oblique self-portraiture that catch important features of her artistic self-fashioning. Throughout her life Woolf drew upon Shakespeare's art to inspire and measure her own, even as she pressed beyond the limits of his male-centered characters and plots' (123, cf. also Briggs).
LLVW contains 39 separate editions of works by Shakespeare, including collected editions of his plays and standalone editions of 21 of the 38 plays he is known to have written. For more details of Woolf's citations of and interactions with plays referenced in the 'Anon' drafts, cf. individual entries for Antony and Cleopatra, The Comedy of Errors, Hamlet, Henry V, 1 Henry 6, 2 Henry 6, 3 Henry 6, King John, King Lear, Macbeth, Romeo and Juliet, and The Tempest.

A Room of One's Own and Three Guineas

person.note: Edmund Sheffield was an English courtier to Elizabeth I and later James I, who captained three ships as the Spanish Armada approached Britain in May 1588. On 4 March 1619, he married Mariana Irwin, a marriage which Anne Clifford described in her diary as 'a mean match, an undiscreet on part of him' (cf. Stater n.p., Clifford 89-90).

monogr.title: The Diary of the Lady Anne Clifford: With an Introductory Note by V. Sackville-West

analytic.title: Sheffield, Edmund, first earl of Mulgrave (1565–1646), politician

person.note: Sir Philip Sidney, a poet, soldier and courtier to Queen Elizabeth who died after being shot in the leg in a battle in the Netherlands. In addition to writing poetry and prose, he acted as a patron for other writers including Edmund Spenser, and family's stately home, Penshurst, in Kent, was a locus of courtly literary activity both before and after his death. In 1907, VW reviews a reissue of Sir Fulke Greville's Life of Sir Philip Sidney (E1 139-43). She reads and takes notes on his prose Defense of Poesie in 1924 as she was preparing to write CR1 (cf. RN 47) and, in the essay 'The Elizabethan Lumber Room' compares this work with the writings of Michel de Montaignein order to explore '[h]ow little Elizabethan prose was fit for its office [and] how exquisitely French prose was already adapted' (E4 56). She wrote on his prose pastoral romance The Countess of Pembroke's Arcadia in CR2 (E5 366-76). VW writes that 'in the Arcadia, as in some luminous globe, all the seeds of English fiction lie latent. We can trace infinite possibilities: it may take one of many different directions' (373). LLVW has two editions of the Arcadia, one dating from 1655 and the other from 1662: VW takes notes on the former in preparation for the CR2 essay, cf. RN 8, 48. LLVW also contains the first volume of a 1873 two-volume set of his poetry. LW's brother was called Philip Sidney Woolf, and in her letter describing Vita Sackville-West (and her legs) to Jacques Raverat, she tells Raverat that Sackville-West 'descends from Dorset, Buckingham, Sir Philip Sidney, and the whole of English history' (L3 150, §. 1520; 26 December 1924).

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

person.note: Robert Sidney, first earl of Leicester, was the brother of Sir Philip Sidney and Mary Herbert (née Sidney), and the father of poet Mary Wroth. Much like his brother, he was a courtier and a poet: their father 'urged [Robert Sidney] to imitate his elder brother in all things' (Shephard n.p.). He met with the approval of both Elizabeth I and her successor James and later in life maintained Penshurst as a locus of courtly literary culture.

analytic.title: Sidney, Robert, first earl of Leicester (1563–1626), courtier and poet

person.note: Potentially the Reverend John Skinner, one of the two parsons whose twin biography Woolf writes in her CR2 essay of that title (E5 423-30). Like John Woodforde, the first of Woolf's two parsons, he spent much of his life as Rector in the village of Camerton, Somerset, and kept a diary. His diary details not just day-to-day life in rural England but also Skinner's work as an amateur antiquarian: he identified Camerton with the Roman Camalodunum, 'where Ostorius established his colony, where Arthur had fought the traitor Mordred, where Alfred very nearly came in his misfortunes' (426) (Camalodunum is actually modern-day Colchester). Skinner's antiquarianism was met with scorn, including from his own sons, and Woolf reports his death by suicide.

Bartholomew Oliver's Afghan Hound named Sohrab. The locus classicus for the name Sohrab is Matthew Arnold's 1853 quasi-Miltonic epic poem 'Sohrab and Rustum.' Woolf knew this poem: her library contain's Arnold's 1859 Poems, which prints 'Sohrab and Rustum,' while she reports in a diary entry of 9th May 1897 that Leslie Stephen recited the poem 'after dinner' (PA 83). Arnold's poem relates how Rustum, an Iranian warrior, killed Sohrab, a warrior in the Tatar host and the son Rustum did not know he had, in single combat (Arnold 302-331). The name Sohrab is a double intertext: within Woolf's own corpus it recalls Old Rustum in Orlando (cf. O 131), the gypsy who disabuses the newly female Orlando of her pride in what she had previously considered her illustrious heritage (136). As a further doggy aside, Orlando has a 'seluchi' (or saluki) in Turkey (129)—a type of sighthound related to the Afghan hound.

series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf
The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

monogr.title: A Passionate Apprentice: The Early Journals
Passionate Apprentice

person.note: The author of The Faerie Queene and The Shepherd's Calendar, among other poems (cf. individual entries for more information on VW's interaction with these). Philip Sidney acted as his patron. Spenser appears as a character in the CR2 essay 'The Strange Elizabethans' (E5 335-48) as an interlocutor with Gabriel Harvey: he sits with Harvey in 'small, smoky rooms' and 'discuss[] poetry and language and the future of English literature' (342). LLVW contains two editions of Spenser's work, a five-volume 1862 edition edited by J. Payne Collier (which was presented to, and annotated by, Leslie Stephen) and a single-volume 1899 edition edited by R. Morris. It is likely that Woolf found the description of Spenser as a 'small man with cuffs and a band' in the 1862 edition, which contains a brief, unattributed biography of Spenser with this line.

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

person.note: Little is known of Gabriel Spencer, an actor on the Elizabethan stage who is most famous for his death. Spencer killed one James Feake in 1596, and was himself killed in a duel by Ben Jonson in 1598. Beyond this, all that has been established is that he spoke four lines as a messenger in 3 Henry VI (cf. Eccles IV 172).

analytic.title: Elizabethan Actors IV: S to End

person.note: Saint George is the patron saint of England, whose saint's day is celebrated on 23 April (incidentally, the day on which Shakespeare is thought to have been born and died). In popular legend, Saint George is known for slaying a dragon. The 'Saint Georges play' to which Woolf refers is a mummer's play which stages a battle between crusader forces, led by Saint George, and Turkish knights. In Hardy's Return of the Native (1878), the Edgon mummers rehearse and perform the 'well-known play of Saint George' at Christmas (157 et passim). Saint George is introduced by '[h]ump-backed Father Christmas [...] swinging [a] huge club, and in a general way clearing the stage for the actors proper' (171). Hardy's narrative excerpts extensively from the play, and we see Saint George vanquish all comers — but Hardy does not dwell on the miraculous resurrection of the dead that occurs at the end of the play (171-4). VW read and took notes on Hardy's novels between February 1919 and January 1921 in readiness for an eventual obituary she had been comissioned to write for TLS on February 14 1919, when the ' "evil hour"' of Hardy's death came (cf. RN 42). The obituary was not published until 11 January 1928 (E4 507-19, cf. 517 n. 1), and it was reprinted in CR2 (E5 561-72). In 1928, theatrical publisher Samuel French printed an edition of the Play of St. George whose text was provided by Hardy, based in no small part on the mummery scene in Return. The 1928 edition also contained a 'modernized' version of the play that features among its dramatis personae King Arthur and Mussolini (Hardy and Loomis). There is no evidence VW encountered this peculiar text.

monogr.title: The play of St. George, as aforetime acted by the Dorsetshire Christmas mummers. Based on the version in "The return of the native" and completed from other versions and local tradition

person.note: The Worshipful Company of Stationers and Newspaper Makers (or Stationers' Company) is a livery company of the City of London, who were responsible for regulating the book trade and whose membership had a monopoly on book production. The Stationers' Register maintained records of all works legally published, and all plays performed, in Britain prior to the Copyright Act of 1710, and as such constitutes a valuable source for the early modern playhouse. They were also empowered to act as censors for state and for church.

Gaius Suetonius Tranquillus was a Roman historian whose most significant work was the 121 BCE De vita Caesarum or The lives of the Caesars, a set of biographies of twelve Roman rulers, beginning with Julius Caesar's rule and the end of the Roman Republic, and ending with the emperor Domitian. LLVW contains a 1893 Latin edition of his surviving works titled C. Suetoni Tranquili quae supersunt omnia in their library, with LW's signature and annotations.

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

person.note: Henry Howard, earl of Surrey, was a poet and a soldier who had the dubious honour of being the last person executed on the orders of Henry VIII. While putting down an uprising in Lincolnshire and East Anglia, a folk ballad emerged that questioned Howard's loyalties. He fell from grace, and though Henry VIII sent him to lead troops in northern France in October 1543, his failure in this campaign led to his downfall. He was put on trial for treason on New Year's Day of 1547 and by the 19th of that month he was dead (cf. Brigden n.p.).

analytic.title: Howard, Henry, earl of Surrey (1516/17–1547), poet and soldier

person.note: A member of the Oliver family in BA, and a denizen of Pointz Hall along with her brother Bartholomew Oliver and his descendants. Lucy's surname, Swithin, is most likely a reference to St. Swithin (c. 800-862), and his eponymous saints' day on July 15th (cf. Brewer's). According to English folkloric tradition, if it rains on St. Swithin's day then it will rain for forty days thereafter; if the weather is fine then the next forty days will be fine. Rather than predicting the weather, this Swithin 'retire[s] to Hastings' to escape cold Pointz Hall winters (BA 6). She has several nicknames, including Batty (7), Cindy (15), and Old Flimsy (20). After the pageant, she seeks out Miss La Trobe to congratulate her on the pageant. Swithin can only 'lay[] hold to a fraction of her meaning' but La Trobe interpolates: Swithin is trying to say 'I could have played... Cleopatra' and that she has 'stirred in me my unacted part' (110).

monogr.title: Brewer's Dictionary of Phrase and Fable

series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

person.note: Aletheia Howard, Countess of Arundel, of Surrey, and of Norfolk, is mentioned in passing here as an associate of Anne Clifford but important in her own right. A granddaughter of Bess of Hardwick, and sister to Elizabeth Grey, countess of Kent, Howard was a patron of the visual arts both in Britain and in Italian cities including Venice, where she lived in 1622. During her sojourn there, she was accused of treason by the Doge but exonerated herself. She spent the final fourteen years of her life in exile in Amsterdam. A work of domestic science bearing her engraving on the flyleaf and titled Natura Exenterata has been attributed to her (cf. DiMeo, Anonymous [attr. Aletheia Howard, Countess of Arundel]).

monogr.title: Natura exenterata: or Nature unbowelled by the most exquisite anatomizers of her. Wherein are contained, her choicest secrets digested into receipts, fitted for the cure of all sorts of infirmities, whether internal or external, acute or chronical, that are incident to the body of man. / Collected and preserved by several persons of quality and great experience in the art of medicine, whose names are prefixed to the book. Containing in the whole, one thousand seven hundred and twenty. Very necessary for such as regard their owne health, or that of their friends. VVhereunto are annexed, many rare, hitherto un-imparted inventions, for gentlemen, ladies and others, in the recreations of their different imployments. With an exact alphabetical table referring to the several diseases, and their proper cures.

author.name: Anonymous [attr. Aletheia Howard, Countess of Arundel]

analytic.title: Howard, Aletheia [née Talbot], countess of Arundel, of Surrey, and of Norfolk, and suo jure Baroness Furnivall, Baroness Talbot, and Baroness Strange of Blackmere (d. 1654), patron and collector of art

person.note: Victorian poet with whom Leslie Stephen was personally close and with whose work he was intimately familiar: VW came to associate Tennyson's poetry inextricably with her father. In 'Impressions of Sir Leslie Stephen,' the obituary of her father commissioned by F.W. Maitland as part of his Life and Letters of Sir Leslie Stephen, she writes that Stephen had 'long acquired all the famous poems of Wordsworth, Tennyson, Keats, and Matthew Arnold, among moderns,' and that he would recite these poems by heart such that his audience 'felt that he was speaking not merely the words of Tennyson or Wordsworth, but what he himself felt and knew' (E1 128-9). In TL, Mr Ramsay is given to reciting (often at great volume) lines from Tennyson's 'The Charge of the Light Brigade' throughout the novel. Tennyson is one of the characters of Freshwater, and in O the narrator names him as the 'last person to suffer from' genius 'in the British Isles' (190), though Nick Greene cites him as example that ' "the great days are over. We live in degenerate times"' (254-5). For more on Woolf's life-long engagement (both biographical and literary) with Tennyson, cf. Kopley.

series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

person.note: Cyril Tourneur was a poet and playwright best known today for his first play The Atheist's Tragedy: Or, The Honest Man's Revenge, a twist on the revenge tragedy wherein Charlemont, the play's revenger, is counselled by his father's ghost to 'Attend with patience the success of things | But leave revenge unto the King of kings' (Tourneur ii.VI 21-22). The Revenger's Tragedy was attributed to Tourneur, but is now more commonly attributed to Thomas Middleton (Gunby n.p.). The Woolfs had the first volume of an 1878 two-volume collection of his plays and poems in their library (LLVW).

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

series.title: New Mermaids

person.note: G.M. Trevelyan was a historian whose popular works sought to engage in nation-building and the construction of what he called 'Englishry' (cf. Cannadine, n.p.). During his time at Trinity College, Cambridge, he was elected as an Apostle (though he left Cambridge in 1903, the same year that LW arrived). VW uses his History of England (1926) as a source for the 'Anon' drafts, quoting from its opening pages and citing it in M53. Anon. Typescript fragment, unsigned, dated Nov. 24, 1940. (cf. also RN37). As well as histories of England and Britain, Trevelyan wrote a trilogy of works on Garibaldi, figuring him as a 'Carlylean hero' and a 'champion of freedom, progress, and tolerance' (Cannadine n.p.). LLVW contains seven works by Trevelyan, including the History of England from which VW quotes: this volume contains LW's annotations.

analytic.title: Trevelyan, George Macaulay (1876–1962), historian, public educator, and conservationist

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

person.note: There is not enough information about this person to make a definitive identification.
The pseudonymous dedicatee and 'onlie begetter' of William Shakespeare's Sonnets. Candidates named in the 'Anon' drafts include William, Lord Pembroke and Henry Wriothesley

A character in A Woman Killed with Kindness, the domestic tragedy by Thomas Heywood. Wendoll is invited by John Frankford to live with Frankford and his newlywed wife, Anne. Wendoll is smitten by Anne and seduces her. The two begin an affair, which is brought to an abrupt halt when Frankford devises a scheme to discover them. He is restrained from killing Wendoll, whom he exiles in disgrace instead. Wendoll and Anne have one final meeting in the final scenes of the play, as Anne starves herself in an act of contrition.

series.title: Arden early modern drama

person.note: Rowland Whyte was a courtier and diplomat, in the service of Robert Sidney. Though initially a servant to the Sidney family (both Robert and his elder brother Philip) he became a close confidante to Robert. His letters constitute a vivid and valuable source on life at the courts of Elizabeth I and James I (Brennan et al. in Whyte 3-4). He was postmaster to the royal court, distributing all official Privy Council letters and documents, for a period that spanned both reigns (1598-1603; Brennan et al. in Whyte 21).

Henry Wriothesley, third earl of Southampton, was a literary patron and courtier. He was briefly patron of William Shakespeare: Shakespeare dedicated his two long poems Venus and Adonis (1593) and The Rape of Lucrece (1594) to Wriothesley. He is a possible candidate for the pseudonymous Mr W. H. to whom Shakespeare dedicates his sonnets.

monogr.title: Shakespeare's poems: Venus and Adonis, The rape of Lucrece, and the shorter poems

series.title: The Arden Shakespeare. Third series.

person.note: John Wycliffe was a scholastic philospher and theologian, reformist priest, and Biblical translator active in the fourteenth century. Though his theological views, which anticipated those of the later Protestant reformation, were controversial enough to spark a riot in 1376 and a Papal bull censuring him, his most lasting achievement was probably the Wycliffite Bible, the first complete English translation of the Bible. His followers were known as Lollards, and were active throughout England until the 1500s.

Irish poet and playwright who had close connections to Ottoline Morrell's circle at Garsington. In a letter sent 29 April 1919 she writes to Morrell that she has 'been reading Yeats new poems [The Wild Swans at Coole (1917)] with great pleasure. I think — for the first time — that he really is a poet' (L2 352, §. 1041). In December 1926, VW reads his Autobiographies: Reveries Over Childhood & The Trembling of the Veil (1911, 1922). Although she writes in her diary that 'some superstition prevents [her] from reading' it, she nonetheless describes it as a 'very good book — very close & measured speech' (D3 118 RN 25 102). They met (though not for the first time) on 7 November 1930 at Garsington. VW describes this meeting in her diary entry the next day and seems almost star-struck, describing him as 'very broad; very thick; like a solid piece of oak' with 'luminous, direct' eyes. Of note here is their discussion of poetry and its periodisation: Yeats argues that Milton's 'Latinised' poetry 'damaged the English language' and that 'the great age of poetry; Shakespeare's age, was subjective; ours is objective; civilisations end when they become objectified. Woolf is hugely impressed by 'this large actively minded immensely vitalised man. Wherever one cut him, with a little question, he poured, spouted fountains of ideas. And I was impressed by his directness, his terseness. No fluff & dreaminess.' (D3 329-30). She writes enthusiastically of this meeting to Vanessa Bell and to Ethel Smyth (L 4 250, §. 2274; 253, §. 2277). They meet again on 25 October 1934: he 'has been writing about [Woolf]. The Waves. That comes after Stendhal. I see what you're at — But I want more humanity' (D4 255). Her letter to Ethel Smyth dated 01 November 1934 ends 'Did I tell you I met Yeats, at Ottolines? And he said (this is my vanity) "I'm writing about The Waves; which...." Now I took that for a compliment, on the lips of our greatest living poet' (L5 343, §. 2946). LLVW contains seven volumes by Yeats, and the Hogarth Press published L. A. G. (Leonard Arthur George) Strong's A Letter to W. B. Yeats in 1932, as the sixth of their Hogarth Letters series.

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

bibl.title: The Ambassadors
bibl.author: James, Henry
bibl.note: Henry James's 1903 comedy details Lambert Strether's journey to Europe to bring the wayward Chad Newsome back to work at his family's business in Massachusetts. VW did not take notes on this work, nor is there a copy in LLVW. However, in a letter to Katherine Arnold-Forster (Ka Cox) sent 01 January 1920, she writes that she is planning to work on 'Henry James' letters [...] — unless someone else has done it for me.' She notes that she 'shan't be sorry since I'm stuck in the Ambassadors' (L2 411. §. 1107). Two years later, in 'On Re-reading Novels,' she writes that James 'surmounts in The Ambassadors problems which baffled [Samuel] Richardson in Clarissa' and that in James's novel 'there is not a hint of a yawn, not a sign of condescension' (E2 343, 344).

bibl.title: The Anatomy of Melancholy

The Anatomy of Melancholy, What it is: With all the Kinds, Causes, Symptomes, Prognostickes, and Several Cures of it. In Three Maine Partitions with their several Sections, Members, and Subsections. Philosophically, Medicinally, Historically, Opened and Cut Up
bibl.author: Burton, Robert
bibl.note: Robert Burton's encyclopaedic investigation into melancholy, published initially in 1621 and significantly expanded in subsequent editions. VW took notes on this compendious work in preparation for the 'Anon' drafts (cf. RN 16) but it is likely that she encountered the Anatomy far earlier. LLVW contains three editions of the text: a fourth edition dating from 1632, a 1676 edition presented to VW by her lifelong friend and possible lover Violet Dickinson (VW's inscription is dated Oct. 1902), the third a three-volume 1893 edition signed by Leonard Woolf. Burton's work holds a privileged place in Woolf's literary-historical narrative as a document of incipient modernity whose inwardness and involution brings the figure of the reader into focus and ends anonymity.

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

bibl.title: Antony and Cleopatra
The Tragedie of Antonie, and Cleopatra
bibl.author: Shakespeare, William
bibl.note:
Shakespeare's tragedy dramatises the deadly romance between Roman triumvir Mark Anthony and Cleopatra, queen of Egypt from 51-30 BCE, and the final days of Ptolemaic Egypt as it is conquered by Rome. Woolf cites both the play and the character of Cleopatra frequently in her novels and essays.
In MD, Antony and Cleopatra proves a formative experience for Septimus Warren Smith. He is taught literature by Isabel Pole, with whom he 'fall[s] in love.' She 'give[s] him a taste of Antony and Cleopatra and the rest' and 'lit in him such a fire that burns only once in a lifetime, without heat, flickering a red-gold flame infinitely ethereal and insubstantial over Miss Pole; Antony and Cleopatra; and the Waterloo Road' (MD 76). Septimus is reading the play on the day that MD is set, although with less satisfaction. As he opens the play, he thinks: 'That boy's business of the intoxication of language——Antony and Cleopatra——had shrivelled utterly' (79). In W, meanwhile, Neville cites both Shakespeare's play and The Waste Land simultaneously in saying 'here in a car comes Cleopatra, burning on her barge' (157). In Antony and Cleopatra, Enobarbarus describes how the 'barge [Cleopatra] sat in, like a burnished throne | Burned upon the water; its poop was beaten gold' (ii.II 201-2) while Eliot writes of '[t]he Chair she in, like a burnished throne | Glowed upon the marble' (Eliot 58 ll. 77-8). After the pageant in BA, Lucy Swithin seeks out La Trobe to congratulate her on the pageant. Swithin can only 'lay[] hold to a fraction of her meaning' but La Trobe interpolates: Swithin is trying to say 'I could have played... Cleopatra' and that she has 'stirred in me my unacted part' (110).
VW's 1916 essay 'Hours in a Library' describes the 'absolute certainty of delight which breathes through us when we come back to' works of literature: as well as works by Milton and Thomas Browne, the narrator cites Antony and Cleopatra (E2 60). The CR essay 'The Patron and the Crocus' uses the play as an exemplum of 'how much grammar Shakespeare violated' (E4 215). On Being Ill (1930) discusses the experience of reading 'in illness, with the police off duty.' The narrator speculates that 'the Chinese must know the sound of Antony and Cleopatra better than we do' (E5 202). In 'A Letter to a Young Poet' (1932), the narrator compares self-centred, inward-looking, modern poetry to past literature whose 'pages were crammed with characters of the most opposite and various kinds——Hamlet, Cleopatra, Falstaff" (E5 315). Woolf's essay on Ellen Terry (1941) concludes with the observation that other actors are 'remembered because they were Hamlet, Phèdre, or Cleopatra' but Terry is 'rembembered becassue she was Ellen Terry' (E6 290). In 'Craftsmanship' (1937), Woolf toys with the prospect of 'plays more splendid than Antony and Cleopatra' that lie waiting to be discovered in the dictionary (E6 626).
Meanwhile, the play is a key intertext for AROO. Cleopatra is listed among the 'women who have burnt like beacons in all the works of all the poets from the beginning of time' (39), part of a 'queer, composite being' who is at once '[i]maginatively of the highest importance' but 'in real life could hardly read, could scarcely spell, and was the property of her husband' (40). The narrator inquires about Shakespeare's 'state of mind [...] when he wrote Lear and Antony and Cleopatra' (46), and later answers her inquiry while looking at the playtext: 'the mind of an artist, in order to achieve the prodigious effort of freeing whole and entire the work that is in him, must be incandescent, like Shakespeare's mind' (51). Later in the essay, the narrator contemplates the phrase ' "Chloe liked Olivia"' and how 'immense a change' this phrase brings with it: 'Chloe liked Olivia perhaps for the first time in literature.' She compares this to Cleopatra, who 'did not like Octavia,' her rival for Antony's love. 'And how completely Antony and Cleopatra would have been altered,' the narrator continues 'had she done so!' (74). Throughout Room, Cleopatra comes to act as synecdoche for women in literary history.

analytic.title: A Letter to a Young Poet

series.title: The Cambridge edition of the works of Virginia Woolf
The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

bibl.title: Ballet Russes
bibl.note: The Ballet Russes, or Russian Ballet, was a ballet company led by Sergei Pablovich Diaghilev that frequently performed in London. LW writes in his autobiography that 'night after night we flocked to Covent Garden' in 1911, 'entranced by a new art, a revelation to us benighted British, the Russian Ballet in the greatest days of Diaghilev and Nijinsky' (Leonard Woolf in Hussey 244). Nadel (2018) provides a fuller account of the company's radically modern approach to dance, arguing that they 'radically broke with a Germanic orchestral tradition, causing writers to readjust their modernist values' (552).

monogr.title: Virginia Woolf A to Z: a comprehensive reference for students, teachers and common readers to her life, work and critical reception
Virginia Woolf A to Z

bibl.title: Broadcast
bibl.note: Shortwave radio became a viable communicative medium only in the 1920s but quickly became what Trotter (2013) calls 'the most momentuous of all new media, in economic, political, and military terms,' radically reconfiguring empire (14). In the metropole, the BBC was established in 1922: Avery (2009) traces Bloomsbury's rich involvement with the corporation. VW gave three broadcast talks. The first was a conversation with LW titled 'Are Too Many Books Written and Published' (1927, cf. E6 609-16); the second an essay on Beau Brummell (1929 cf. E6 618-24); and the last was 'Craftsmanship' (1937, cf. E6 624-7). In 'Poetry, Fiction, and the Future' (1927), modernity is figured as a 'long avenue of brick [...] cut up into boxes, each of which is inhabited by a different human being [...] yet is linked to his fellows by wires which pass overhead by waves of sound [...] which speak to him of battles and murders and strikes and revolutions all over the world' (E4 432-4), while in TG the 'wireless' forms part of a 'public psychometer' that the letter-writer urges her interlocutor to 'consult' (206). Its 'clamour' and 'uproar' transmits the profoundly antifeminist 'infantile fixation' across Britain and Europe, the voice of patriarchy giving way to 'no language but a cry, Ay, ay, ay, ay' (269). In 'Thoughts on Peace in an Air Raid' (1940) a verbal 'current flows fast and furious [issuing] in a spate of words from the loudspeakers,' and 'tell[ing] us that we are a free people, fighting to defend freedom' (E 243). Suffice it to say the narrator is not convinced of this.

analytic.title: Desmond MacCarthy, Bloomsbury, and the Aestheticist Ethics of Broadcasting

monogr.title: Literature in the first media age: Britain between the wars
Literature in the first media age

bibl.title: The Canterbury Tales
bibl.author: Chaucer, Geoffrey
bibl.note: Geoffrey Chaucer's unfinished compendium of fictive verse narratives, told by pilgrims journeying from Southwark to Canterbury to worship at the shrine of Thomas à Beckett. VW's most sustained engagement with this work is to be found in 'The Pastons and Chaucer,' written for CR1 (1925; E4 20-38), in which she read Chaucer's narrative(s) alongside the decidedly more everyday Paston Letters. She read and took notes for the Tales in 1924. Notes on 'The Nun's Priest's Tale' can be found in RN. 47, while she makes brief notes in most of the others in RN. 49. LLVW contains three editions of Chaucer's works. The pageant in BA features the Canterbury pilgrims, whose song (though interrupted by the wind) makes reference to their journey ' "[t]o the shrine of the Saint... to the tomb..."' (59).

series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

bibl.title: Cinema
bibl.note: Early cinema constitutes an important context for VW's writing and Bloomsbury aesthetics. The richest scholarly source on the cinema and early twentieth century British literature remains Laura Marcus's 2007 The Tenth Muse (cf. 99-189 especially). Marcus tracks VW's scattered corpus of writings on the medium and I do not intend to recapitulate this analysis, save to note that Woolf's most extensive critical engagement with early cinema is her 1926 essay 'The Cinema,' published initially in the New York magazine Arts (E4 348-54).

monogr.title: The tenth muse: writing about cinema in the modernist period

bibl.title: The Comedy of Errors
bibl.author: Shakespeare, William
bibl.note: Cf. William Shakespeare's farcical comedy of misrecognition dramatises the (mis)adventures of two sets of identical servants and masters, Antipholus and Dromio of Syracuse and Antipholus and Dromio of Ephesus. The play is thought to have been composed at some point between 1589 and the end of 1594, and certainly before its first recorded performance on 28 December 1594 (Foakes in Comedy xvii). LLVW does not contain a standalone copy of The Comedy of Errors, although the Woolfs did possess an Oxford Miniature Edition copy of Shakespeare's comedies and three of Shakespeare's complete works. If VW read this work, no trace of her reading survives, and she does not make explicit reference to the play in her writings.

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

series.title: The Arden Shakespeare

bibl.title: The Countess of Pembroke's Arcadia
bibl.author: Sidney, Sir Philip
bibl.note: A long prose pastoral romance (punctuated by songs) that Philip Sidney dedicated to his sister Mary Herbert Sidney, the Countess of Pembroke. The poem is extant in two variants. Sidney most likely started drafting the first, which became known as the Old Arcadia in 1577 and finished drafting it in 1580. This edition circulated in manuscript form, but was not published until Albert Feuillerat's 1912 edition. Sidney attempted to rewrite the Old Arcadia, starting between 1582 and 1584. He did not finish before his death in 1586 though posthumous editors filled in the gaps: these editions have come to be known as the New Arcadia (Evans in Sidney Arcadia 10-13). LLVW contains two editions of The Countess of Pembroke's Arcadia: a tenth edition from 1655 and an eleventh edition from 1662. VW took notes on the former of these editions in preparation for her CR2 essay 'The Countess of Pembroke's Arcadia' (RN 8; E5 366-76). While this does not preclude Woolf having read the Feuillerat Old Arcadia it seems highly probable that she refers exclusively to the later set of variants when she discusses the Arcadia. In her CR2 essay, she writes that 'in the Arcadia, as in some luminous globe, all the seeds of English fiction lie latent. We can trace infinite possibilities: it may take one of many different directions' (E5 373). She quotes from the Arcadia in the opening of F: 'That there was an aristocracy of dogs by the time Queen Elizabeth was on the throne Sir Philip Sidney bears witness '... greyhounds, Spaniels and Hounds', he observes, 'where-of the first might seem the Lords, the second the Gentlemen, and the last the Yeomen of dogs', he writes in the Arcadia' (7).

bibl.title: The Defence of Poesie
bibl.author: Sidney, Sir Philip
bibl.note: Philip Sidney did not title his long essay on poetry. It was published posthumously in 1595 in two separate editions, one known as An Apology for Poetry and the other as The Defense of Poesy (Maslen in Sidney Apology 1, n. 1): the edition that VW reads and takes notes on in preparation for CR1 calls it The Defence of Poesie (Sidney 'Defence' [1655 ed.] 540; cf. RN 47). Particularly relevant to Woolf's argument in the 'Anon' fragments is Sidney's lengthy digression in which he takes the time to 'inquire why England (the mother of excellent minds) should be grown so hard a stepmother to poets' (Sidney Apology 108): VW often notes that, during the period that her Common History drafts cover, examples of literary writing in English are relatively thin on the ground. In the CR1 essay 'The Elizabethan Lumber Room,' VW compares Sidney's prose style in the Defence with that of Michel de Montaigne' s Essais, demonstrating '[h]ow little Elizabethan prose was fit for its office, how exquisitely French prose was already adapted' (E4 56). Sidney's writing is 'an uninterrupted monologue [which] is never quick, never colloquial, unable to grasp a thought closely and firmly, or to adapt itself flexibly to the chops and changes of the mind,' whereas Montaigne 'is master of an instrument which knows its own powers and limitations, and is capable of insinuating itself into crannies and crevices which poetry can never reach; capable of cadences different but no less beautiful; of subtleties and intensities which Elizabethan prose entirely ignores' (57). She concludes that '[a]n age seems to separate Sidney from Montaigne. The English compared with the French are as boys compared with men' but that nevertheless the 'Elizabethan prose writers, if they have the formlessness of youth, have, too its freshness and audacity' which is most fully expressed in comic prose written for the stage (57).

monogr.title: An apology for poetry, or, The defence of poesy

imprint.publisher: Manchester University Press ; Distributed exclusively in the USA by Palgrave

bibl.title: Harrison's Description of England in Shakspere's Youth
Harrison's Description of England in Shakespere's youth: Being the second and third books of his Description of Britaine and England
bibl.author: Harrison, William
bibl.note: William Harrison' s Description was initially published as part of Raphael Holinshed's Chronicles (first ed. 1577, second ed. 1587), but VW encountered it as a standalone three-volume edition published 1877-18 for the New Shakespere Society, edited by Frederick Furnivall. LLVW contains the first and second volumes of this edition with VW's bookplate. Harrison vividly depicts recent and contemporary Elizabethan England, and Woolf uses his writing as a major source for her descriptions of changes in English society at this period, and as a contemporary source on the theatre and playhouses. She makes three sets of notes on it: the first in preparation for CR1. In this set of notes she focuses on changing dietary habits as an index for broader social change (RN 19). She revisits Harrison in preparation for the 'Anon' drafts: in RN 21 she focuses on Furnivall's introduction to the first volume, and his biography of Harrison (RN 21). Her final set of notes are more general in character, covering arms and armaments, historic ballads, inns and more (cf. RN 37).

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

bibl.title: Elizabeth and Essex
Elizabeth and Essex: A Tragic History
bibl.author: Strachey, Lytton
bibl.note: A reference to Lytton Strachey's 1928 dual biography of Elizabeth I and Robert Devereux, second earl of Essex, an erstwhile favourite of Elizabeth who led an attempted coup against her in 1601. VW was not a fan, calling it a 'lively superficial meretricious book' in her diary entry of 28 November 1928 (D3 208). She discussesd broaching the subject with Strachey in a diary entry of 15 June 1929, six months after the publication of Elizabeth and Essex. It is a 'painful' conversation but 'we were glad to say it, & have this reserve over.' She describes Strachey's 'suppression of irony; his being tied by the story; the difficulty of using reality imaginatively; a wrong subject for him [which] could only be treated imaginatively' (233-4). In 'The Art of Biography' (1939), she writes that despite its 'failure,' Strachey's work was the 'result of a daring experiment carried out with magnificent skill, lead[ing] the way to further discoveries' (E6 185).

monogr.title: Elizabeth and Essex: A Tragic History

bibl.title: Everyman
The Summoning of Everyman
bibl.author: Anonymous
bibl.note: An anonymous early English morality play, probably based on the Dutch play Elckerlyc (Everybody). The play is a religious allegory, its characters given demonstrative names such as Death, Good Deeds, Knowledge, and, indeed, Everyman. It is explicitly pedagogical: the incipit of the first print edition calls it a 'treatise how the High Father of heaven sendeth Death to summon every creature to come and give account of their life in this world, and is in the manner of a moral play' (Everyman 181, 0.1). The moral play dramatises the titular Everyman's journey to the grave: in the play's opening lines, God sends Death to Everyman. In the play's first half, Everyman is deserted by Fellowship, Kindred, and Goods; they cannot prevent his end, but they encounter Good Deeds. Good Deeds lies paralysed on the floor but nonetheless sends Knowledge to 'go with thee and be thy guide | In thy most need to go by thy side' (ll. 522-3). Knowledge leads Everyman to Confession, and they revive Good Deeds. His soul saved, Everyman goes to his grave willingly. The play received its first attested performance in 1901 and this performance 'opened the floodgates to its modern popularity' (Bruster and Ramussen in Everyman 67).

series.title: Arden early modern drama

bibl.title: The Faery Queen
bibl.author: Spenser, Edmund
bibl.note: Edmund Spenser's allegorical epic poem in eight cantos. Spenser dedicated the poem to Elizabeth I, and identifies her with the characters of Gloriana and Belphoebe. VW first takes notes on the poem in the early months of 1935, from 20 Jan to 11 March (cf. RN 47), and in the same year writes an essay counselling that 'the first essential' to prepare oneself to read The Faery Queen is 'of course not to read The Faery Queen. Put it off for as long as possible' and immerse oneself in the prosaic. Only when 'the whole being is red and brittle as sandstone in the sun' should one 'make a dash for' the poem (E6 487). In analysis that anticipates that of the 'Anon' drafts, VW writes in her 1935 essay that the poem's difficulties lie not in its archaisms ('it is easier to read Spenser than to read William Morris') but 'elsewhere,' 'in the fact that the poem is a mediation not a dramatisation' and that 'we are confined in one continuous consciousness, which is Spenser's' (490). This essay was not published during Woolf's lifetime, and was first printed Mom (1947). Woolf takes further notes on the poem in her 'Reading at Random' notebook (RN 37, 1940-1). A copy of the poem is among the books in Jacob's Cambridge room, alongside 'all the Elizabethans' (JR 60)

series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

bibl.title: Doctor Faustus
The Tragical History of the Life and Death of Doctor Faustus
bibl.author: Marlowe, Christopher
bibl.note: Probably the last play Christopher Marlowe wrote before his death. Woolf read the play at least twice: she writes in a letter to Thoby Stephen dated 1901 that she has been reading Marlowe and 'was much more impressed by him than I thought I should be.' She had read 'Dr Faustus, and Edward II' and thought Marlowe's characters were drawn 'with more humanity' than those of the 'great man' Shakespeare, whom Thoby idolised (L1 45-6, §. 39). Her youthful enthusiasm for the play evidently faded by the time she came to take notes on the play twenty-two years later, in August 1923. She writes that Faustus is a 'very poor play compared with the two Tamburlaines' calling it 'short, scrappy cut up [...] far less rich & harmonious than the other two' (RN 25). In her diary entry for 25 December 1931 she writes of reading 'Faust' but it is not clear whether she refers to Marlowe's play or Goethe's (1808; 1832), a German-language copy of which is in LLVW with Leonard Woolf's signature.

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

bibl.title: Fidelio
Leonore, oder Der Triumph der ehelichen Liebe
bibl.author: Beethoven, Ludwig van
bibl.note: The only opera by Ludwig Van Beethoven. The opera's hero, Leonore, disguises herself as a boy named Fidelio to free her husband from death in a political prison. In a May 1934 letter addressed to Ethel Smyth, VW complains that her plans to see Fidelio were derailed by '[t]his d––––d influenza' (L 5 302-3, no. 2891).

bibl.title: Gammer Gurton's Needle
A Ryght Pithy, Pleasaunt and merrie Comedie: Intytuled Gammer gurtons Nedle played on stage, not longe a go in Christes Colledge in Cambridge
bibl.author: Anonymous
bibl.note: The authorship and composition date of Gammer Gurton's Needle are both unknown, though the earliest edition of the play dates from 1575: its title page attests that it was 'played on stage not longe a goe' in Cambridge (Gammer Gurton fol. 1r). The play's plot is simple: Gammer Gurton is at work patching her servant's breeches and chaos erupts when she loses her needle. In BA, Lucy Swithin says that the villagers performed Gammer Gurton's Needle one year (43). Hussey notes that Angelica Bell acted in a touring production of the play in 1938, which VW saw on 13 August (Hussey in BA 188).
