series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

bibl.title: The Garden
bibl.author: Marvell, Andrew
bibl.note:
argh there is another layer of quotation here - it is Bacon (Of Great Place and Of Masques and Triumphs) citing Marvell perhaps...
A reference to Andrew Marvell's pastoral English poem 'The Garden,' published initially in 1681. The poem celebrates the retreat from society into 'delicious solitude' (Marvell 49, l. 16), and the pleasures both of nature and of the vita contemplativa. The stanza Woolf cites reads in full:
Mean while the Mind, from pleasure less, Withdraws into its happiness: The Mind, that Ocean where each kind Does streight its own resemblance find; Yet it creates, transcending these, Far other Worlds, and other Seas; Annihilating all that's made To a green Thought in a green Shade. (50, ll. 41-8)
LLVW contains four editions of Andrew Marvell's verse, and, in Y, North Pargiter begins to quote from 'The Garden' to his cousin Sara before he is interrupted by the sound of Abrahamson, the 'Jew having a bath [...] coughing and clearing his throat as he sponged' (Y 306, cf. also Linett on Woolf's citation of Marvell).

series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

bibl.title: Ghosts: A Domestic Drama in Three Acts
Gengangere
bibl.author: Ibsen, Henrik
bibl.note: Ibsen's 1881 drama Gegangere, (lit. 'those who return' but most commonly translated into English as Ghosts) is a controversial play whose subject matter was, at the time, shocking: it deals with incest, syphilis, and euthanasia. Woolf uses it as a point of comparison between early modern English drama and contemporary drama: she posits that the audience in the Jacobean playhouse must have felt emotions akin to those provoked by Ibsen's play. These feelings were strong: Ibsen's translator William Archer compiled press notices of the first English performance in 1891 into an article called 'Ghosts and Gibberings.' The first, a leader from the Telegraph calls it an ' "open drain; a loathsome sore unbandaged [...] Literary carrion... Crapulous stuff",' and the others that Archer cites are similar (Archer 3). Its initial reception has not stopped the play from being produced many times since then. LLVW contains a twelve-volume edition of Ibsen's works which includes Ghosts: Woolf could have read of the play's early reception in Scandinavian theatres in Archer's introduction to the play (Archer in Ibsen xx-xxiii).

monogr.title: The Collected Works of Henrik Ibsen
The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

bibl.title: The Golden Bowl
bibl.author: James, Henry
bibl.note: VW's review of this Henry James novel was published in the Guardian on 22 February, 1905, was one of her first publications. She reports receiving the book in her diary entry for 7 February of that year (PA 233), noting two days later that it is 'very closely packed with words – 550 pages of small print. Henry James print too, wh. I am to boil into 7 or 800 words' (234-5). Evidently, she did not boil enough as on 15 February she reports receiving a letter from her editor 'enclosing that wretched review, & asking me to cut it down, & send it back as soon as possible. So I set to work with scissors & somehow patched it together' (237). Her notes for this review are extant (cf. RN 35). In her review, she damns with faint praise, likening James to 'an artist who, with a sure sense of anatomy, paints every bone and muscle in the human frame; the portrait would be greater as a work of art if he were content to say less and suggest more' (E1 23). She mentions the novel infrequently after 1905: in 'Is Fiction an Art?' (1927), VW's review of Aspects of the Novel by E.M. Forster, Woolf critiques Forster's 'notably harsh judgment' of James, asking 'Why, if we get a keen and genuine pleasure from the pattern of The Golden Bowl, is it less valuable than the emotion which Trollope gives us when he describes a lady drinking tea in a parsonage?' (E4 461), while in 'On Being Ill' (1930), she says that this is not a 'book for influenza' (E5 201) LLVW contains a 1905 first British edition of James's novel, presumably the copy which VW received to review.

Passionate Apprentice

bibl.title: Hamlet
The Tragicall Historie of HAMLET, Prince of Denmarke
bibl.author: Shakespeare, William
bibl.note: A tragedy by William Shakespeare which dramatises titular prince of Denmark's halting quest for revenge against Claudius for the murder of his father. Woolf reads and returns to Hamlet throughout her life. VW begins reading this play as early as 1909 alongside other four other tragedies: Romeo and Juliet, King Lear, Othello and Macbeth, supplemented with A.C. Bradley's Shakespearean Tragedy (cf. RN 29), although this was not her first encounter with the text: in 'Sketch' she recalls reading the play aloud to Julia Stephen at some point before her death in 1895 (MoB 96) and her diary entry for 12 November 1897 is simply 'Hamlet' (PA 133). In her 1916 essay 'Charlotte Brontë' she writes that '[t]o write down one's impressions of Hamlet as one reads it year after year, would be virtually to record one's own autobiography, for as we know more of life, so Shakespeare comments upon what we know' (E2 27). The play spurs VW's mature insight that 'we are the words; we are the music; we are the thing itself': in 'Sketch' she cites Hamlet as part of the 'truth about this vast mass that we call the world' (MoB 81). VW's deep and lifelong engagement with Hamlet is too complex to fully describe here: Fox's 1990 account remains authoritative (94-158 cf. especially 103-108). In addition to editions of the play in four sets of collected works, LLVW contains a standalone edition of the play and an 1860 dual facing-page facsimile that displays both 1603 (Q1, sometimes referred to as the 'Bad Quarto'), and the 1604 (Q2) variants.

monogr.title: Virginia Woolf and the literature of the English Renaissance
The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog
A Passionate Apprentice: The Early Journals
Passionate Apprentice

bibl.title: Heart of Darkness
bibl.author: Conrad, Joseph
bibl.note: Woolf makes a passing reference to Joseph Conrad's novella 'Heart of Darkness' here. Conrad's novel was initially serialised in Blackwood's Edinburgh Magazine in 1899 and published by Blackwood in 1802 as part of the volume Youth: A Narrative and Two Other Stories". Woolf reviews the 1917 J.M. Dent reissue of this volume for TLS (E2 158-60), and mentions 'Heart of Darkness' in her 1917 review of Lord Jim (E2 141).LLVW does not contain a standalone copy of the Blackwood volume but it does have a later version collected as part of the 22-volume collected works published by J.M. Dent (1923-28). Woolf reviewed the first tranche of this edition in 1923 for Nation & Athenaeum: her essay, 'Mr Conrad: A Conversation' does not discuss 'Heart of Darkness' specifically, but the conversationalists do discuss Marlow, the narrator of many of Conrad's stories including 'Heart of Darkness' (E3 377-8). Similarly, VW's 1924 obituary of Conrad for TLS (collected in CR1, 1925) does not cite 'Heart of Darkness' but does discuss Marlow (E4 231).

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

bibl.title: Henry V
bibl.author: Shakespeare, William
bibl.note: The conclusion of William Shakespeare's second tetralogy of history plays, and depicts Prince Hal's accession to the throne as Henry V, and his victory at the Battle of Agincourt. Shakespeare most likely used Raphael Holinshed's Chronicles as a source text for this play, and its composition can be precisely dated due to a reference to Robert Devereux, Earl of Essex, and his 1601 attempted coup against Elizabeth I (Hen5 5.31-4; Lytton Strachey's 1928 twin biography, Elizabeth and Essex: A Tragic History discusses this coup). In VO, Henry V is the favourite play of both Mr Grice and Clarissa Dalloway (55). Fox writes of this scene that 'the chauvinism and bellicosity of the play would seem to have alienated Woolf to such an extent that she uses a preference for it to satirize' the two (128).

monogr.title: Virginia Woolf and the literature of the English Renaissance
Elizabeth and Essex: A Tragic History

series.title: The Arden Shakespeare. Third series

bibl.title: Henry VI
bibl.author: Shakespeare, William
bibl.note: Shakespeare's three-part history play forms the bulk of Shakespeare's early first tetralogy of history plays (though VW's sole reference to the plays, in M111, Set 2 of 3 [The Reader: Anonymity was a great possession], is to 'Henry the Sixth' singular). The plays dramatise the tumultuous reign of King Henry VI and the early days of the War of the Roses. If VW read or saw any of these plays, no trace of her having done so remains extant.

bibl.title: History of England
bibl.author: Trevelyan, G.M. [George Macaulay]
bibl.note: A 1926 work by historian George Macaulay Trevelyan. VW took notes on this in 1940 in preparation for the 'Anon' drafts: the edition in LLVW also contains LW's annotations. Trevelyan's narrative stretches from prehistoric Britain to the death of Queen Victoria, though Woolf's notes peter out after the Stuarts. The ecological fantasia that opens many of the 'Anon' fragments, where early human music is prefigured by birdsong, draws inspiration from and cites the opening of Trevelyan's history (cf. Trevelyan 3). She also makes notes on the lack of literacy among the ruling classes of early England, and the subsequent development of bardic culture and the impact that this had upon the medieval sensorium: 'The form and colour of things seen and the sound of fine words were a greater part of the pleasures of that simple age than in our own more intellectual world' (86); on the impact that the Norman conquest had on the formation of the English language (131-2); and the 'growth of a leisured class' (146). Her notes then skip ahead by several hundred pages and several hundred years to Trevelyan's discussion of the influence of the Bible and of music on English art (367).

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

bibl.title: Holinshed's Chronicles
The Chronicles of England, Scotlande and Irelande
bibl.author: Holinshed, Raphael
bibl.note: Raphael Holinshed's Chronicles were part of a project commissioned by printer Reyner Wolfe to create a ' "universal cosmographie"' which would cover every part of the globe (Clegg n.p.). Wolfe's ambitious project did not see completion, but Holinshed did publish the vast, collaborative Chronicles of England, Scotlande and Irelande as part of this. The first edition of the Chronicles was published in 1577 in two volumes, and a substantially expanded, three volume edition followed a decade later. It was a source for contemporary writers including Marlowe, Shakespeare, Spenser. While VW read William Harrison's Description of England, which was part of the Chronicles, she read Harrison in a separate edition and there is no evidence to suggest that she had read Holinshed's broader project.

bibl.title: King John
The Life and Death of King John
bibl.author: Shakespeare, William
bibl.note: Though one of his least-known plays now, King John has the distinction of being the first of Shakespeare's plays to be filmed (Lander and Tobin 1). The play depicts the dynastic conflict that followed King John's excommunication by the papacy. VW read the play in August 1924: she writes in her diary entry of 15 Aug that it 'lights me as I walk to think I have 2 acts of King John tonight, & shall next read Richard the 2nd' (D2 310, cf. also RN 47).

series.title: The Arden Shakespeare

bibl.title: King Lear
The tragedie of King Lear
bibl.author: Shakespeare, William
bibl.note: Tragedy by William Shakespeare that sees the aging Lear divide up his kingdom among his three daughters, Regan, Goneril, and Cordelia: they must each swear that they love him in order to inherit. Regan and Goneril extravagantly pledge their love; Cordelia can say nothing and 'nothing will come of nothing' (1.1.90). VW begins reading this play as early as 1909 alongside other four other tragedies: Romeo and Juliet, Hamlet, Othello and Macbeth, supplemented with A.C. Bradley's Shakespearean Tragedy. Fox argues that at this point Woolf identified Lear with her father Leslie Stephen (108-9). Certainly, her early reading of the play is autobiographical: her notes begin with the observation that 'One feels Lear has always been stormy. His daughters have suffered from it,' but it is also somewhat broader: her notes end with the observation that 'all human kind [is] exposed on the heath' (RN 29, at back 8-9). In the TLS review 'Men and Women' (1920), VW writes that it is 'becoming daily more evident that Lady Macbeth, Cordelia, Ophelia [...] and the rest are by no means what they pretend to be' (E3 193). The CR1 essay 'On Not Knowing Greek' (1925) the narrator writes of reading Lear as a process of 'stripping the branch of its flowers instantly' (E4 48). In On Being Ill (1930), illness causes the brain's 'barriers [to] go down' and 'the brain rings and resounds with Lear or Macbeth' (E5 202). In the CR2 essay 'How Should One Read a Book' (1932), the question 'is Hamlet a better play than Lear is left up to the reader, not 'authorities [...] heavily furred and gowned' to answer (E5 573). Fox writes of Bernard's continual citation of the play in W (Fox 135-6), and of references to the play in BA (Fox 155-6).

monogr.title: Virginia Woolf and the literature of the English Renaissance

series.title: The Arden Shakespeare

analytic.title: How Should One Read a Book?

bibl.title: Le Morte Darthur
The hoole booke of kyng Arthur & of his noble knyghtes of the rounde table
bibl.author: Malory, Sir Thomas
bibl.note: Le Morte Dartur is a middle English prose narrative retelling of earlier Arthurian legend: its (putative) author, Thomas Malory translated and reworked French stories of Arthur and his retinue, the knights of the Round Table, moulding them into what he called a 'hoole booke.' Malory's work was printed by William Caxton in 1485: an earlier manuscript of Malory's work was discovered at Winchester College in 1934 which made apparent the extent to which Caxton revised Malory's text. Though Arthurian mythology is vast and diffuse, VW consistently uses this work as her source. LLVW contains two editions of Malory's work, including an 1899 edition by Edward Strachey, from which Woolf quotes herein. Strachey modernises and regularises Caxton's text, presenting an edition 'for ordinary readers, and especially for boys, from whom the chief demand for this book will always come' (Strachey in Malory xvii). Evidently LW was one of the boys Strachey's introduction gestures towards: the copy of the book in LLVW bears his inscription.

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog
Le morte Darthur: Sir Thomas Malory's book of King Arthur and of his noble knights of the round table.: The text of Caxton
The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

bibl.title: The Lord's Prayer
bibl.author: Wycliffe, John (translator)
Tyndale, William (translator)
bibl.note: Fundamental part of the Christian liturgy in various languages. VW read and took notes on Latimer's seven sermons on this prayer, in the first of which he calls it a 'prayer above all prayers, the principall and most perfect prayer' (Latimer 121). Each of these sermons ends with a recitation of the prayer in English.

bibl.title: Macbeth
The Tragedie of Macbeth
bibl.author: Shakespeare, William
bibl.note: William Shakespeare's tragedy of witchcraft, regicide, and revenge, colloquially referred to as the Scottish Play. VW begins reading this play as early as 1909 alongside other four other tragedies: Romeo and Juliet, Hamlet, Othello and King Lear, supplemented with A.C. Bradley's Shakespearean Tragedy, though she 'hesitate[d] to write of this play,' having 'read it in the train, wedged between Germans, by the light of sunset in Switzerland' (RN 29 12). Written in the wake of a disastrous trip to Europe with Vanessa and Clive Bell, VW's 1909 notes pay close attention to Macbeth and Lady Macbeth's relationship (cf. Fox 101). In the TLS review 'Men and Women' (1920), VW writes that it is 'becoming daily more evident that Lady Macbeth, Cordelia, Ophelia [...] and the rest are by no means what they pretend to be' (E3 193), while in Room, Lady Macbeth is listed among the 'women who have burnt like beacons in all the works of all the poets from the beginning of time' (39). In On Being Ill (1930), illness causes the brain's 'barriers [to] go down' and 'the brain rings and resounds with Lear or Macbeth' (E5 202). In 'Ellen Terry' (1941), VW writes of John Singer Sargent's painting of Terry 'robed and crowned as Lady Macbeth' (E6 288). Jacob Flanders (mis)quotes Macbeth's insult, saying 'The devil damn you black, you cream-faced loon!' The precise quotation is 'The devil damn thee black, thou cream-faced loon.' (205; cf. Mac. 5.3.11).

monogr.title: Virginia Woolf and the literature of the English Renaissance

series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

monogr.title: A Room of One's Own and Three Guineas

bibl.title: The Mad Lover
bibl.author: Fletcher, John
bibl.note: A tragicomedy in blank verse by playwright John Fletcher. Though the text of the play was published in the first Beaumont and Fletcher folio in 1647, after Fletcher's death in 1625, Anne Clifford writes in her diary of seeing it as early as 2nd January 1617 (47). Fletcher's plot is simple, and to some extent given away by the title: Memnon, a victorious general and the titular mad lover of the play, is driven 'starke mad' (Fletcher 1.2.110) over love of Calis, the king's sister.

monogr.title: The Diary of the Lady Anne Clifford: With an Introductory Note by V. Sackville-West
The dramatic works in the Beaumont and Fletcher canon

bibl.title: The Magic Flute
Die Zauberflöte
bibl.author: Mozart, Wolfgang Amadeus
bibl.note: Mozart's final opera, which premiered only two months before his death in December 1791. In Virginia Woolf and the Languages of Patriarchy, Jane Marcus suggests VW composed ND as a 'modern Magic Flute (Marcus 20), while in the same novel William Rodney 'pick[s] out the melodies in "The Magic Flute" upon the piano' while waiting for Katharine Hilbery (ND 295). In 'The Modern Essay,' published initially as 'Modern Essays' in TLS on 30 November 1922 and revised for inclusion in CR1, VW gestures to Mozart's opera. She writes that the modern essay is shorter in length than its forebears but it has 'brought about a corresponding expansion of individuality. We no longer have the "I" of Max [Beerbohm] or [Walter] Lamb, but the "we" of public bodies and other sublime personages. It is "we" who go to hear the Magic Flute; "we" who ought to profit by it; "we," in some mysterious way, who, in our corporate capacity, once upon a time actually wrote it' (E4 223).

monogr.title: Virginia Woolf and the languages of patriarchy

series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

bibl.title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
bibl.author: Shakespeare, William
bibl.note: A fantastical and explicitly metatheatrical comedy by William Shakespeare, probably composed 1595-6. VW read this play once: in a letter to Julian Bell dated 2 May 1936 she tells her nephew that she read it the previous night, commenting 'Well there you have it — all England, all May in a song or two' (L6 33, §. 3126). If she made notes while reading, none survive, and she only mentions it once by name in her fiction and essays, and very rarely uses its characters' names: in O, the young Orlando writes a piece called 'The Birth of Pyramus' (71). In a letter sent to Quentin Bell on June 8 1930, she tells her nephew that '[t]omorrow there is a village festival [in Rodmell] — our cook dances on the lawn — they act Midsummer Nights Dream and I am to guess the weight of a cake' (L4 176, §. 2189). This, perhaps, finds its way in the 1911 chapter of Y, in which Celia tells Eleanor Pargiter that she has seen a ' "scene from Shakespeare"' but cannot remember which play: ' "Midsummer-Night? As You Like It? I forget which."' (177). In early April 1937 she sees her niece Angelica Bell play the fairy Ariel in a production of the play at Sadler's Well theatre, Islington, London, and writes of it to Janet Case (cf. L6 118, §. 3233). Claudia Olk argues that A Midsummer Night's Dream's double plot, one of which is metatheatrical, provides a 'conceptual model for Woolf's double plot' in BA (117).

analytic.title: Virginia Woolf's 'Elizabethan Play': Between the Acts and A Midsummer Night's Dream

series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf
The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

bibl.title: London
Norden's Map
bibl.author: Norden, John
bibl.note: A map of the city of London, Westminster, and Southwark initially printed in 1593. VW is most likely to have encountered it in her reprint of William Harrison's Description of England, included by the editor as contextual material.

monogr.title: Harrison's Description of England in Shakespere's youth: Being the second and third books of his Description of Britaine and England

series.title: Publisht for the New Shakspere Society

bibl.title: Of Maskes and Triumphs
bibl.author: Bacon, Francis
bibl.note: One of the essays published in Francis Bacon's 1625 Essayes or Counsels, Civill and Morall. Bacon puts on an air of reluctance, seemingly unwilling to discuss the 'Toyes' that 'come amongst such Serious Observations' discussed in his other essays. Nevertheless, 'since Princes will have such things,' needs must discuss them. He does so with relish, describing acting, music, colour, even odour, and things that give '[g]reat Pleasure; and Refreshment.' Such a list might stretch beyond the bounds of Bacon's usually terse essays, but he breaks off from his enumeration with a rhetorical flourish: 'But enough of these toyes' (117-8).

monogr.title: The Essayes or Counsels, Civill and Morall

series.title: The Oxford Francis Bacon

bibl.title: The Outline of History
The Outline of History: Being a Plain History of Life and Mankind
bibl.author: Wells, H. G.
bibl.note: A work of universal history written by H.G. Wells, read in BA by Lucy Swithin. Wells' narrative stretched from the earth's beginnings and the 'very oldest rocks' (Wells 5), through the fossil record to prehistoric humans and the emergence of agriculture, Bronze and Iron age civilisations (with a focus on the ancient Near East) through to what he calls 'the world tragedy of 1914' (565) and the 'failure to produce a more satisfactory world settlement' in the wake of the First World War (594). It concludes by looking to a quasi-messianic future 'Federal World State': Wells writes that this is 'our true State, this state that is already beginning, must be now this nascent Federal World State to which human necessities point' (601). He looks to a 'moral and intellectual revival, a religious revival [...] stripped of corruptions and freed from its last priestly entanglements' (602) and argues that his 'new telling and [...] common interpretation of history' (603) is a necessary part of the revival that will lead to his global utopian world state. The Woolfs owned a 1920 edition of Wells' Outline, presented to Leonard Woolf by Wells. This volume is among the 130 books belonging to the Woolfs collected in HRC rather than LLVW.

monogr.title: The outline of history: being a plain history of life and mankind
monogr.edition: Revised and corrected edition (with several new maps and diagrams)

series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

bibl.title: Paston Letters
bibl.author: Various members of the Paston family and correspondents
bibl.note: A compendium of personal letters sent by members of the Paston family in the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries, which speak to the daily life of a Norfolk family that had 'risen in the world' (E4 21). VW reads these in preparation for her CR1 essay 'The Pastons and Chaucer' (1925; E 21-38) and notes can be found on them in RN 47, 59. LLVW contains a two-volume 1924 edition of the letters, though VW also took notes from an 1872-5 three-volume edition.

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

bibl.title: The Revenger's Tragedy
bibl.author: Middleton, Thomas
bibl.note: An extravagantly gory satire that recapitulates a great many tropes and figurations common to the revenge tragedy genre. Written for the King's Men in 1606 (Jackson in Middleton i.544), published anonymously in 1607-8 and mistakenly ascribed to Cyril Tourneur but now credited to Thomas Middleton (i.546). The play opens with Vindice holding the skull of Gloriana, his 'poisoned love' (I.i, l. 14) and swearing to 'give Revenge her due' (I.i l. 43) by exacting vengeance on her murderer, the Duke. Also plotting revenge and jostling for position at court are Duke's sons, Lussurio and the illegitimate Spurio; his wife the Duchess and his stepsons Ambitioso, Supervacuo and Junior join the fun. Vindice has his revenge when he disguises himself as Piato, a 'pander' or pimp, and is hired by the Duke to 'greet him with a lady | In some fit place veiled from the eyes o'th' court' (3.4.11-12). The lady in question is the skull of Gloriana, dressed in a wig and dress, its mouth smeared with poison. The Duke kisses Gloriana's skull and dies a painful death as the poison eats at his teeth and tongue. Some time later Vindice attempts to frame the Duke's sons and stepsons at a masque held at the new Duke Lussurio's court, which sees Lussurio murdered: in a frenzy the other sons kill one another. In the play's very final moments, Vindice is found to have engineered everything, but he accepts his death, asking 'are we not revenged? Is there one enemy left alive among those' (5.3.107-8). In M1-8, 5 of 10. The Reader, Woolf highlights an 'extraordinary intensification' that 'comes fitfully' to the Jacobean stage: The Revenger's Tragedy is nothing if not intense in the single-mindedness of its satire and, of course, its sheer and unstinting violence. VW's 1916 essay 'Hours in a Library' lists The Revenger's Tragedy among the 'list of books that someone read in a past January at the age of twenty' (E2 56).

bibl.title: Romeo and Juliet
The Tragedie of Romeo and Ivliet
bibl.author: Shakespeare, William
bibl.note: Cf. William Shakespeare's tragic tale of two star-crossed lovers. VW begins reading this play as early as 1909 alongside other four other tragedies: King Lear, Hamlet, Othello and Macbeth, supplemented with A.C. Bradley's Shakespearean Tragedy. She was not impressed, writing 'Who shall say anything of Romeo & Juliet? Do I dare? — in private: it seems to me immature work' and that the titular lovers 'have very little that is individual' in their relationship with one another. However, she expresses a preference for the Nurse and Old Capulet (RN 29 3). VW's assessment of the play remains, as Fox describes it, relatively stable (101). She begins to take notes on the play again in preparation for CR1 but only writes 'There is of course perfect character drawing in Capulet & the old nurse,' and copies out a quotation from Old Capulet (RN 47). In the CR1 essay 'The Pastons and Chaucer' (1925), Woolf writes of a 'certain kind of humour [which] depends upon being able to speak without self-consciousness of the parts and functions of the body' and which is expressed through characters such as the Wife of Bath, or Juliet's nurse (E4 29). In ND, Mrs Hilbery suggests that her daughter Katharine has a 'dash of the old nurse in [her]' (323).

monogr.title: Virginia Woolf and the literature of the English Renaissance

series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

bibl.title: The Shepheardes Calendar
bibl.author: Spenser, Edmund
bibl.note: Edmund Spenser's first major poem is a Virgilian pastoral whose twelve eclogues (one for each month) depict Colin Clout, the titular shepherd, and his life. Spenser dedicated it to his patron Philip Sidney. Woolf takes brief notes on the poem in RN 25, p. 54 (likely 1926-7).

bibl.title: The Spanish Tragedy
The Spanish Tragedie: Or, Hieronimo is mad againe
bibl.author: Kyd, Thomas
bibl.note: Jacobean drama written in the late 16th century by Thomas Kyd, though only attributed to him after his death and considered anonymous until 1773. The play was most likely composed after the Battle of Terceira on the 26th July 1582 (Calvo and Tronch in Kyd 13) and certainly before the 23rd February 1592 performance by the Lord Strangers' Men that Philip Henslowe records in his diary, though he calls it 'spanes comodye donne oracoe' [Spanish Comedy of Don Horatio] (Henslowe i.13). Though no record of its first performance survives, it was nonetheless 'one of the first and longest-lasting Renaissance box-office hits' (Calvo and Tronch in Kyd 1), and Kyd's play revitalises Senecan tragedy for the English stage and originates the revenge tragedy genre. The play narrates Hieronimo's elaborate quest for revenge over the murder of his son. Hieronimo's desire for revenge drives him mad, leading him to stage a play within a play that sees him kill his son's two murderers before biting out his own tongue and killing both the Duke of Castille and himself. The play was enormously influential on the Jacobean and Elizabethan stage, providing a theatrical lexis that would be deployed by playwrights includng, inter alia, Shakespeare (cf. Titus Andronicus, Hamlet) and Thomas Middleton (cf. The Revenger's Tragedy). Cf. White (307-10) for a reconstruction of the play's first performances at the Rose playhouse. The Woolfs had a standalone 1898 edition of this play in library, published as part of the Temple Dramatists series (cf. LLVW). VW made notes on this edition in preparation for CR1 (cf. RN9, 25).

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

series.title: Arden early modern drama

monogr.title: The Cambridge History of British Theatre: Volume 1: Origins to 1660

series.title: The Cambridge History of British Theatre

bibl.title: Tamburlaine the Great
bibl.author: Marlowe, Christopher
bibl.note: Christopher Marlowe's two-part historical epic play vividly and viscerally depicts the Scythian shepherd Tamburlaine's rise to become ruler of a vast empire and his subsequent demise after burning the Qu'ran and rhetorically challenging the prophet Mohammed. It was evidently a crowd-pleaser, being frequently performed at Philip Henslowe's Rose playhouse. VW took notes on both parts of the play, although non-consecutively. Her notes are collected in a composite notebook kept from 1922 to 1928, made up of loose leaf paper. In August 1923: she read the second part alongside Doctor Faustus and The Jew of Malta, writing that 'T. can embody his greater extreme of thought in words w. topple over, not ridiculous, so much as unwieldy' (RN25 28-30), while at some other point she read the first part of the play. Though this set of notes are sequenced after those taken in the summer of 1923, it is plausible that she read it beforehand, based on her observation that she expected Tamburlaine to face a 'downfall after his behaviour, to the virgins especially' (RN25 39-41). Tamburlaine does not face his expected downfall until the end of part two. Though she discusses Marlowe in essays and novels, she does not mention either play by name elsewhere in her corpus.

bibl.title: The Tempest
bibl.author: Shakespeare, William
bibl.note: One of the four tragicomedies or romances William Shakespeare wrote towards the end of his career (the others are Pericles, Prince of Tyre, Cymbeline, and The Winter's Tale). VW read this at least once: in a letter dated 7 January 1926 to VSW she says she is reading 'some of the Tempest, to compare with Defoe' in preparation for her essay on Defoe's novel published in The Nation and Athenaeum" and collected in CR2 (L3 226-7 §. 1608, cf. E5 376-82, RN 4). However, it is probable that she had encountered the work prior to 1926. As Clarissa Dalloway and Mr Grice discuss Shakespeare in VO, Grice quotes from the start of Ariel's song, 'Full fathom five...' though both express a preference for Henry V (VO 55, cf. Temp. 1.2.396-412). Terence Hewet's apostrophising of Rachel Vinrace as a 'creature who'd lived all its life among pearls and old bones' also echoes language from this song (VO 341). In a letter to Molly MacCarthy dated 19 January 1923, VW cites Ariel's song, writing that she has been 'struck down by the usual old temperature, which sinks my head fathoms deep in mud. Ought one not to find one's father's eyes when one sinks fathoms deep?' (L3 5-6, §. 1348). On 9 May 1934 VW visits Shakespeare's house in Stratford-upon-Avon and, on looking at 'Shre's garden' is told by the caretaker that ' "That was where [Shakespeare's] study windows looked out when he wrote the Tempest."' (D4 219). Fox references Shakespearean allusions, including to The Tempest in the drafts of Y (Fox 148-9).

monogr.title: Virginia Woolf and the literature of the English Renaissance

series.title: The Arden Shakespeare. Third series

bibl.title: Timber; Or, Discoveries
Timber: Or, Discoveries: Made upon Men and Manners
Timber: Or, Discoveries: Made upon Men and Matter: As they have flow'd out of his daily Readings; or had their refluxe to his peculiar Notion of the Times
bibl.author: Jonson, Ben
bibl.note: A compendium of quotations, maxims, and sententiae collected by Ben Jonson akin to a commonplace book, though Pebworth points out that it differs formally and stylistically from other contemporary examples of the genre, and is most likely a synthetic compilation of loose reading notes (164-5). It was published in 1640-1, shortly after Jonson's death in 1937. VW gestures to this work in her 1934-5 reading notes to the Faerie Queene (cf. RN 45). Timbers discusses Spenser twice: once in section 63, 'Censura de Poetis' [Judgement of the Poets], in which Jonson laments that public opinion ranks John Taylor, the self-proclaimed Water Poet, above Spenser (Jonson 34), and again in section 106, 'Praecipiendi Modi' [Modes of Teaching], Jonson writes of the order in which a pupil have writers introduced to them: he counsels teachers to introduce 'Sidney before Donne' and to 'beware of letting them taste Chaucer and Gower at first, lest, falling too much in love with antiquity, and, not apprehending the weight, they grow rough and barren in language only.' He then goes on to say that 'Spenser, in affecting the ancients, writ no language; yet I would have him read for his matter' (89). LLVW contains an 1898 edition of Timbers.

monogr.title: Timber; or, Discoveries: being observations on men and manners

series.title: The Temple classics

monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

bibl.title: The Unfortunate Traveller
The Unfortunate Traveller: Or, the Life of Jack Wilton
bibl.author: Nashe, Thomas
bibl.note: A work of picaresque prose fiction by Thomas Nashe that sees its protagonist Jack Wilton engage in seamy adventures across seventeenth century Europe. If VW ever read this work then no traces of her having done so survive. Her mention of the text in M1-8, 10 of 10 [The great house is visible in the pages...], fol. 4 mistitles the book, calling it the 'Poor Traveller.'

bibl.title: A Woman Killed with Kindness
bibl.author: Heywood, Thomas
bibl.note: A Woman Killed with Kindness, by Thomas Heywood, was first performed in 1603 though the earliest surviving text of the play dates from 1607. The play arguably originates the genre of the domestic tragedy, and its two intertwining plots deal with lust and chastity, friendship and duty, retribution and pity: for more detailed summaries of the play's two plots, cf. Acton, Sir Francis, Frankfort (Frankland), John, Frankford (Frankland), Anne, and Wendoll. The cry of 'Oh God' that Woolf cites in M.1-8-5. The Reader, fol. 2 punctuate the play: Charles Mountford cries 'My God – what have I done? What have I done?' (3.41) when he realises he has killed two of Acton's retainers, and Mountford's sister Susan, similarly, cries 'O God! O God!' (3.103) when her brother is imprisoned for the crime. Wendoll cries 'O God! O God! With what a violence | I am hurried to my own destruction. | There goest thou, the most perfectest man | That ever England bred [...] And shall I wrong his bed?' (6.16-20) when he is torn between his friendship with John Frankford and his infatuation with Anne Frankford. Having been told of his wife's infidelity by his servant, John Frankford says to himself in soliloquy 'O God, O God. | Shall I put up these wrongs? No. Shall I trust | The bare report of this suspicious groom | Before the double gilt, the well-hatched ore | Of their two hearts?' (8.102-5), and again cries 'O God, O God' when his servant presents him with irrefutable evidence of Anne and Wendoll's affair (13.47). He again exclaims 'O God' when discovering his wife's lute after having banished her (15.13), before directing his servant to bring the lute to Anne, while Wendoll provides the final O God, lamenting that he has 'divorced the truest turtles | That ever lived together' (16.49-50) on hearing Anne play this lute one final time.

series.title: Arden early modern drama

object.note: A comma is a butterfly of the species Polygonia c-album. In A History of British Butterflies (1853 but reprinted well into the twentieth century), naturalist F.O. Morris notes that this 'handsome and singularly shaped species' appeared across Britain, but evidently it was rare enough (at least in the south-west London suburb of Surbiton) by the time Woolf wrote to justify being mentioned in the newspaper. With its wings closed, the butterfly looks like a fallen autumn leaf; its wings open to reveal a 'beautiful rich fulvous orange colour.' Cf. Morris (70-72). Francis Orpen Morris (1810-1893) was a popular British naturalist, cleric, and anti-Darwinist. In JR, the young Jacob Flanders corrects one of Morris's works, probably the four-volume History of British Moths (1859-70), cf. JR 34

series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

object.note: The mythical sword of King Arthur. Malory offers conflicting accounts of how Arthur acquired the sword: his sword is referred to as Excalibur (32) shortly after pulling an unnamed sword out of the stone and thereby proving himself to be the 'rightwise king born of all England' (28), though later in the narrative Excalibur is bestowed upon him by the Lady of the Lake (47-8). In the aftermath of his final battle against Mordred, the dying Arthur commands Sir Bedivere to cast Excalibur back into the water, whereupon it is caught by an 'arm and a hand' (480).

monogr.title: Le morte Darthur: Sir Thomas Malory's book of King Arthur and of his noble knights of the round table.: The text of Caxton

object.note: In Arthurian legend, the Holy Grail is the cup used by Jesus at the Last Supper. It is sought by various members of Arthur's retinue: in Malory's version of Arthurian legend, many of Arthur's knights seek the Grail, most notably Lancelot and his son, Galahad, as well as Gawain. Only the purest and most morally upstanding of knights can complete the quest for the Grail, which knocks most of Arthur's retinue out of the running save for Galahad, though he dies shortly afterwards.

monogr.title: Le morte Darthur: Sir Thomas Malory's book of King Arthur and of his noble knights of the round table.: The text of Caxton

object.note:
A form of hot metal typesetting that does not require a compositor to arrange individual sorts by hand, but rather to type text for printing on a keyboard at an automatic casting machine. The machine would arrange copper matrices (letter moulds) into the correct order and then injected molten lead alloy into these matrices, which would cool to produce solid metal type. The set type could then be used for printing and then melted down for reuse. The first commercially successful machine of this kind was the Merganthaler Linotype machine, which, as the name suggests, cast a single line of type (referred to as a 'slug') at once (Linotype [1925] xxix). It was primarily used to print newspapers and cheaper paperbacks (OCB 884-5). However, the Mergenthaler Linotype Company did attempt to position their product as an aid for 'fine book-printing' (cf. Linotype [1923] vi). It was first commercially used in 1866 (OCB 884-5)
Monotype was a later development: the first monotype system was sold in 1900 (OCB 884-5). The monotype system could cast a page of type at a time, but more importantly, it also separated the work of composition from the work of casting. A Monotype system was composed of two separate machines. The first was a keyboard which at which a typist would create a representation of the print page on a 'paper ribbon' or punched tape (Monotype Keyboard 9-10). This punched tape would serve as instructions for the asting machine. The operator of the casting machine would feed the tape into the second machine, which would read the instructions punched into the tape and arrange the letter matrices into the order specified, which then could be cast (Monotype Casting Machine 48-55). This process was slower but more precise than Linotype, and the paper ribbon could be reused for later printings even after the original type had been melted back down, making it better-suited to literary texts. Hot metal typesetting represented one of the most significant developments in printing since the development of movable type and the introduction of the printing press to Europe.

The Oxford Companion to the Book

object.note: 'An instrument of torture for squeezing the fingers, similar to a thumbscrew' (OED). They were used to extract a confession of witchcraft from Geilles Duncane in the North Berwick witch trials, cf. 'Newes from Scotland...' (3).

monogr.title: Newes from Scotland, declaring the damnable life and death of doctor Fian, a notable sorcerer, who was burned at Edenbrough in Ianuary last, 1591.

object.note:
The arrival of the moveable type printing press and associated book technologies in England brings about a radical shift in literary production and consumption: in many ways, Woolf's literary history is one that follows in the wake of print. The technology was introduced to England by William Caxton in 1476, when he established a printers' office in the grounds of Westminster Abbey (OCB 595). The moveable type handpress was developed several decades earlier (c. 1440) by Johann Gutenburg, a goldsmith whose innovation was the introduction of metal movable type and, later, the invention of punch moulds that would enable the easy creation of type as well as a lead-tin-antimony alloy suitable for use in typecasting (OCB 11; 771-2). Gutenberg did not invent the printing press wholesale: woodblock printing was introduced to western Europe as early as 1418 (OCB 15-16), and precursors to Gutenberg's movable type were developed in East Asia far sooner: a series of Chinese essays published in 1088 describe the invention of ceramic moveable type by one Bi Sheng in 1041-8 (OCB 356). Nevertheless, his innovation enabled the print revolution in Europe, and the processes of founding type, compositing, and printing that Gutenberg developed remained standard practice until the development of hot metal typesetting in the late nineteenth century, and handpresses such as those that the Woolfs used would have been more-or-less recognisable to the creators of early print books.
In Woolf's literary history, Gutenberg's technology (and Caxton's introduction of it to England) is what simultaneously kills and preserves Anon's song, and indeed Anon himself. Anon is a figuration of the oral ballad tradition that acts as a prehistory for written literature in English, and as Anon's words are set in print they are put into a fixed form, the generative process of oral composition and re-composition brought to a standstill. In its place emerges the iterable printed word that can endure past the moment of its enunciation, and written literature.
VW's own experience of print technology, through the Hogarth Press, was formative for her literary practice. Battershill and Staveley provide brief summaries of the Press's commercial and literary activities, and Willis remains the standard history of the Woolfs' press. The name 'Hogarth Press' refers to both the publishing house that the Woolfs started in 1917, named for their house in Richmond, London, from which they printed and published, and to the handpress which they used to print works from 1917 to 1932. LW and VW bought a handpowered tabletop printing press (a platen-jobber press, though the precise model is unrecorded) in the spring of 1917, from the Excelsior Printers' Supply Co. on Farringdon Road, in London's Clerkenwell, with the aim of publishing their own work and that of their friends. The two were necessarily self-taught, as training could only be provided to apprentices (LW Beginning 233). By the end of the year, they had printed their first work, Two Stories. The Press's early works were printed in small runs: only 150 copies of Two Stories were printed, while their next publication, Prelude had a run of 200 and their third, Eliot's Poems less than 250 (Woolmer §. 1-3), but the press outsourced printing with increasing regularity from their second publication onwards, and by 1920, had started to employ the services 'commercial printers' (LW Downhill 65-6) whose mechanised presses diverged from the essentially Gutenbergian hand-powered press that the Woolfs themselves had purchased in 1917. Nevertheless, the Hogarth Press continued to issue books that the Woolfs themselves printed, first on the Excelsior press then on a treadle-powered Minerva platen press purchased in 1921 (Southworth ix). The final book they printed themselves was Dorothy Wellesley's Jupiter and the Nun (1932; Woolmer §. 313).
The Hogarth Press both worked in the wake of, and rejected, the revival of fine printing that originated with William Morris and his Kelmscott Press (1891-8, cf. LW Downhill 79-80, Wilson 36-7). Though LW talks vividly about the Press's use of brightly-coloured papers and cloths to cover their early works, and Vanessa Bell's designs for the dust-jackets of Hogarth books would become famous in their own right, their aesthetic was more homespun: Willis suggests that Roger Fry's Omega Workshop acted as a precursor for Leonard and Virginia Woolf's work at the Hogarth Press (10-13).

object.note: In Arthurian myth, the Round Table is both a metonym for King Arthur's retinue of knights, and the table where he and the knights would convene. Caxton, in his preface to Thomas Malory's Morte Darthur wrote that one could see 'at Winchester the Round Table' (Caxton in Malory 2): a large round table (or at least a tabletop) is kept in Winchester Castle (cf. Bruce 430).

place.note: Amesbury is a small town in Wiltshire, some two miles from Stonehenge. VW's sketch of her two visits to Stonehenge in 1903 (PA 198-200) make no mention of Amesbury.

monogr.title: A Passionate Apprentice: The Early Journals
Passionate Apprentice

place.note: An area of London in the borough of Southwark immediately south of the Thames, across the river from St Paul's Cathedral and the City of London. Early modern public playhouses were found here as early as 1576, preceded by bear- and bull-baiting rings (Chambers ii.355). The public playhouses built along the Bankside were typically round, open-air constructions with a 'pit' into which a stage thrust. They were banned from the City of London as early as April 1559 but there was no such prohibition preventing their establishment across the river (Chambers ii.357).

This site was a tenement attested to in a lease for the neighbouring Rose playhouse, dating from the reign of Henry VIII. It and its neighbours were described as lying "vppon the banke called Stewes"' (cf. Chambers ii.405). Stew is a euphemism: it is at once an obsolete word for brothel and a kind of 'lock hospital' where 'prostitutes were confined, and received the benefits of surgical assistance' (OED "stew n2, I.4a").

Little is known for certain about this playhouse. Chambers evidences its existence in 1560 and that it was assigned to the Queen's Men 'by a civic order of 28 November 1583 for their first winter season' (ii.381-2). A lease dating to Henry VIII's reign mentions that it abutted the site of Philip Henslowe's Rose playhouse and describes it and its neighbours as lying "vppon the banke called Stewes"' (cf. Chambers ii.405). Stew is a euphemism: it is at once an obsolete word for brothel and a kind of 'lock hospital' where 'prostitutes were confined, and received the benefits of surgical assistance' (OED "stew n2, I.4a").

A district in the City of London between St Paul's Cathedral and the Thames, centred around Blackfriars Bridge, which gave its name to two indoor, private playhouses, the latter associated with William Shakespeare and his theatre company, The King's Men. The area is named for a priory of Dominican friars (known as 'black' friars owing to the colour of their garb), who acquired land here in 1275 (Chambers ii.473). Over the next three centuries the priory waned in influence, and its estates were dissolved in 1538 by Henry VIII (ii.476). A theatre was established in the former priory in 1576 (ii.496-7). This first theatre hosted companies of boy actors and shuttered in 1587. In 1596, the building's refectory was sold to James Burbage, father of the Shakespearean actor Richard Burbage (ii.503). On James Burbage's death, his son inherited the theatre but he and the King's Men were prohibited from using it due to a combination of legal and business strictures until 1609 (Edmond n.p.), after which time its decades-long association with Shakespeare began: Shakespeare's company used it as an indoor playhouse during London's cold winters. Though it was smaller than outdoor public theatres such as the King's Men's other theatre, the Globe, it attracted an aristocratic and royal audience, though as Gurr notes, it was this royal association that proved 'one of the kisses of death that destroyed the King's Men and all the other players' in the wake of the English civil war, 'when Parliament signaled its opposition to their royal attachment by closing the playhouses in September 1642' (Gurr in Menzer 29). In Woolf, Orlando has property in Blackfriars, which has an analogue in Dorset House, the Sackville family's London residence (O 155, cf. also 419, n. 155:10).

analytic.title: London's Blackfriars Playhouse and the Chamberlain's Men

monogr.title: Inside Shakespeare: essays on the Blackfriars stage

series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

place.note: A historic prison in Oxford which held Hugh Latimer and Thomas Cramner, among others, before they were burnt at the stake. It stood from some time in the thirteenth century to 1771, when it was demolished (Hibbert 49).

South Cadbury is a small village in Somerset, England, and the site of Cadbury Castle, a sprawling neolithic hillfort that spans some 18 acres. In his Itinerary of 1542, antiquary John Leland identifies Cadbury Castle as the site of King Arthur's castle, Camelot (Leland I.151).

monogr.title: The itinerary of John Leland in or about the years 1535-1543

place.note: A city in south-east England and home to one of England's two ancient universities (the other being Oxford). Though VW did not attend either university, many in her immediate family did, and the Bloomsbury coterie had its roots in the Apostles (the Cambridge Conversazione Society), of which (inter alia) LW, E.M. Forster, Roger Fry, John Maynard Keynes, Lytton Strachey and Saxon Sydney-Turner were members, and Leslie Stephen had been a member a generation prior. Banfield traces the profound influence that the Apostles and Cambridge philosophy had on Bloomsbury aesthetics and Woolf's writing (cf. in particular 8-14; 26-36). Room has its roots in talks VW gave at Girton and Newnham Colleges, in October 1928.

monogr.title: The Phantom Table: Woolf, Fry, Russell, and the Epistemology of Modernism
A Room of One's Own and Three Guineas

place.note: The legendary castle of King Arthur and his retinue, and the capital of Arthurian Britain kingdom. Though there was likely no historical Camelot, Caxton and Malory both identify Winchester as Camelot in Le Morte Darthur, while in his Itinerary of 1543, antiquary John Leland locates it at the site of a neolithic hill fort just south of the Somerset town of Cadbury.

monogr.title: The itinerary of John Leland in or about the years 1535-1543
Le morte Darthur: Sir Thomas Malory's book of King Arthur and of his noble knights of the round table.: The text of Caxton

place.note: A medieval city in Kent, southern England. Canterbury Cathedral was founded in 597 (though the structure is largely twelfth century) and is the locus of the saint's cult dedicated to Thomas à Beckett, the 'turbulent priest' Henry II assassinated. In Chaucer's Canterbury Tales, the pilgrims journey to the cathedral to pray at Beckett's shrine.

A city in the northwest of England, close to the Scottish border. Woolf refers to the city's connections to Arthurian mythology. In Le Morte Darthur, Carlisle is a significant location. Tristram and Palamides fight here, and Palamides is christened after Tristram defeats him (Malory 347); Arthur heals Sir Urre at 'the meadow of Carlisle' (447), and, having discovered Lancelot and Guinevere's affair, sentences Guinevere to burn at the stake here: Lancelot rescues Guinevere and in the process kills many of Arthur's retinue (458-9). In other Arthurian writings, Gawain is tested by the Carl of Carlisle (Bruce 105).

series.title: Garland reference library of the humanities

monogr.title: Le morte Darthur: Sir Thomas Malory's book of King Arthur and of his noble knights of the round table.: The text of Caxton

place.note: The English Channel is the stretch of sea separating southern England from northern France. Dover is a major port as it is located closest to France: the Strait of Dover is only 33km wide.
A street in the City of London to the west of St Paul's Cathedral.
Ceremonial county in northern England, to the south of Liverpool and bordering Wales. The Fytton family originated here.

The Chopping Knife was likely a tavern or hostelry in central London, but concrete evidence attesting its purpose or location is scanty. Newdigate-Newdegate collects an account of seventeenth-century gossip whose locus is the Chopping Knife, and whose key actors are Mary Fytton and William, Lord Pembroke. The quotation which VW excerpts here reads:
One Mrs Martin who dwelt at the Chopinge Knife near Ludgate tould me [that] she hath seene preists mary gentlewomen at the Courte, in that tyme when that Mrs Fytton was in great fauour, and one of her Majestie's maids of honour, and duringe the time yt the Earle of Pembrooke fauord her she would put off her head tire and tucke upp her clothes and take a large white cloake and marche as though she had bene a man to meete the said Earle out of the Courte. (36)
Beyond this, little evidence attests to the existence of a place named the Chopping Knife or its function. The City of London Corporation Library contains a collection of seventeenth century tradesman's tokens, effectively an illegal form of coinage issued not by the state but by individual traders, collected by Henry Beaufoy. The 1855 edition of this collection's catalogue references a coin with a 'chopping knife.' On its obverse is written 'IN THE STRAND' and on its reverse 'IN WESTMINSTER' and the initials 'S. S. M.' (Burns 232, §. 1122). The Strand is a historic street in the City of London that runs from Trafalgar Square to Temple Bar and then (as Fleet Street) up to Ludgate Hill and St Paul's Cathedral. What kind of establishment the Chopping Knife was is not recorded. VW read Newdigate-Newdegate in preparation for the 'Anon' drafts, and specifically notes down this part of the narrative (RN37).

monogr.title: A descriptive catalogue of the London traders, tavern, and coffee-house tokens current in the seventeenth century; presented to the Corporation Library by Henry Benjamin Hanbury Beaufoy. By Jacob Henry Burn

imprint.publisher: Printed for the use of the members of the Corporation of the City of London

monogr.title: Gossip from a muniment room; being passages in the lives of Anne and Mary Fitton, 1574 to 1618.

place.note: This site was a tenement attested to in a lease for the neighbouring Rose playhouse, dating from the reign of Henry VIII. It and its neighbours were described as lying "vppon the banke called Stewes"' (cf. Chambers ii.405). Stew is a euphemism: it is at once an obsolete word for brothel and a kind of 'lock hospital' where 'prostitutes were confined, and received the benefits of surgical assistance' (OED). In O, Nick Greene recounts an anecdote involving Christopher Marlowe and William Shakespeare which takes place at 'the Cock Tavern in Fleet Street' (82): on returning from their honeymoon, VW and LW lived in rooms off Fleet Street and took their meals at a Cock Tavern after some unsuccessful attempts at home cooking (Lee 324).

series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

place.note: A playhouse on the Bankside, close to the Rose. Chambers does not discuss it but it is described by Greg as a 'recognized stew' (ii.3), using almost identical language to that of a lease that describes the Rose, Barge and Bell as lying "vppon the banke called Stewes"' (cf. Chambers ii.405). Stew is a euphemism: it is at once an obsolete word for brothel and a kind of 'lock hospital' where 'prostitutes were confined, and received the benefits of surgical assistance' (OED).
A district of east London, on the southern banks of the Thames. Christopher Marlowe was killed in a brawl here by Ingram Frizer on 30 May 1593.

A major port on the south coast of England, on the Channel. In Thomas Malory's Le Morte Darthur, Dover is the site of Arthur's first battle with Mordred, who had usurped his throne (Malory 475): his nephew Gawain is killed in this battle, and interred in a chapel in Dover Castle with his skull left visible to all (477). In his prologue to the Morte, William Caxton writes that Gawain's skull could still be seen at the castle.

monogr.title: Le morte Darthur: Sir Thomas Malory's book of King Arthur and of his noble knights of the round table.: The text of Caxton

place.note: Essex is a large county in south-east England, abutting London. It is bounded to the south by the Thames Estuary. It plays a minor role in the 'Anon' drafts: Woolf notes that Thomas Betson was from Essex.

The Fortune was a playhouse located north of the Thames, in the parish of St Giles' Cripplegate (the medieval church in the present-day Barbican complex) and therefore outside of the jurisdiction of the City of London. It was built in 1600 by theatre financier Philip Henslowe and actor Edward Alleyn, whose instructions for the builders specifically referenced the Globe. This building burnt down in December 1622, and it was later rebuilt, though this was dismantled in 1649 (Chambers ii.435-442). Cf. Orrell for a detailed examination of the playhouse's construction.
Gawsworth is a village in Cheshire, England. It is the ancestral home of the Fytton family: Mary Fytton and her father Edward both originated here.

Almost certainly the best-known of the Bankside playhouses, the Globe was home to the Lord Chamberlain's Men, later the King's Men: William Shakespeare's theatre company for much of his career. Built in 1599 from the dismantled timbers of the Theatre playhouse, Gurr describes its construction as an 'attempt to retrieve something from the disaster of the Theatre's closure and the ban on the use of the Blackfriars hall playhouse' (369). Its lease was initially held in common by members of the Lord Chamberlain's Men, including Shakespeare, actor William Kempe and financier Richard Burbage: this is notable because 'for the first time, actors became joint owners of the playhouse in which they worked, and the Globe became the first playhouse designed for a specific company' (White 317). The 'wooden O' that the prologue of Henry V (prologue, 13) most likely references was burnt down in a 1613 performance of Henry VIII ' "by negligent discharge of a peal of ordinance"' which landed in the building's thatched roof, setting light to it (Chambers ii.419). The playhouse was almost immediately rebuilt, and only met its end when the building was ' "pulled downe to the ground [...] on Munday the 15 of April 1644, to make tenements in the room of it"' (ii.427).

series.title: The Arden Shakespeare. Third series

monogr.title: The Cambridge History of British Theatre: Volume 1: Origins to 1660

series.title: The Cambridge History of British Theatre

place.note: A country estate to the west of the city of St Albans, Hertfordshire. It is the ancestral home of the Bacon family, and both Anne Bacon and her son, Francis lived here, though the Elizabethan house they inhabited is now in ruins.

One of London's four Inns of Court at which lawyers would train and practice law. It was also a site of early modern performance. Students would perform plays and masques, and theatrical companies would visit, most notably the Lord Chamberlain's Company, in which Shakespeare acted: they performed The Comedy of Errors here in 1594 (SHaLT Gray's Inn). In JR, Jacob signs papers in Gray's Inn: he is perhaps training to be a lawyer or works as a clerk (145).

series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

place.note: A district of south-east London, on the banks of the Thames. Greenwich Palace (originally referred to as the Palace of Placentia) was rebuilt by Henry VII and served as the primary location of the Tudor and early Stewart courts, until the Civil War. In O, the newly-crowned King James attempts to 'curry favour with the citizens' by turning the frozen Thames at Greenwich into a 'park or pleasure ground, with arbours, mazes, alleys, drinking booths, etc. at his expense' and sets up his court behnd a 'silken rope' in this winter wonderland (32-3).

series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

place.note: An Elizabethan country house built from 1590-97 by Elizabeth Talbot (Bess of Hardwick). VW stayed at Teversal in summer 1904, two miles away, while convalescing from a period of mental illness (PA 249, n. 12). On 15 November 1940, she writes to VSW that it is 'angelic of [her] to wish me to write another book. But at the same time devilish. Havent I 20 books sizzling in my head at the moment. Then you tempt me with old Bess.' Evidently VSW has suggested that VW write a book about Bess of Hardwick; Woolf suggests that VSW writes it instead (L6 455, §. 3659). This does not stop Woolf from writing to VSW on 26 December of the same year to ask her for a 'life of Bess of Hardwick,' probably as research for this literary history. There is no evidence to suggest whether or not Woolf read Talbot's biography.

monogr.title: A Passionate Apprentice: The Early Journals
Passionate Apprentice

place.note:
A castle in Warwickshire, built by Robert Dudley, a favourite of Elizabeth I. Walter Scott's Kenilworth: A Romance (1821) is largely set here, and features three pageants, two of which have historical analogues, albeit the final and most elaborate of the three is fictional (Arata 104). The novel narrates a power struggle in the Elizabethan court. This struggle takes place as Dudley is entertaining the Queen and her retinue at Kenilworth, and the novel's three pageants, each of which narrates a period of English or British history, are part of this entertainment. The final of these, during which the novel's denoument unfolds, depicts the 'strife between the English and the Danes' with 'one party of the [nearby] town's folk present[ing] the Saxons and the other the Danes' (Scott iii.271) The narrator calls the 'whole exhibition [...] a sort of anti-masque or burlesque of the more stately pageants, in which the nobility and gentry bore part in the show, and, to the best of their knowledge, imitated with accuracy the personages whom they represented.' This entertainment is 'more incongruous and ridiculous' (iii.273-4). Despite, or perhaps due to, the incongruity, the ridiculousness, Elizabeth enjoys the entertainment and 'laughed heartily at the imitation, or rather burlesque, of chivalry, which was presented in the Coventry play' (iii.278).
Edmund Spenser appears briefly (and perhaps anachronistically) in the narrative (ii.114), though not in relation to any of the pageants.
LLVW contains a 1821 edition of Scott's historical romance, though no reading notes on it remain extant. Woolf may also have known about the contemporaneous Kenilworth Castle Pageant, held 08-15 July 1939 (cf. Bartie et al.). This was a sizeable affair, attracting some 20,000 spectators over its week-long run, and was reported in the Manchester Guardian and the London Times.

monogr.title: The Redress of the Past: Historical Pageants in Britain
The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

imprint.publisher: Printed for Archibald Constable and Co.; and John Ballantyne, Edinburgh; and Hurst, Robinson, and Co., London.

place.note: A house and estate in Sevenoaks, Kent, and the ancestral home of the Sackville-West family, as well as the fictional home of Orlando. Lady Anne Clifford was mistress of Knole from 1509 onwards through her marriage to Richard Sackville. One important manuscript for her diary was copied and stored at Knole, and Vita Sackville-West used the Knole manuscript as copy-text for her edition of Clifford's diary, which Woolf cites throughout the 'Anon' drafts (cf. Malay 8).
A tributary of the River Thames that flows from its source in Luton, Bedfordshire, and south through the Chiltern hills and through east London, where it joins the Thames.

Capital of England and the United Kingdom. VW spent much of her life here (whether in Kensington, Richmond, or Bloomsbury), as did her family and most of her social circle, and Bradshaw calls Woolf 'synonymous with' London (229). All of her novels (bar TL and BA) have scenes set in the city. As the locus for early modern theatre, print culture, and court, London is a place of vital importance to Woolf's literary history.

A bridge crossing the River Thames, linking the City of London and Southwark. There has been a bridge at this location since at least 1209 (the one Woolf would have known was opened in 1831 and transplanted to Lake Havasu City, Arizona, in 1971). In O, the Thames at London Bridge has frozen 'to a depth of twenty fathoms' and an 'old bumboat woman, who was carrying her fruit to market on the Surrey side' has frozen solid there (33), while centuries later, the ship on which Orlando returns to England weighs anchor close to the bridge (154).

series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

place.note: Historic province of Scotland encompassing Edinburgh, the capital, and, of note here, North Berwick. The witch trial that Woolf relates happened in North Berwick, and the witchy happenings that the trial sought to uncover were carried out both in North Berwick and in Lothian more broadly. Cf. entry on North Berwick for more details.

Lundy is a small island in the Bristol Channel, off the coast of Devon, England, inhabited by a flock of puffins and other seabirds. It is unclear why VW mentions Lundy in this context, though in Macbeth, the First Witch says that she will sail 'in a sieve' to Aleppo (Macb I.iii, l. 8).

series.title: The Arden Shakespeare. Third series

place.note: A seventeenth century tavern on London's Cheapside. The tavern had literary-historical resonances: playwright and poet Ben Jonson was among its frequenters, as was Francis Beaumont and his collaborator John Fletcher. A drinking society named the 'Fraternitie of Sireniacal gentlemen' are also associated with the tavern: O'Callaghan suggests that John Donne was part of this group. Popular legend also places Sir Walter Raleigh, Thomas Dekker and one William Shakespeare here as part of a quasi-mythological Mermaids Club, but O'Callaghan is sceptical of this club's existence.

A county in the east of England with many Woolfian resonances. VW most of August 1906 in Norfolk when the Stephens rented the Elizabethan manor house Blo' Norton Hall, in a remote part of the county: it was '7 miles from a railway; & every mile seems to draw a thicker curtain than the last between you & the world' (PA 310). While at Blo' Norton, she wrote the short story 'The Journal of Mistress Joan Martyn,' set in the locale. Some decades later, in a letter to Vanessa Bell dated 25 May 1928 VW writes that she and LW are considering selling Monks House after 'some hanky panky with the agent behind [their] backs' leads to the sale of their terrace and the threat of building work thereon: VW 'see[s] from advertisements one can get the most ravishing old houses with gardens and orchards in Dorset, Suffolk or Norfolk for a mere song' (L3 500, §. 1895). They drive along the north Norfolk coast in March 1932: VW's joy in the 'lovely lonely coast' between King's Lynn and Cromer is tempered by her grief at the recent death by suicide of Dora Carrington (D4 84).
In VO, St John Hirst comes from Norfolk 'the son of the Reverend Sidney Hirst, vicar of Great Wappyng in Norfolk' and later refutes the rumour that he has 'Jewish blood in [him]' as his family has 'been in Norfolk, Hirst of Hirstborne Hall, for three centuries at least' (160, 232), while in Woolf's next novel, Ralph Denham takes a cottage in Norfolk (310) but does not leave London before the novel's end. The county is part of the mental landscape of several characters in MD. Richard Dalloway is not a fan of his wife's parties: in an aside we learn that 'to do Richard justice he would have been happier farming in Norfolk' (69), and his thoughts turn to Norfolk and its 'soft warm wind' as he shops for jewelery with Hugh Whitbread (101). Among the credits to Whitbread's name is 'the protection of owls in Norfolk' (92), while Mrs Hilbery questions whether 'some Mongol had been wrecked on the coast of Norfolk [and] had mixed with the Dalloway ladies' (110). Captain Frederick Marryat, whose writings and Life and Letters Woolf reviews in the 1935 essay 'The Captain's Death Bed' died in Langham, ' "two miles from the sea, on the coast of Norfolk'" (E6 65). Sir Thomas Browne lived in the county town, Norwich (cf. entry on Browne for more details), and the Paston family took their name from the town of Paston, on the north Norfolk coast (cf. 'The Pastons and Chaucer,' E4 20-38).

monogr.title: A Passionate Apprentice: The Early Journals
Passionate Apprentice

place.note: The county town and largest city in Norfolk, East Anglia. It was home to Sir Thomas Browne (cf. entry on Browne for more details), and in the CR1 essay 'The Pastons and Chaucer,' Woolf writes that John Paston was buried roughly twenty miles north of Norwich (E4 20) and that William Paston 'retained' Norwich monks to 'pray for his soul "for ever"' (23). The early short story 'The Journal of Mistress Joan Martyn' is set in the vicinity of Norwich: the frame narrative takes place as historian Rosamond Merridew is making her way along the Thetford road from Norwich to East Harling (CSF 35) while the titular Joan Martyn spent her early life in a hall along this road (41-62).

monogr.title: The Complete Shorter Fiction of Virginia Woolf

place.note:
Small town in the historical kingdom of Lothian, east of Edinburgh (not to be confused with Berwick-upon-Tweed). North Berwick was the locus for a spectacular witch trial in 1591, reported in the anonymous pamphlet 'Newes from Scotland...'. The pamphlet describes the torture and confessions of a number of suspected witches, the magical misdeeds they allegedly performed, and their eventual executions. Relevant to Woolf's narrative are the testimonies of Geillis Duncane and Agnes Sampson.
Duncane was maidservant to one David Seaton: Seaton 'had his maide in some great suspition' because she 'in short space did perfourme manye matters most miraculous,' and he 'supposed it done by some extraordinary and unlawfull meanes.' Seaton had Ducane tortured and 'did with the helpe of others, torment her with the torture of the Pilliwinckes upon her fingers, which is a grievous torture' ('Newes' 3). This act of torture, in front of James VI of Scotland, marked the start of the North Berwick witch trials, which would run for two years and saw the arrest of over 100.
Agnis Tompson confessed that she was among some 200 who 'went by Sea, each one in a Riddle or Cive [...] to the Kerke of North Barrick in Lowthian' (7) where they took part in a Sabbat. Moreover, Tompson confessed that she was among those who christened a cat, 'bound to each part of that Cat, the cheefest partes of a dead man, and several ioints of his bodie, and that in the night following the said Cat was conveyed into the midst of the Sea' (16-7). This was the 'cause that the Kinges Maiesties Ship at his comming foorth of Denmarke, had a contrary winde to the rest of his Ships' (17). The 'contrary winde' that 'Newes' discusses delayed King James's marriage to Anne of Denmark, and was popularly attributed to witchcraft (Willumsen).
James VI wrote a three-volume dialogue titled Daemonologie on sorcery, witchcraft and magic. LLVW contains a 1924 volume that reprints both 'Newes...' and Daemonologie. VW notes both titles separately as part of a reading list for her literary history (RN 37), though if she took notes on them then they do not survive.

monogr.title: Newes from Scotland, declaring the damnable life and death of doctor Fian, a notable sorcerer, who was burned at Edenbrough in Ianuary last, 1591.
King James, the First : Dæmonologie (1597). Newes from Scotland, declaring the damnable life and death of Doctor Fian, a notable sorcerer who was burned at Edenbrough in Ianuary last (1591)
