monogr.title: The Library of Leonard and Virginia Woolf: A Short-Title Catalog

analytic.title: Witchcraft against Royal Danish Ships in 1589 and the Transnational Transfer of Ideas

place.note: A city in southern England, and home to one of England's two ancient universities (the other being Cambridge). These drafts focus on Oxford's long history as a locus of religious dissent in the fourteenth, fifteenth and sixteenth centuries, which was viewed as heresy by the authorities of the time. Dissenters discussed herein include John Wycliffe and Hugh Latimer. Other figures from these drafts associated with Oxford include Robert Burton, author of An Anatomy of Melancholy, and A. C. Bradley who was Oxford Professor of Poetry.
Not coterminous with present-day Palestine: rather, this usage typically refers to the eastern Mediterranean more broadly, centred around the city of Jerusalem.

The family seat of the Sidneys from the sixteenth century onwards and home to Sir Philip Sidney, his brother Robert Sidney and, before her marriage, Mary Sidney Herbert. The stately home was a locus of courtly literary culture: in several fragments herein, VW figures its doorway as the portal to an incipient literary modernity. VW visited the house with Vita Sackville-West, meeting its contemporary inhabitants, on 14 June 1940, the day that German troops entered Paris and, according to Woolf, 'the first day that invasion becomes serious' (D5 296-7).
A parish in Essex, centred around a village of the same name. William Harrison was rector of this parish from 1591, recommended to the position by his patron William Brooke, Lord Cobham.
The seat of three regimes or powers relevant to VW's literary history: the Roman empire, the Catholic Church, and Mussolini's fascist Italy.

The Rose playhouse in London's Bankside was named after its location, in a former rose garden and a ' tennement then called the little rose wirth twoe gardens"' (cf. Chambers ii.405). The site was purchased by Philip Henslowe in 1585. It abutted several other tenements that would become playhouses: a lease refers to the Barge, Bell and Cock on its boundary, which 'lay "vppon the banke called Stewes"' (ii.405). At least two of Shakespeare's early plays were performed here, prior to the formation of the Lord Chamberlain's Men: Henslowe's diary records performances of 1 Henry VI and Titus Andronicus from 1592-4 (cf. Gurr 365). Henslowe's diary attests that began building the playhouse in 1592 and provides some insight into the activities of the playhouse. Its foundations were excavated in 1989 and archaeological work at the site has evidenced the construction both of this specific theatre and others like it (Orrell and Gurr).

analytic.title: What the Rose can tell us

place.note: District of London on the south bank of the Thames, across the river from the City of London and centred around London Bridge. The Rose was the first playhouse to be built here in 1592, with several others, including the Globe following thereafter. In Geoffrey Chaucer's Canterbury Tales, the pilgrims set out from the Tabard Inn, in Southwark.

St Albans is a small cathedral city in Hertfordshire, to the northwest of London. St Albans Cathedral is the oldest site of continual Christian worship in the United Kingdom, and Gorhambury House, several miles outside the city, was home to both Anne Bacon and her son, Francis. In Malory, it is the site of the final battle of Uther Pendragon, King Arthur's father (Malory 27-8, cf. also Bruce 434).

series.title: Garland reference library of the humanities

monogr.title: Le morte Darthur: Sir Thomas Malory's book of King Arthur and of his noble knights of the round table.: The text of Caxton

place.note: VW writes about this central London cathedral most sustainedly in 'Abbeys and Cathedrals,' the fourth of the six 'London Scene' essays she published in Good Housekeeping magazine 1931-2 (E5 301-6), contrasting it with the nearby Westminster Abbey. She writes of the cathedral's 'colourless serenity' and its complete lack of mystery compared to the Abbey close by (302). In Y's 1914 chapter, Sara and Martin bump into one another on the cathedral's front steps and share a meal in a chop-house close by. In O, the dome of St Paul's Cathedral is one of the first sights Orlando sees on her return to London, though not the building that she remembers: rather, she sees 'the dome of St. Paul's which Mr. Wren had built during her absence' (152). The older construction had been destroyed in the 1666 Great Fire of London and Wren had designed the new, domed, cathedral in the years that Orlando was absent.

series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf
The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

place.note: Prehistoric standing stone circle on Salisbury Plain, two miles from Amesbury. While staying in Salisbury, August 1903, VW visited Stonehenge twice with Vanessa Bell. She wrote a sketch in her diary on each occasion. In the first sketch, she writes that 'The singular, & intoxicating charm of Stonehenge to me, & to most I think, is that no one in the world can tell you anything about it. There are these great blocks of stone; [...] & what more? Who piled them there & when, & for what purpose, no one in the world [...] can tell,' and calls the circle 'a piece of wreckage washed up from Oblivion.' Given that the culture that built Stonehenge left no written records, many of VW's questions remained unanswered or unanswerable. Later on she writes that the most 'attractive, & I suppose most likely' theory about the megalith's purpose is that 'some forgotten people [...] built here a Temple where they worshipped the sun,' and conjectures that a fallen stone in the middle 'may have been an altar' on which 'the Priest of that savage people slaughtered his victim [...] in honour of the Sun God' (PA 199-200). In her second, briefer, sketch describing their second visit, she calls the megalith 'a kind of altar made of earth, on which the whole world might do sacrifice' (205). These early descriptions and suppositions are of a piece with her invocation of Stonehenge as a site of ancient ritual in M.54-8.

monogr.title: A Passionate Apprentice: The Early Journals
Passionate Apprentice

place.note: A south-western London suburb, south of the Thames and across the river from Hampton Court Park.

This playhouse stood at the western end of the Bankside. It held performances as early as 1596 (Chambers ii.412) and is last attested to in 1637 as ' "fallen to decay and like a dying swanne hanging down her head seem[ing] to sing her own dierge"' (cf. Chambers ii.414).

Woolf refers to this Norman keep infrequently in her work. It is one of the first sights that Orlando sees on her return to London (O 152), while in the 1940 short story 'The Legacy,' Angela Clandon writes in her diary that she visited the castle with 'B.M.' (CSF 285). The tower sits at the western extremity of London's historic docklands and in 'The Docks of London' (1931), the first of the six 'London Scene' essays VW wrote for Good Housekeeping, Woolf describes it as 'the knot, the clue, the hub of all those scattered miles of skeleton desolation and ant-like activity' (E5 277).

series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

monogr.title: The Complete Shorter Fiction of Virginia Woolf

place.note: VW writes about this Anglican place of worship in 'Abbeys and Cathedrals' (1932), the fourth of the six 'London Scene' essays she published in Good Housekeeping magazine 1931-2 (E5 301-6). She contrasts it to St Paul's Cathedral: whereas St Paul's Cathedral is 'spacious and serene,' Westminster Abbey is 'narrow and pointed, worn, restless and animated' (301) and far from being silent, the dead interred there, the 'Kings and Queens, poets and statesman still act their parts and are not suffered to turn quietly to dust' (302). It is among the first sights that Orlando sees on her return to London (O 152). The narrator of Room tells her audience that '[a]ll women together ought to let flowers fall upon the tomb of Aphra Behn, which is, most scandalously but rather appropriately, in Westminster Abbey' (60). Behn is interred in the abbey, though not in Poets' Corner, where a number of writers relevant to the 'Anon' fragments are either buried or memorialised, including (inter alia) Chaucer, Coleridge, Ben Jonson, Samuel Johnson, Marlowe (disputed), and Shakespeare.

series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

place.note: Historic county in the north of England which now forms part of Cumbria. Anne Clifford inherited her father's estates in Westmorland, though not after a lengthy legal struggle. In so doing, she became a wealthy landowner in her own right. Clifford's diary makes reference to her active role as landowner, collecting rents and pursuing lawsuits against her tenants.

monogr.title: The Diary of the Lady Anne Clifford: With an Introductory Note by V. Sackville-West

place.note: A street in Westminster, London leading from Trafalgar Square to the Houses of Parliament. In Woolf's time and contemporaneously, many departments of the British Civil Service are located here, and as such it has become a metonym for the Civil Service more broadly: cf. for instance, Woolf's multiple uses of the term in TG. Within the timeframe that the 'Reader' fragments describe, Whitehall was the site of a palace occupied by British royals from Henry VIII's reign to its near-total destruction by fire in 1698. It is to this palace that Elizabeth I summons the young Orlando (O 23). In MD, Peter Walsh watches a procession of '[b]oys in uniform' march up Whitehall to lay a wreath at the Cenotaph (46). BA refers to this street in its allusion to a sexual assault that took place at Horse Guards Parade, a barracks on Whitehall (BA 15 cf. Clarke 3-4). M111, set 3 of 3 [The Reader: Anonymity was a great possession] contains a draft of this portion of BA at fol. 5v (cf. Phillips 198-207 for analysis of this folio).

analytic.title: How Should One Read “The Reader”? New Approaches to Virginia Woolf’s Late Archive

The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

monogr.title: A Room of One's Own and Three Guineas

series.title: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Virginia Woolf

place.note: A village in Wiltshire, England, which gives its name to a country house, which was the home of the Herbert family, the earls of Pembroke: Mary Herbert lived here after marrying Henry Herbert, third earl. VW visited Wilton on a family holiday to Wiltshire in 1903, writing two sketches about her trip. The first, 'Wilton – From Outside the Walls' describes the village of Wilton as 'more smug & well pleased with itself than the majority of English villages [...] that sit in the shadow of a great house,' leading her to conclude that 'it is safe to say that the feudal spirit in England is not yet dead' (PA 188-90). VW returned at a later date, when the house was open to the public and 'the public [could] enter the great gates of Wilton as freely as any Herbert in the land.' She was not altogether pleased with the excursion: 'Honestly, I was disappointed in my first view of a great house. I had imagined something more spacious & more harmonious.' Returning to the diary entry a week later, she writes: 'I can find nothing very profitable to say about the beauties of Wilton' (196).

monogr.title: A Passionate Apprentice: The Early Journals
Passionate Apprentice

place.note: Winchester is a cathedral city in Hampshire, southern England. Thomas Malory identifies Winchester as the site of Camelot, perhaps influenced by the large round table kept in Winchester Castle (the table-top hangs in the castle's hall at the time of writing). In asserting the veracity of Arthurian legend and the historical reality of Arthur, Caxton argues that 'at Winchester [one can see] the Round Table,' as well as 'many other things' (Caxton in Malory 2). Cf. Bruce 430, 496.

series.title: Garland reference library of the humanities

monogr.title: Le morte Darthur: Sir Thomas Malory's book of King Arthur and of his noble knights of the round table.: The text of Caxton

place.note: Ancient county in the north of England composed of the North, West and East Ridings of Yorkshire and centred on the city of York. In A Woman Killed with Kindness, Wendoll makes reference to Yorkshire (6.40), while Thomas Middleton wrote a play called A Yorkshire Tragedy (1606?, initially attributed to William Shakespeare).
